reviews.review: Loved it! Good shopping!. Big long street full of fun stalls, with off the side interesting markets.The things on sale are amazing! Lots of local handicrafts, but also markets and stalls with lots of crystal and ceramic tiles and glass soda siphons. It looks like an amazing clear out of Art Deco houses.Go, really great fun, even in the rain as happened to us!
Bohemian Old Neighborhood. Quaint and friendly. Lots of restaurants and bars. Huge2 mile long Sunday street market on Defensa Av. Old sidewalks in poor repair. Fun place to visit.

Great Way to spend a Sunday Afternoon. Great Street Market, and great food and entertainment. I bought a lot of artwork there and the people are so nice and friendly. Great Sunday place to hang out and check out the local flavor

Great place for a walk, not too much to offer though. The San Telmo Feria takes place on Sundays, and is a very nice walk from San Telmo, from the south, all the way to the Plaza de Mayo, with a stop at the Mafalda statue on Calle Chile in between. It has some interesting gift offerings and nice art, but don't expect anything too fancy or really worth spending too much in. Great for a Sunday morning visit.

Great area, go after the Sunday market. It's gets very buzzy after dark with Tango del Indios, go to the Plaza Direego and watch the locals and keen tango dancers do their stuff, just brilliant. Later at 11pm visit Peru 561 for the Maldita Milongo only in B A.

We went Twice!. This was such an enjoyable afternoon that we went back and spent the afternoon before leaving Bs As. We had lunch at a cafe that featured a couple dancing tango! it was a lovely way to end our stay.

Best on Sundays. Be sure to visit on Sunday. While walking on the main pedestrian thoroughfare, wander around in parallel streets and blocks to see art murals on the walls and shops. Be careful with your belongings while walking in crowded areas. Can easily spend 4 to 6 hours in a day depending on your interest. Or just 2 hours for a quick jaunt. Be sure to visit Pasaje de la Defensa- the historic shopping area

10 days in San Telmo. Rented an apartment on ST in September for 10 nights. The neighbourhood is charming, Never felt unsafe. Loved going to the market in the morning to get fresh croissants and baguettes. Every thing you need is a short walk away. Sunday market is amazing. In my opinion the best place to stay when visiting BA.

How to 'Do' San Telmo. San Telmo market is a must see. It runs every sunday from about 11am until about 5ish, 6ish 7 ish, depending on the stall holders!First of all, wear good shoes and have tons of cash with you. You can buy everything on this market. If you dont buy anything, then you need cash to pay all of the street entertainersI suggest that you don't go on a very hot day, the market covers 'one' street, and goes on for about 3km. Start at Plaza Dorrengo and just keep walikng !!If you are looking for a quick danse, look out for the 'old man with a hat.....' we found him, he is fantastic ;) near the PlazaI decided not to take children as i had heard about how busy it is. Yes its true, the streets are narrow with stall holders on both sides. Leave the kids behind and have fun on your own!!As the market packs away, head to Chacabuco block 900, -(possibly 942, 3 blocks away from the market) for a Tango lesson in a lovely old cultural centre with 2 great teachers. The lessons start about 17h30, and stay for a practise at this lovely early Milonga- costs 80 pesos per person. coffee and biscuits included :)At about 7pm head back to Plaza Dorrego for the public Milonga, grab some food and a beer and relax in the atmosphere of San Telmo. At 8pm grab your dancing shoes (or just a seat) and join in with the Milonga in the plaza.Stay as late as you like (hence the no kids advise!!)Didn't see any 'dodgey' characters all day/night, and had a fantastic day outThe only downside was our choice of carpark in the afternoon....it was 4 blocks off the main plaza and down a bit of a badly lit quiet side street---not a great idea walking back at midnight. SO i advise you to move your car at about 7pm into the side streets/ car park off the plaza, as they are well lit and LOTS of people around.Felt safe all day, except the dodgey 5 mins at midnight DO it... enjoy it....go back next Sunday.....;)

Sensational San Telmo. Did this one twice. We toured through the area on a city tour and we were curious to see more. Sunday is a big craft, music and market day and we were excited to go back. Many talented people offered everything from paintings and leather crafts to music and foods. There was also a huge antique area in a very interesting old building. It was a very interesting area to stroll in.

A Visit You Should Not Miss When In B.A.. Every Sunday don't miss the fair, from music, to local crafts, painting to antiques to great food, there is something for everybody.
Here you can also find the Mafalda statue, a famous Argentian cartoon along with other famous characters..

Touristy but charming. My favourite spot has to be Walrus Books....and some eateries which are rather local and unique. Weekends are a blast as many vendors will be out on the street. A must for any visitor to Buenos Aires.
San Telmo. Do not miss visiting not only the square, but also the closed market and watch for some of the old buildings

Nice area to stroll around. We enjoyed walking through the streets of San Telmo. Lots of pretty buildings, numerous antiques shops and plenty of restaurants. Doesn't really come alive until mid afternoon, so don't plan an early morning visit!!

Great Vibe - antiques, cool crafts, cafes . Loved my visit to St Telmo, the weekend antiques market is fascinating, I have been to markets all over the world and saw many antique objects here that I have never seen before. There is also a strong artisanal culture with some fabulous original locally made products from Frida Kahlo image bottle top earrings to a fabulous Venus print neoprene iPad cover. In the search for interesting and unique things, this is my favourite market.

Unique shops in San Telmo. San Telmo is teeming with lots of restaurants, bars and antique shops. The architecture is interesting and a lot of older buildings still stand. One of the oldest bars in BA can be found here. You will also see a few murals on the sides of buildings which are quite moving! There is also the large inside mercado.
Must visit when in Buenos Aires!. If you love antiques, coffee, tango, arts and crafts you have to go on the weekend to San Telmo, it one of the nices places to visit in Buenos Aires!
Cool vintage vibe. Around every corner there are cool details dating back to early 20th century. Cool little antique shops everywhere. Relaxed vibe with some cool parks. Not too touristy.
Absolutely fantastic!!. Saw them live at a milonga (place where people meet to dance tango) and they were excellent. Lively, vibrant... A must see if you want to experience true Argentinian culture.

Average neighbourhood. Booked my hotel in San Telmo neighbourhood as it was highlighted as one of the best options to stay for travellers. However, I was a little disappointed.Maybe, because I was visting BA in the weekdays there was not much happening in the neighbouhood. However, it would be one of the cheaper neighbourhooda to stay for travellers as the others such as Recoleta, Palermo etc. are very expensive in terms of hotels and restaurants.

street entertaiment. it is worth walking the streets of Defensa quarter , i have listen to at least 3 street orchesters - amazing feeling to see that musicians play , that tango couples dance as it is Covent Garden and not a simple Buenos Aires street. and it is not just 2-3-5 musicians, there are at lest 12-14, a whole orchestra, a lot of small local shops, there you would see the vibrant city during daylight.there have been several smaller flee markets too. Worth to be seen and filled

The old town. Bohemian, chick, filled with people from all over the world, home of the true Buenos Aires café. Cobblestone streets, tunnels connecting different sectors, classy antique shops. A must-see!

Must visit district of Buenos Aires!. We stayed in San Telmo for a few days and really felt at home here - very friendly with great bars and shops. The market on Sunday is huge and full of the usual, and not so usual, stuff, and generates a great atmosphere in the area. Well worth a visit.

Plaza under renovation!. Not the same vibe with street tangoers etc when the entire plaza is dug up and dusty. A lot of atmosphere with narrow crowded streets and buses barreling by. Sitting at a corner cafe the view is not what I remembered from previous visits.
Good for antique shopping. This place is famous for antique shopping. Unfortunately we didn't get a chance to visit the Sunday market.

Lovely markets!. The markets go on and on and on - it was fascinating. So many cool things, we did our souvenir shopping here. I was surprised by how much variety there was. Strolling through thess cobbled streets was a truly lovely way to spend a day!

Very much a working class neighborhood. Where our hotel was located and very much a working class neighborhood. We walked all over the area and always felt safe. There are a multitude of small restaurants so we tried a different one each night. From anywhere in San Telmo the metro is a short walk, or you can walk to the Plaza de Mayo in about 20 minutes. Watch out for the dog droppings on the sidewalk here and everywhere in the city for that matter.

SUNDAYS BEST, ALWAYS BUENOS AIRES !. Choose any Sunday and you will be part of the biggest, more enjoyable Flea Market I ve ever seen, you will be able to get to most awesome memorabilia and things to collect, furthermore have excellent eating options, coffee and desert, or just watch nice people pass by !

Best neighborhood in town. The San Telmo area is known as the antique district, but I would call it the bohemian district. It reminds me of Georgetown in DC. I walked for miles around central Buenos Aires and could not find any Starbucks, but there is one in the small San Telmo area. There are many indoor markets for the locals and souvenir shops for the tourists. I enjoyed walking the small streets and I always felt safe, even late at night.
Me gusta san telmo. I find some telmo to be very touristy but enjoyable at the same time... I liked the bars in the street and having a beer with friends

Disappointing . Having read a few reviews, I had high expectations of the area. However, I was quite disappointed. Some streets were filthy and I only saw a couple of nice buildings, with 'colonial architecture'. I was in BA during the week so I can't comment on the antiques market/fair. Also the weather wasn't great, for 75% of my trip, so that's probably coloured my view. I popped into some antique shops...the doors are locked so you have to knock be let in, and a couple of shop assistants seemed miffed that I didn't buy anything. I went to the Museum of Contemporary Art (MACBA) which I felt was a rip off at 60 pesos. The best part of San Telmo was by far Café San Juan (on Avenida San Juan) which had delicious food. I wouldn't stay in San Telmo again- I think Palermo or Recoleta are much better areas.
Enjoy. Take your time and enjoy this nice place. You ll arrive by uber only 10 minutes from obelisco. Good food and drinks. Many people take care with your values. GOOD!!

Nice neighborhood. San Telmo is a nice neighborbood to visit during the day or at night. Many of the streets are still made of stones like in the colonial period. The neighbood is close to Porto Madero, so I would suggest a visit to both locations on the same day. The sunday fair is just ok, I actually prefer to visit the neighborhood on saturdays to avoid the crowd. Not sure about staying here during your visit, but def a nice place to check out and spend some time. Stay away from the restaurants around the san telmo square.

A great flea market. It's for sure one of the best open markets I have already visited, wehere we can find anything and also listen to great traditional songs, have nice food and enjoy a great Sunday!

A must when visiting Buenos Aires. Very long and wonderful flea market full of lovely items that include food, art, leather, specialties and jewelry. A perfect way to spend a Sunday morning or afternoon walking and listening to local musicians as you sample the best that the local artisans have to offer
Beautiful. Lovely place to spend some time. The San Telmo market on Sunday was the largest market I've ever seen with loads of variety and plenty of creativity.

Not as quaint/charming as I was expecting. After reading rave reviews of San Telmo, I was really looking forward to visiting it. While it is more quaint than many other parts of BA we visited, I wasn't blown away. The majority of the vendors were "antiques" (sure there are treasures for those willing to hunt -- think of it more as flea market finds). We got there around closing time so, unfortunately, weren't able to try food from any food vendors. It is a nice place to walk around and there are many stores and restaurants to check out. Overall, felt like any old city center that has become a tourist trap. Worth a walk through it, but once you check it off your to do list it isn't something you need to go back to.

Vendors, Artists & Antigues. A great place to get a feel for some of the local artists, and some of the old antiques of Argentina. Crowded, some things a bit overly commercial, but oveall a great experience on Sunday.

Our local in BA . We loved our little place in San Telmo. Whilst a little off the centre of city, had a great vibe about it. Cool art works, graffiti and many many little restaurants. I'd defiantly recommend it.

Excellent walk. Sunday morning walk from Casa Rosada till San Telmo PlazaHundreds of artisans and local art, antiques and souvenirsPlaza is more sophisticated and somehow not as bargain as used to beNice experience!!!

Sunday Market is a must "To-do" in Buenos Aires. Go on Sunday and start at Plaza de Mayo. Begin your journey by walking down “Defensa” street all the way to Plaza Dorrego. I've been to flea markets but nothing that extends nearly 2km!At first, I was hesitant to purchase anything believing there would be 10 other stands just like it however I was surprised by the variety of goods for sale. Everything from antiques to food to clothes to souvenirs and jewelry etc. I actually found a few items worth bargaining for. And once I reached the end (at Av San Juan), there was no subway nearby, so I turned around and came back and realzied I had missed a lot on my first round through – likely due to the overwhelming selection and large crowds.Do not go souvenir shopping until you go to the market! And you can get some great deals here - make sure you negotiate too! And buy some of the street food to keep you energized for all your shopping. Enjoyable way to spend a Sunday while most of the rest of BA is closed.
Nice walk for a Sunday evening. It was a different and new experience. Lots of nice things to see.We found a lovely bar and had some drinks in a really friendly place.Loved it!

Drive Through. I will start saying that we did not walk the area, but a friend drove us around and gave us a tour. This is neighborhood has a bohemian feel to it and is filled with antique stores. I was told there is a antique fair on the weekends, but there is also a market open during the week. Not sure this is for everyone, it seemed safe, but it was in the afternoon.

Great shopping! Artisans Market!. I really enjoyed this market. There's so much to look at. It's perfect for souvenirs and to get scarfs. I also loved the ambiance of the places with street food and music. It's a must!!!

Fantastic time in San Telmo. My hotel was in Plaza Dorego which is in the heart of San Telmo so during the day it was like being in a 1930's cowboy movie. San Telmo is known for its antique shops and the dark wood café s. The Plaza also has 5 bars which each have very good live entertainment each night. Keep in mind that in Argentina dinner is eaten about 9:30 and entertainment starts about 11pm. I would go to bed at 5 pm and get up at 8pm to go out. One night there was jazz, next night a live salsa band and the next night flamenco. Really, really good bands as well. One thing to mention, the people in Argentina love graffiti, they consider it to be a high art form, even tagging, so whn you head into San Telmo, you will see a lot of graffiti. I still am not walking alone at night in the neighborhood outside the plaza, I take a cab, but this is a very tourist friendly, warm and wonderful part of Buenos Aires.

Tango, every day.. A great Barrio with many choices of restaurants and bars. You'look find tango being performed in front of many of the restaurants. Lots of video and photo opportunities from outdoor restaurants. Be careful of your wallet!

Large Sunday Flea market. If you find yourself in BA on a Sunday, consider strolling down this one long street which is closed off to traffic. Many of the items at this very large flea market are of an antique nature, however all kinds of interesting stuff is made available for purchase. Not everything is at the cheapest price. You must know your prices. There are also many stalls selling food. You can also hear a number of musicians and bands playing at different locations throughout the flea market. A piece of advice, the street can get very crowded, so beware of pickpockets. Keep valuables in a safe place, as the pickpockets are real pros.
Walking tour. This afternoon I visited San Telmo. It was insightful to see another side of Buenos Aires ... The cobblestones streets are quaint and the people lovely ...
Great Market. We found some great souvenirs here and enjoyed talking with the artisans who made them. A great way to spend a Sunday in BA.

Old and quaint. The older part of town and lots of history. The bars and cafes are on every corner . The weekend markets in ladefense rd are the biggest I have seen . They go on for kilometres and have lots of cool stuff.

Fun and Funky. We were only in San Telmo for 24 hours, but we stayed in the area and walked at night, feeling very safe. The graffiti is everywhere! Some of it looks like gang tags, but a lot of buildings are covered in beautiful art! My suggestion to the local homes and businesses, if you don't want a "tag" on your building, paint a mural. There seems to be a "gentlemen's code" among graffiti artists to avoid defacing another's work. The antique shops were plentiful. Cute restaurants and cafes scattered about and art galleries everywhere. Walking distance to the water, the Plaza Mayor, Florida Street and more. We will definitely stay in the neighborhood again and hope to be there for the weekend as there is tango on the streets and a huge market day on Sundays.
Wonderful Sunday Outing. The best place in Buenos Aires to see wonderful architecture, antiques and collectables, musicians and restaurant in just a few blocks of walking.

Back to IXX century. Old Buenos Aires at a glance .Hundreds of restaurants, bars and live music . Also some street artists performing on week ends . Parking it's a major issue. ....a cab from down town is better than drive. Some precautions needed in late nite if walking alone . Regular dining starting at usd 20 each.

Quaint and historical... safe?. We stayed nearby so we're here four times in the week we spent in B.A. Lots of food options, a questionable "market" and a feeling of slight unease each night. The buildings, cobblestone, and antique shops made up for any shortcoming.
Historical grandeur and taste. Wandering the streets of San Telmo, it reminds me of Roma. Antiques, markets, food and grand architecture, what a wonderful place to get lost in

Artisans alley. What an incredible place to stroll through stall upon stall of goods and artisans' art, jewelry, etc. on a Sunday afternoon! Start at the beginning of Defensa at Plaza de Mayo and amble all the way down to Plaza de San Telmo at least 2-3 miles down. On the Plaza de San Telmo, you'll find old telephones, crystal, and linens, but you'll also come upon a beautiful tango show. A great way to pass the day on a weekend while visiting Buenos Aires!

Artisans Fair is excellent . Every Sunday on Defensa, there is a seemingly endless artisan fair, with very reasonable prices. It is a great place to spend the afternoon, with food, beverages, clothing and crafts. Going earlier is better, as it tends to get very crowded, especially when the weather is nice.

Gotta be World's BIGGEST Antiques/Flea Market!. I came here expecting a big market for antiques, but the size of this market is beyond comprehension! The square at the center of San Telmo has the best concentration of antiques but on Sundays they close down the street and it goes on and on. It would take the better part of a couple of hours just to walk the length of it. If you have a Sunday off in Buenos Aires then this is where I would go - extend your trip if you have to.

Nice place for evening walk on Sundays. If you are interested in street market, then this is the place you can hang on on Sunday. There are multiple restaurants, street shops to purchase souvenir items of BA, Argentina. This is the very attractive place for locals and tourists on Sunday throughout the year. Most of the places the items are non-negotiable and you may end up paying bit extra if you don't know the actual prices. However if you are not keen in purchasing anything and just want to roam around, then do visit this place at least once during your stay.

Sunday market is great for people watching. I had a hard time finding anything I wanted to buy here despite the size of the market, which seems to go on forever. However, it's worth visiting because you'll find tourists and locals here. Pay attention to the stores/restaurants lining the streets behind the vendors. I ducked into a packed restaurant that was clearly local and ordered an empanada to go.

Sunday perfect day to go. going there on Sunday is the best choice if you want crowd and a hippy market. During the week is more calm but still plenty of charm. looking for the market indoor ( open every day) you have a mix of antique, food, music..etc.
in San Telmo you can find also nice shop selling Tango Shoes
Darling!. If I could I would live here. The area has so much charm. Cafe, restaurants, Plaza with Tango dancing, a festival, corner specialty markets (bakery, meat, pasta etc...).

A happening place and market on a Sunday afternoon. We missed the San Telmo experience first time we visited Buenos Aires, so this time made for the legendary quarter and its vendor lined cobblestone streets. It is a great spot to soak up the joie de vivre and, in better weather than we had, some sun. Mum and Dad were dancing tango in the square to a solo guitar accompaniment ... perhaps their son? He was very accomplished and daughter was selling his CD's. There are rows of stalls as far as the eye can see selling everything from antiques to leather to clothing to toys. Great photo ops, so take the camera.

if you want to visit San Telmo, go on weekends. I was at San Telmo during the week and it is a sad place. Very few people, at the market most of the stands are closed and the general feeling is grimsly.

A MUST on Sundays - Antiques and Tango. Buenos Aires started here .... and today it is an area to walk around (specially on Sunday -Market Day). Street artists, the market with antiques and many other things, beer shops, cafes, restaurants. TANGO!. A perfect place for a Sunday afternoon (from 12 to 7 pm).

my fav place in BA. I really love San Telmo. And why is that U ask? Well:- lots of street art, so murals and music - great coffee places- lots of tango places- good nightlife- big street market each sundayDo not hesitate to go there!

Fun, interesting shopping - Great for Antiques. Truly one of the treasures of Buenos Aires are the antiques which reminded me of the flea market district in Paris. Cobblestone streets, friendly people, diverse little stores and some real bargain finds. Fun shopping and local people watching.

A great stroll. We went here on a Sunday for the market. A great experience and quite happy to spend any hours wandering around the stalls. Lots of musicians, but no tango dancers when we went which was a shame - may have been a bit early for them. Great coffee in the Dorrego Bar - thoroughly recommend
Sunday fair. Great place to visit on Sunday when they have the San Telmo Fair. It is full of tents selling local art.
full of character. The San Telmo area in in Buenos Aires and is an interesting neighbourhood with lots of local colour and character.
Sunday. If you come to this place you have to go a Sunday because this day is more crew and you can see san Telmo bazaars and buy some craft stuff

Fun place. This is the old district of Buenos Aires. This area was the original site where well to do people lived before the turn of the twentieth century. Today the original stone roads add to the charm of the district and there are many restaurants and antique shops which add to the charm of the place. The markets operate daily and there are many street stalls on the weekends. A must see and an enjoyable place to see.

Fun spot.. I stayed in this areas of Buenos Aires close to walk to all the main sights. Recommend the area main square a short walk away, and the walking street for shops and markets. Lots of bars in walking distance.
Love it!. Very nice market with tons of artisan and vendors. You will find also good places to eat authentic food.

Must see neighbourhood of BA. Try come on a Sunday when they have the markets for about 2km up Defensa and in Dellegro square. A lot of antique shops along the way too. A lot of junk, but good people watching, a lot of live music and yummy food to pick up too (churros, empanadas, calzones).
Tango and more. Very nice for a saturday night and sunday afternoon. Lots of places to enjoy tango music and dance, and very good restaurants both cheap and expensive.

Flea and antiques markets everywhere. If you like flea and antiques markets this is the right place for you, but can be very busy on weekends. You will find (specially on weekends) a lot of tourists. In Plaza Dorrego could find a lots of coffees and beer stores, probably some tango dancers or/and musicians. You could also go to lots of museums, the city museum in defensa 219 (is free), the national museum of the history of the outfit in Chile 832 (not sure if was free or not) or the modern art museum in Av. San Juan 350 or contemporary art museum in Av. San Juan 328, this last two charge a little feed (between $20 and $40 at most)
Different.... If you have some time on a Sunday stroll down Calle Defensa and see all the stuff and art they have for sale, it is a great experience.

Fun but touristy. There is a great market every Sunday along Defensa and in Plaza Dorrego. The area is very historic, but also very touristy. The market had some hidden gems but was also a lot of junk. Worth checking out but don't spend the whole day there.
Good!. It's nice to walk around, it felt safe and the stores are really good to visit, they are usually about furniture, chandeliers or home decoration.

Sunday activity. Much to see on a Sunday at the street fair. Lots of craft and local food on sale, as well as other little trinkets. Bands and musicians were also exhibiting their craft. Large crowds in the street. We were told to beware of pickpockets.
Aus. Great area lots of things happening this is a must see area of buenos aires .... amazing markets on sundays loved it ..stayed longer than intended
Just fantastic.... Walking through San Telmo is transported to ancient Buenos Aires, bars, restaurants, outdoor cafes, the flea market on weekends are a must.
I love San Telmo. What an amazing area with a colorful soul and classic architecture. San Telmo market is an absolute must-do.

Old style Buenos Aires. This is where Buenos Aires was born before it moved further north to Recoleta and Palermo.I love it's cobble stoned streets, small bars (like El Federal, Poesia & Seddon), cafes like (Plaza Dorrego) and great parillas like (La Brigada, Desnivel & Don Ernesto).The feeling of this barrio is unparalleled and a walk along Defensa each Sunday for its markets is a must.I fully recommend staying in this area or at least a visit. If you're short for time then a walk along Defensa from Independencia to Plaza Dorrego will get you started!

Take a tour with Joy of Buenos Aires. Without a tour we would have never appreciated the history of the area, the church with its tunnels built by the Jesuits, the flooding and relocating , truly makes a different to have a tour and Joys was the best!! La Boca and San Telmo drip with history.
Incredible. One of the best neighborhoods in Buenos Aires to be at, to see real Buenos Aires with outsider eyes... just fanstatic. you cannot miss it out
Sunday in Buenos Aires. When visiting BA it is a must, touring San Telmo on Sundays. You have music, dance, various artists, food, and all kinds of designers. Is a Bohemian part of the city.

The authentic view of Buenos Aires . There are so many areas in Buenos Aires it is sometimes hard to get a true sense of the city but this area seems the most unique and distinct. I felt like I was seeing the true city here.

A Sunday mandatory destination.... Antique stores galore!..., very good quality street art. Stand in different spots and just observe the surroundings. Look up to the buildings..., turn 360 degrees and see things from the next perspective. Simply people watching is a treat here! Regretfully, eateries around here are a rip off.

A very underrated place!. We stayed in San Telmo for 5 nights at the Lemon Apartments in Chacabuco street! And we had a great time. The place feels like you a close to everything and would have loved to stay for much longer.We arrived at night and the first thought was that it is a bit dodgy, but as time goes on, you see that this is the way it is and the place has some serious good spots to eat, to have coffee, the market on Sundays and we enjoyed it very much.Would stay there anytime again!

Market on Sunday . Save san telmo until Sunday when they have their local market up and down the street. Busy and bustling a nice way to spend the afternoon.Nice reaturants around. Very short walk from centro
Interesting old and rusty neighbourhood. Visit San Telmo if you want to get a glimpse of old Buenos Aires. Plenty of antique shops café/restaurants

A must visit. Went on a rainy Sunday but you would have never known it was raining with all the vendors out as well as people. If you plan on buying souvenirs this is the place to be. The vendors are very friendly and they did take dollars. There are restaurants where you can have lunch and continue shopping. There are also local vendors that sell local food. We were there in July so make sure you dress warmly and take a large umbrella.

Cool rustic and chilled out part of the city.. San Telmo is filled with tonnes of cafes, bars, antique shops and the smell of cooking meat. If you sleep through your hostel's compimentary breakfast you'll only have to walk for 15 seconds before you find a bakery or pizzeria or milenesaria or parilla and the list goes on. There are lots of cool pieces of street art speckled throughout this little section of the city and on any given night you can find a bar playing tango, reggae, punk and I'm pretty sure I walked past a couple of poetry readings or spoken word nights. There is no problem with finding a place to eat dinner at midnight, or even 2am for that matter, and you'll find that not only are you not alone in this endeavor but that tables will be filled with young and old passionately conversing and consuming wine. Check out Moretti Bar for good beer, good people and good music. It's neighbour, Refuerzo has a big wine selection and good food. If you can find the market on Carlos Calvo, there is a coffee town that served the best coffee I had in Argentina.It's a good spot to stay in BA and although I've never been to New York, I feel it has a rival for the title of 'The City That Never Sleeps'.

Walking gets fun. My kids and I really enjoyed this trip...walking and just seeing people perform on the streets. When we went it was winter so it was cold but it's so worth it and definitely a must do when in Buenos Aires. It's about 4 long streets filled with Argentines selling their products from bags to cloths to all you can think of artsy. We absolutely loved it. It happens every Saturday and Sunday from 11am till 6pm. Also you can negotiate on the items and there is a park near so if you want your kids can play while you sit around and water people. It's about 25min from palermo hollywood area. And any taxi driver knows the place. Great for the whole family.

You can´t miss it!. If you don´t know San Telmo, you don´t know Buenos Aires!Antiques, Tango dancers, accordeon players and tipically Argentinean people! It´s a lovely place to visit on Sunday mornings!

Sunday market!. Before the yellow fever epidemic, this was the area where the high class lived. The buildings are very nice and the cartoons in the streets are nice to watch. Don't miss the Sunday market!

Sunday market. Lovely architecture...lovely calm environment Great to mouch around and enjoy the atmosphere Sunday market drew us to the area... Prices in the antiques stalls seemed very high to us...but we are no expertsLots of indoor markets not to be missedNo hassle from anyone A real must visit...in flat shoes as the streets are cobbled
Exquisite quarter. Loved every corner of it! Lots of eateries, antiques shops, beautiful historic buildings. Very nice atmosphere.

Amazing shopping experience on a Sunday morning . The market of San Telmo is few blocks away from the famous plaza the mayo. It is all set to go by 10AM and is really pumping throughout the day. I must admit i saw things what I never saw in life which is unlikely for a normal flee market. If you are into arts this market is perfect. A must go place if you around BA.

We love this one. this was awesome with so much to see and do. got to watch live music on the street and so many people and vendors. really you can spend the whole day there and still need to return to finish the walk. and great prices.

Very touristy!. Having visited about 10 years ago we were disappointed as it seems to have lost its luster or maybe we are just that bit older!! Appears to be more touristy now with more shops selling cheap souvenirs. Still an enjoyable stroll through one of Buenos Aires' famous spots
Market on Sunday. We visited this Historic area on Sunday when the crafts market runs for 20+ blocks. The indoor markets, antiques shops were a a great experience.

Spirit of Buenos Aires.. Great place to visit. We were here sunday to see market and experience the ambiance of BA. Music playing, dancing tango, market stalls with original artisanal goods for sale. Great atmosphere. Many antique shops to visit but prices quoted much higher if you are not a local!!!

Feria de San Pedro Telmo. I love San Telmo and come here often. The shops and restaurants are excellent and the neighbor hood is home to many artists and musicians. The number one place to go while in San Telmo is the Feria de San Pedro Telmo, it's a large co-op building that houses many many businesses. I come here for the produce and some meats and I always stop by Coffee Town to have coffee and buy some beans. You can buy anything from collectibles and antiques to clothes for everyone. It's worth you time to stop by while your in the neighborhood.

Looking for a fun Argentine place to go. This is a most among all the places to visit in Buenos Aires. Yup! You won't regret, specially if you come with family or friends . There is tango on the Plaza, even on the restaurants, you could also buy antiques and souvenirs. Then finish the afternoon at one of the restaurants near the Plaza filming or dancing with a tango teacher after your meal.

The heart of BA. San Telmo was very nice, I stayed in a hotel directly on Plaza Dorrego during the weekend. The street "Defensa" and Plaza Dorrego was the best choice to stay during weekend. Live music, nice food & drinks, interesting art galleries
Markets on Sunday fantastic!. Loved this market and could have stayed here for hours. Was really worth a visit and if you have to get some souvenirs perfect.

Feira de San Telmo. An incredible place. On Sundays, there is the "Feira de San Telmo" which you just cannot miss. There are hundreds and hundreds of small kiosks where several products are sold, like small gifts, leather bags, empanadas and dulce de leche. Some places accept other currencies like the american dollar and the brazilian real.

A must do in sunday With caution. and without bags,. a great experience, I have born in Buenos Aires and the last time I visit San Telmo was 8 years ago and have to improve a lot without losing his soul, we got several souvenirs, good prices, but some other things are really overpriced like antiques. Attention, on Sunday market, is very crowded and is people everywhere traying to cut your bag or small kids around trying to get your purse ,DONT BE NAIVE even kids are professionals, so go only with cash as the stores only accept cash most of them , and use a belt under your clothes as you will not feel the hands of kids when they are trying to get your purse. enjoy the place is great, and they normally use the tango shows on the streets of San Telmo to hit the targets,

It may have seen better days. We stayed at San Telmo during our 2 days in Buenos Aires, as I heard from many that this was a nice area of the city. It has indeed some few charming streets, with cobblestones, antique shops and nice places to eat, aside from being very centric, however I found that this neighborhood may have seen better times. I was staying at a AirBnb in Peru avenue, and though it was generally quiet, it felt a bit unsafe at night as it was pretty solitary and the building were kind of old, vandalized and dirty. As well, streets tend to be covered on dog poop and thrash in some places.I recommend visiting the San Telmo market, which has interesting antiques and book shops, but aside of it I would rather stay at another neighborhood if I visit Buenos Aires in the future.

Good food but….. Visited Buenos Aires in April 2016 and walked to San Telmo on a weekend to visit the market and had an enjoyable time and a very good meal afterwards. However, would not recommend travelers to walk there at night, and should not be carefree with your bag even during the day. Lots of artistic graffiti to photo and cute historic cartoon characters to get your selfie with! Do recommend a visit and a meal.

My Favorite of Buenos Aires. San Telmo was my home for about 5 weeks while I was in Buenos Aires. The cutest cobblestone streets with quaint restaurants and little boutiques. San Telmo, in my opinion is the place to stay. It doesn't get too rowdy at night, but does have a few fun bars. Don't pass up this barrio if staying in Palermo, worth the cab/subte ride!
A sundays shopping. Great place for a stroll on a Sunday wandering around the stalls and listening to the banter.Nice place to see some Tango and pick up a few bits.

Local flavours, great food and corners to explore for hours!. San Telmo is the perfect place to spend a lazy Sunday evening and walk for hours. You will find street carts full of empanadas, other local cuisine and homegrown musicians on every corner. The roads are normally cleared for the feria so you can walk around without any hesitation. Antique displays both in stores and on the streets, locals mingling with tourists and live performances - what's not to love?

San Telmo and surroundings. We went here after a huge meal with Jorge and Jimena.It was about a 30 block walk one way.Here are many antique shops,tango dancers,clubs,restaurants and a wide range of activities.The mate(Mah-tay)cups are often made here on the plaza by hand,along with the bombillas.There is much to do both day and night..many historic places.See photos.

Good destination for Fotographers!!. The San Telmo Church is the center of this part of Buenos Aires, here you will find very good restaurants, Tango shows at night, antiques and a flea Market on Sundays.You just have to look around a bit to find very interesting motives for nice pictures.Enjoy!!

Famous for restaurants and street feir. It is a place where there are so many restaurants it is hard to choose - all price ranges, all kinds of foods. Once a week, on Sunday, a fair is set up in thr square, lots of carts all selling cheap goods - some fake. "Old" furniture is roughed up, and wooden pieces are shot ar with a 20 gauge shotgun to stimulate wormholes. All round the square are good shops, with appropiate high prices. Tourist tend to buy souveniers from the carts, and most of the time, buy rubbish, not too cheaply. Chap eats all round the square. Visit, but don't buy, unless in a good shop.

Missing something. Everyone else seems to think that this is a lovely area, but i just walked around and didn't really see anything much of interest, a small square was about it.There are much prettier areas to go to if you are short on time. I would go to La Boca area over San Telmo every time.
Great Sunday stroll. Pleasant Sunday activity. Wear flat shoes and just walk.Enjoyed the whole market experience. Sellers are not pushy just browsing is fine.

Worth a Sunday visit . A large part of this area becomes a flea market on Sundays starting at around 10Am. While this is not my cup of tea, I enjoyed the walk on a beautiful weather day. Two added attractions were some art galleries and lots of antique stores. Another thing I likes about the area are the beautiful, even if I bad need of repair and restoration, buildings.

Great spot for antiquing. This is a lovely neighborhood, with high- and low-end antique shops. Don't miss the artists fair on Sundays! San Telmo is the patron saint of sailors, and the 10 symbols behind the altar reflect that emphasis. Cool!

Lazy Sunday afternoon in San Telmo. One of the best things we did during our trip to Argentina was a couple of hours spent in San Telmo on Sunday afternoon.Great market with plenty of small stalls selling clothes and souvenirs. What makes that experience worth the visit is not the shopping (although some interesting souvenirs may also be found) but numerous live performances of local musicians, dancers and other street artists. The guitar player that performed on one of the corners was so great, that I purchased his CD and was listening to that music for weeks after coming back from Argentina. The tango dancers on one of the squares were as good (if not better) as those we saw in the famous Cafe Tortoni. We also had a chance to sit down over a beer and wine in one of the numerous open-air cafes, with a traditional jazz band playing live and a charleston dance school showing their skills and inviting audience to join them for dancing.What an atmoshpere!!
Sunday market at San Telmo. If you are planning a visit to BA, make sure you have a sunday to spare to visit San Telmo flea market. The place is awesome!

Great browsing in flew market, local trinkets, performers on Sunday. On a chilly Sunday the street was full of craft vendors and the park full of flea market stands. There's a Starbucks midway along if you're looking. To tell of the leather is authentic smell it. All the little bracelets we saw were authentic, many of the wallets were not. Great place for photography and strolling.

Great place on Sunday. In Buenos Aires many chops are closed in the WE. So, how to keep busy yourself in such a town?San Telmo is certainly an option. Walk from the "Plaza de Mayo" to San Telmo, you will find many shops and bars open. Furthermore, there are plenty of people selling local products, art pieces, antiques, etc... You will enjoy also people playing music and singing...To sum-up, I place not to miss in Buenos ires if you have sometime free... Enjoy it!

INCREDIBLE SUNDAY FLEA MARKET - ON THE "MUST DO" LIST FOR YOUR BUENOS AIRES VISIT. If you are lucky enough to be in Buenos Aires on a Sunday - you must spend at least part of your day at the Feria de San Telmo (San Telmo Flea Market). Every Sunday, thousands of locals and tourists descend on the San Telmo area to walk street after street viewing the wares being offered by hundreds of vendors. There is a square where there are regular booths which sell strictly antiques, but as you walk the surrounding streets you will find crafts, souvenirs, clothing, food stands and more. Guide books tell you there are 270 stands - I think this refers to the actual market - but there are hundreds more on the surrounding streets.Besides for the many vendors selling from their street booths, there are brick-and-mortar galleries, antique shops and restaurants. Many of the buildings in this older area are themselves worthy of more than a casual glance for their wonderful turn-of-the-century architecture. Along the way you will pass musicians, singers and dancers performing in the street. One of the highlights for us was a wonderful tango performance. We arrived early (about 10:00 in the morning) and walked the entire length of the market area from Parque Lezama all the way down Defensa (street) to Plaza de Mayo (where you will find the Casa Rosada and the main cathedral).We were there for about five hours but you can either do it faster than we did or not cover as much ground and still get a feel for this unique and fun Sunday market.Between the antiques and crafts, the food and music - the Sunday San Telmo street market should definitely be on your “do not miss” list for a visit to Buenos Aires.Note: Our concierge and our taxi driver both warned us to beware of pickpockets. Given how very crowded it can get - it seemed good advice.

Buzzing marketplace with souvenirs and artwork.. Make sure to do this on a sunny day and make a day of it, stopping to eat and snack. It is a buzz, and crowded, but really nice. The attraction here is the markets, the food, and also at night where you can go to Tango clubs.

Overrated part of town. Has a long way to go before becoming an enjoyable experience.One suggestion: start w/ holding dog-owners responsible for removing their dog's poo off the side walks ... at present pedestrians will encounter sizeable mount every 5+ meters :-((
San Telmo Market. The weekend market was my favorite. Picked up some many great bargains, bags, belts, ART galore. Also great eats in the area.

A good browse. An interesting walk with lots of antique shops with interesting wares but with high prices. Stumbled on "El Zanjon" a very well restored 1830s tenament house under which are tunnels and remains of the original settlement dating back to 1536. The San Telmo Markets were a disappointment with a lot of junk.

Do not elevate your expectations. The "Mercado San Telmo" has lots of stores with antiques. Some of the stores are really beatiful with great stuff and old objects for sale. On sunday there is a traditional "MARKET". It seems that they sell old objects of recent passed away people. The objects are not well conserved and does not seems to have great deals.

Lovely area to walk through . Nice area with antique stores that have anything from antique jewelry to furniture. I found it very interesting and would come back to look around more but we couldn't stay long. We heard this area can be sketch but during the day we didn't notice any of that during our walk.
Great Sunday market. The San Telmo neighborhood is famous for its Sunday antiques market. More like a flea market where you could also find souvenirs and handicrafts. Also some street foods.

Great Sunday stroll down Defensa Street. The open market on Defensa street is a real mix of some unique crafts and junk. I enjoy the Sunday market and always come away with some new interesting souvenir. The street tango dancers entertain and there is plenty of food. Great way to spend a Sunday.

Small but with with quite a few things to look around. The heart of San telmo lives in a middle of a plaza with tons of street vendors and restaurants around it.
There are many. The ambience is old but preserved with cobble stone. Small and narrow streets.

A great flea market type expeeience. Did the Sunday market and liked the experience. There were a lot of small souvenirs to buy although we noticed that the silver jewelry was better at the northern end of the market. Also most of the products repeat within about tree blocks so if you are tired you don't have to go all the way up the street

Bring good shoes, US Dollars and a joyful heart. If you don't have fun at this "worlds largest street fair" then you might need to check your meds.Miles of horrible, cheap, tourist trinket booths, interspersed with fantastic artists, musicians, food and fun!Where else can you buy a cowboy hat made out of capybara skin? Then have an ice cream, a slab of BBQ'd beef and listen to a Jewish jazz quartet performing at the African Cultural Center!

A must. The miles long arts exhibit, with a drink then and there, listening to tango, rock, twist, salsa in every other corner, while eating a choripan or stopping for a bife or empanada is a must during your visit to BA. It's only on Sundays, wear your tennis and get ready for an unforgettable time. Oh! Remember that you may want to walk back. Double the fun.
Old Part of City. Very Cool Section. Went during the Sunday market. Great shopping for fun things. Older people should watch our as you walk on cobblestones often.

Visited the market. This market is incredible! It goes for many city blocks on several streets. Felt like it covered the city. Tons to buy, eat, drink and watch tango shows.
Antique stores all around as well.
We would do it again 😊👍🏼
San Telmo. Best time is on this Sunday for the markets and then for the shops which sell antiques and collectibles from Wednesday through to Sunday

Great on Sunday for markets. Recommended to us on a Sunday for the markets. The streets come alive with local stalls! Great musicians along the entire Main Street, and local food. Fantastic Argentinian BBQ place on a corner halfway down, full of people devouring a great lunch! Recommend to all travellers on a Sunday!

Older part of town with antique and second-hand stores. Cobblestone streets lined with second hand stores and antique shops make for a fun area to explore and browse. Plaza Dorrego at the center of it is a little more touristy than the rest, but still worth a visit.

Visit on a Sunday. Any Sunday a trip to Defensa (mainly 11-4pm) will wow the senses. The roads are closed and from one end to the other (about a 1 mile strip) the streets are full of market stalls and people. Areas such as car parks during week days are turned into mobile industrial scale barbeques, and every inch is full of arts and crafts for sale. It’s also a beautiful old cobbled street so full of atmosphere. Wherever there are loads of people, there are the usual pickpockets, so keep your valuables close and in front of you. Enjoy the day, it’s an excellent experience.

Cool spot for Sundays . The cool thing about this place is that it's so near so many things, so you can easily spend a whole day around the area and be perfectly content. However, it should be noted that this place is 10x better on Sundays when the roads are closed off and the streets become alive. Worth taking a visit!

Weekend Delight. Stroll Defensa on A Saturday afternoon and take in the sights, smells and sounds that summarize into a charming experience. Food, artisans, merchants and smiling people. Does not get any better. AND, there are some terrific parillas for a bite to eat.

Love this part of BA. San Telmo is a great interesting district in the hear of the city, full of energy. It is full of history and culture with some great steakhouses and cafes. Excellent place to sit back, have a drink and watch some tango in the main square. The market on a Sunday is a must see when in the city, it is a district that won't disappoint!

Perfect way to spend a day!. Wear very comfortable walking shoes because you'll be at the market and on your feet for several hours! Crafts, art, antiques, tango demonstrations and music. Great prices for souvenirs to take home. A must-do when you're in Buenos Aires!

May be in the summer . I honestly wouldn't recommend the feria but the shops in the neighborhood are worth to visit. In the feria prices are good but there aren't really valuable antiques, this feria goes about 10 blocks and only one part of it is antique the rest is like whatever, people sell many things. Not my taste really. There are few musicians they are all talented, many food seller most of them are good and restaurants ofcourse is open. I been there in the winter, I bet it must be fun in the summer.

Absolutely loved it here . So much art, history, antiques , Sunday shopping that goes on forever Outside of Defensa there are fabulous restaurants and fantastic museums. Really loved this ancient barrio

The Sunday street fair. This is a must-do while in BA - the Sunday street fair in San Telmo. This is BA at it's best - fun, exciting, vibrant, colorful. Lots of stores to wander in and out of as you walk down the street checking out the surprisingly nice wares. Prepare to spend most of the day....so much more fun than a trip to Recoleta Cemetary

Amazing. San Telmo is an amazing place. It has plenty of small stores pitched like a tent selling many different crafts and food. Highly recommend this place to whoever who is visiting Buenos Aires for the first time. Note that it's only open on Sunday.

Is this the biggest street market in the world?. It is worth coming to San Telmo just to see the largest collection of antique stores I've ever seen.You would think you are in Europe with antique Murano glass ,more Ivory than I've ever seen before,alabaster,you name they have it.Best coffee in B.A at coffee world in the San Telmo market and the owner is a gentleman.I hate markets that don't price their products and this market is one of them.I have been to street markets everywhere but I haven't seen one this big .It stretched 3 kilometres along Defensa street.Just amazing

SAN TELMO plus TANGO. At the end 2015 i decided to spend a few weeks in Buenos Aries. I did a great deal of research and settled on SAN TELMO. I figured that an old Italian sector would certainly have great fruit and veg markets...... I was correct. What was unexpected was that my favourite Tango Venues were also to be discovered in this old and fascinating place.........Wonderful 10 piece orchestras and remarkable floor shows were easy to find and attend, not to mentioned the Tango generous and non judgemental well mannered local men. I extended my trip to three months and I'm planning another at the end of this year. The architecture was enchanting and not ever did I feel unsafe stepping out at night to Tango.On the weekends there is such a lovely friendly market at either side of Dorego Plaza and so many exquisite antique shops and at the end of all of it TANGO under the stars....I can't wait to be there again

Rustic and charming. Lovely area with cobbled stone narrow lanes and boutique shops. If you are antique collector then you would love the shops around San Telmo Square. Some local cuisine to taste at small food outlets. Overall I enjoyed staying in this area. I stayed at Anselmo Curio collection by Hilton which is a small boutique hotel worth trying.

Great for Antiques, Artisan products, music and Flea Market. The Saturday flea market is very entertaining and interesting. There is lively music, some beautiful quality artisan products, lots of antiques and collectable items, street food and crowds of people. Our best purchase was a homemade cardboard and Styrofoam toy with a string that you pull to make the sound of a chicken.

All about the people . Exciting time walking through on this Sunday afternoon with the market going. Very busy and whole lot of interesting merchandise to check out. Also, fun watching the different entertaining groups or individuals . That was best part.

Nice area to walk about. We spent a nice afternoon walking about the San Telmo area of BA. It is a nice and relaxed area with lots of eating places and markets and small shops. All interesting. lots of book shops! We liked the markets and all the little cafes and restaurants. We were there on Saturday and it was not too busy compared to the nearby Mayo Plaza area.

A quite nice and relaxed walk across San Telmo. San Telmo is one of those places where you want to spend time with friends and making new ones. There are bars and restaurants all over the place that invite to celebrate with good food and some argentinian wine during hours. Go outside and meet with locals on Saturdays to learn a lot about mate and handcrafted stuff. San Telmo market has a lot of stores where you can get old and really amazing stuff and olease don't forget to take a picture with Mafalda.

BOHEMIAN AREA WITH GALLERIES AND LOTS OF STREET TANGO. We saw this area briefly as part of a city tour off of our cruise ship. The area is billed as the bohemian area of the city and we saw lots of impromptu tango going on.
Perfect for sunday. nie place to visit on sunday. many nice shops and restaurants to go.antique places to buy old stuff...
Interesting area of Buenos Aires. San Telmo marches to it's own beat and should not be missed during a visit to Buenos Aires. Colorful, historical, fun. Go see it!
wonderful. this feels so authentic and fabulous. There are super touristy parts, but it is all mixed in with local bars and restaurants.

Sam Telmo rocks. Dan Telmo.on Sundays with handicraft markets food stalls music and visitors rocks. Best salami and pecorino cheese from mountains of Argentina at an unbelievable price from a lively gentlemen and lots yo see and do

Not worth the time unless you want to buy some leather goods.. I found San Telmo to be a very disappointing experience. It is really just a couple streets lined with a few brightly painted buildings and shops for tourists and a small eateries. The moment you enter the area you are approached by people in tango outfits asking if you want to learn tango or have your pictures taken with them. The ladies are saying, "Don't be shy, come here." I found it to be very uncomfortable. Some of the shops do have some nice leather goods at reasonable prices if you are in the market for these. The restaurants did not look very inviting.

Charming. San Telmo is exquisitely charming. Many cool shops and cafes line the brick laid streets. The Sunday market is famous as it deserves to be. You can find just about anything here (I bought a handmade chef's knife here for 500 pesos). I would not recommend staying here in a hotel unless you are fluent in Spanish as night time could be dicey.

Whole area walking. Loved this area in BA so much so we wished our hotel had been there. Market area to eat and watch the tango dancers was fun. Beer life is a good evening venue and most restaurants during day are reasonable with a bottle of costing little more than 10 aus dollars if that

Fun Touristy Place full of Tango History. Tango began here in the early 1900s and is still danced here today. It is so colorful and great for photos. There are also a lot of tourist junk shops to buy souvenirs. Still it is a fun lively place. Be sure to go on Sundays when there is a street fair to enjoy.

Bohemian!!!!. Really pretty area to walk around, a lot of restaurants, street art, music and off course Mafalda and friends monument.
Safe and good to spend the whole day. Must go place!

Good for tourism. This is an old neighborhood and now is the paradise of antique seekers.- The center of the activity is in Plaza Dorrego, Defensa street corner Humberto 1°.- In the two blocks of Defensa Street, between San Juan ave. and Carlos Calvo is the major concentration of antiques stores.- As in all places where are plenty of tourism be careful with crooks.-

Only on Sunday. Plaza Dorrego in the heart of San Telmo is a must on a sunny Sunday in Buenos Aires. Tango is in the air with professional demonstrations of the different dances to prepare for one of the many Milongas in the late evening downtown. The streets ar full of llittle stalls with handy craft and sometimes dubious antiquities. Take care and discuss prizes. Bars and restaurants know about the tourists preferencies, offer tasty meals and Tapas all day long for reasonable but up market prizes.

Come on Sunday during the Market. San Telmo might just be my favorite place in Buenos Aires. There is a lot of charm in the cobblestone streets. The restaurants are great and they have the most amazing market on Sundays.
Sunday marktet is a MUST!. The Sunday market at San Telmo is great. There are so many things to buy. A lot of handicraft and made made jewellery. Street performers and bands playing.

Tango in the Plaza. San Telmo was a perfect way to spend an afternoon browsing for antiques, hand crafted items and a market place filled with booths of foods and anything your little heart desires. Interesting colonial architecture, quaint paved streets and of course... Tango dancing. Definitely a bit of nostalgia and a good glimpse of How it Used to Be... I enjoyed my time there and the weather was perfect for strolling.

Go on a Sunday and attend the street fair. Sunday has stalls for blocks and blocks selling good leather belts at good prices, matte cups, other clothing, trinkets, etc. it's a scene that's worth being part of. Expect crowds, but it lasts all day, so you can take your time. We stopped for a light lunch in the San Telmo Market at a little coffee shop toward the back. The empanadas, fruit drinks, and salad were delicious!

My home. I have an apartment in san Telmo where I have lived since 2010. I love my home. The barrio is a magnet for tourists largely because it touts itself as the birthplace of tango. This is only partially true, but it's good for business. Tourists come for the Saturday and Sunday markets in and around plaza Dorrego. In good weather or bad, it's mobbed. There's plenty of junk to browse at the stalls and you can find bargains. You have to haggle, and the dealers will never go as low as they can if you are obviously a tourist. I was born in Buenos Aires so I help out friends who come. Even so, I can't get the best prices if I am with visitors -- only when I am alone and can chat up the vendor. Sundays there's also a fair bit of music and some classic tango. I don't go too often because I don't like the hordes of tourists. The cafes around the plaza are all good, but not cheap. If you're not a local I wouldn't venture too far from the plaza on Sundays. It's a safer neighborhood than some, but you need to know what you are doing if you wander off the beaten path. Better to go on a weekday if you want to wander around. The shops are all open on weekdays but the market is not there, so there's people going about their daily business all around.. San Telmo is also legendary for its murals which are everywhere and constantly changing. The covered market is brilliant. You can get anything you want there from fresh meat and veg to antique clothing. There's also a ton of cheap eateries serving local specialties. You'll get home cooked dishes here which you won't recognize if you don't know about Argentine cooking. Wherever you are in san Telmo keep a tight grip on your bag or wallet. There are thieves everywhere.
Graduated Children . As always, San Telmo is a must. Greatest flee market in Argentina, and probably in South America. Antiques, souvenirs, etc. Great lunch a at Amice Mie
Fair. We went on a drizzly day so the crowds were not too big and the vendors were plentiful. Beautiful hand-crafted items that made great souvenirs and gifts to bring home

Busy San Telmo makes a great half day. San Telmo is known for its antiques. There are galleries and small markets all over the place. Just keep your wallets safe as it can be crowded. Some days there are tango shows in the street and all in all it is a nice place to come to as there are so many locals here too.
San Telmo. Unique. Loved the market here on Sundays. Trash and treasure. Fabulous restsurants and bars. Lots of atmosphere. Safe and fun.

The place to be if you are looking for a good time. This is a great place with many options for dinner and have a good time. Many good restaurants with great atmosphere and beautiful people. I loved it.

must visit on a Sunday. Love the antique market on a Sunday. Some bizarre things and a few hidden gems. Also lots of music. We found a fantastic jazz band there. At any day of the week you can sit in Plazo Dorrego and have a very reasonably priced meal or drink and watch tango. Fascinating!I love the old fashioned look of San Telmo and could easily return and spend a few days just exploring the streets and shops
Very Interesting. We visited San Telmo on a Sunday and we discovered one of the most interesting Antique market we ever visited. Many interesting items, diverse and at very reasonable prices.

Sunday wonders. Antique fair in the square has amazing treasures. You'll want to pack some to take home. Crafts on side streets are excellent. I purchased a wood painted carving of an Argentinian man. I call him Paco.

The historic heart of Buenos Aires. I enjoyed a lot the relaxed atmosphere and the old buildings of the place. An excellent way to see a tango show for free!!Mi è piaciuta molto l'atmosfera rilassata e i vecchi palazzi della piazza. È un ottimo modo per vedere uno spettacolo di tango gratis!

Sunday market is a must!. We were there today and it was amazing, even if the weather was a little dreary.You can buy some some original artwork, leather goods, typical souvenirs, hand made jewelry- the list goes on and on!Don't forget to take a peek inside the stores lining the streets as well as the indoor market.You can also see live music and a Tango show for a good price.The architecture in San Telmo is stunning so don't forget to look up once in a while.This is definitely a part of Buenos Aires that can't be missed!

Perfect Sunday! San Telmo Market.. Music. Tango. Coffee. Empanadas. $2 handmade bracelet. Antiques. Cash or Pesos. Spent the day walking the market. Ducked in a quaint restaurant to rest up and let the rain pass. Finished in the San Telmo square for tango show and local beer. Really lovely day. Buy a belt...high quality leather. Vendors will actually fit you and assemble the belt while you wait and watch....

Don't Miss the Sunday Market. There's truly something for everyone at the Sunday market in San Telmo....rightfully so, since the market spans 50 blocks. You can find everything from kitschy souvenirs to sombreros, homemade empanadas to alpargatas... and so much more. Pair this with food stalls, street corner cafes, beer stands and lots of live music interspersed, and you have a pretty fun and lively Sunday afternoon!
Go sit and people watch . Grab a bottle of wine and watch the tango dancers. The little stands will negotiate and price but not too much. Quantity counts!

Nice place. If you go to Buenos Aires you should stop in San Telmo. There is a market there and you can buy so nice things like keyrings,shirts,socks,bags...You can find Mafalda and her friends there too.You must take a picture with her.Have fun!

Something to see on every corner. This is the oldest part of Buenos Aires and the buildings are reminiscent of a golden era in times gone by. Some are restored to the original magnificence and some are in much need of attention. But that just adds to the charm. Defensa Street is full of charming cafes and antique stores but the place really comes alive on Sundays when people from all over town flock to the huge antique and craft market - more craft than antiques! Lots of great buskers too from ska bands to tango (Gardel) singers. And fabulous street art! Not as much tango dancing as I was led to believe though. A great place to stay for a week or so or just for a day trip

I was Surprised!!. My tour guide dropped me off for my own time to explore... he gave me 25 minutes and I thought that was plenty...... I was so wrong... I could have spent hours in this locale.... plenty of bars and food and great shops, especially for souvenirs...it's a part of town that is completely different from Recoleta or Puerto Madero but I love it anyway!!!!!! Several people tried to hustle me but I played ignorant and just kept walking!!!!! Tons of things to do there and the football stadium is right there too.... amazing!!!!

A fun market, but watch your purse. We loved the color, sounds and delicious aromas of the San Telmo weekend market, a good place for leather purchases. We strolled as we enjoyed the street food empanadas, especially after the vendor assured us they were not gato. But we later learned that a friend at a San Telmo cafe had her purse stolen right out from under the table -- we figure they probably used a long-handled hook. This is a colorful and fun city, but crime is on the rise , so beware.

Touristic area. if you like authentic places you must visit here. All the house are old style and every sunday A big public market is being held on the streets of the San Telmo and you can really find something interesting that you have been looking for.
You can find everything there!. lot's of interesting and beatiful thing to buy, specially if you are looking for something to bring back to your friends.

A Great Sunday Activity. The market in San Telmo which takes place every Sunday is a wonderful place to visit. All down Calle Defensa there are interesting stalls with clothes, leather goods, jewellery, art and lots more and then there is Plaza Dorrego itself with all its antiques, second hand goods, jewellery and old books, in fact evrything you can think of. Also, there will be live music with the chance to buy musicians' CDs, tango dancing and all the people to look at. There are also permanent shops to visit, some in arcades as well as cafes and restaurants. Sunday in San Temo is a must for every visitor to Buenos Aires.

Great place to spend time. Make sure you do not miss the market, you can still find great things at a good price. Lunch in the littleplaza is a must, they always have a couple dancing tango, we liked it so much we went for a privare lesson after that

Flea market extravaganza. On Sunday in San telmo there is a great flea market that covers about three blocks on each side of the Main Street. There is everything from antiques to handmade sandals and espadrilles. We bought a very unique hanging wire sculpture. Just walking around is an experience. There is music and food and lots of people Great.fun on a Sunday afternoon
Great fun on a sunday. We went for the Sunday market. Loads to see- a feast for the eyes! Lots of stalls and street performers. Bars and restaurants were buzzing.

Buzzing. This is my favourite area in Bs As as it is so alive. The market on Sunday is amazing and even if you don't need to buy anything, there are many places to sit and watch the world go by. I would recommend taking a seat round the edge of the square for a drink whilst the market packs up, then moving to the restaurant seating as it sets up in the square itself next to the tango dancing area. Anyone is welcome to join in the dancing and it attracts quite a crowd.Even when it isn't a market day there are indoor markets selling a wide range of bric a brac and souvenirs. The area feels safe too!

Wow, just keeps going and going!. This is a great place to find a souvenir. There are literally hundreds of booths. There are really about 15 varieties of souvenirs that you see over and over, but every once in a while you come across a real gem. We found some lovely items from local artists.
Beautiful. On sundays vendors come out to the street and is a beautiful place to hang out. They are really good vintage restaurants that you should go!

The Sunday market is a must. We stayed in this beautiful area of the city. We were lucky enough To arrive during the Sunday market so it was very lively. People selling all sorts of gifts And antiques. We saw Tango dancing, well into the night!! You have To experience this great atmosphere. If you miss the market, the area is a great place To stay. Lots of the best steak houses are here, plus mouth watering patisseries!! We walked To a lot of places from here.We didn't really understand how the busses worked, we waited ages for a bus To Bocca And about 10 Just drove straight passed us, even when we checked the bus stop-? Maybe the bus drivers didn't like the look of us!!

Great Neighborhood but take care!. This is a one of the oldest areas in Buenos Aires and it has a lot of history, cute shops, and resturants. It´s a must vist if you are in town. My only warning is to beware if you decided to stop for a drink in the main square (Plaza Dorrego). The resturants there will try to rip you off and the service sucks. I would especially avoid the resturant on the left side if you are coming from Defensia - they are the worst.

Colorfull and interesting. I am not a flea market type, but this one... wow! This is something else. On Sundays San Telmo turns to vibrant and bouncy place. Thing sold on this flea market aren't trash, there is a lot of really nice and preserved antique objects. Telephones, shoes, knives, binoculars, typewriters, jewelry....Al around place you can buy empanadas and other street food, there are lots of bars and cozy restaurants. Take your time and enjoy it. Tango show I saw here was much better than the one we paid for.

loved the Sunday street fair. We spent an afternoon at the street fair and loved the local flair. We were finally able to mingle with the locals which we found to be warm and welcoming. We visited the San Telmo Market and were awe struck with it's turn of the century beauty. We purchased old leather bags at the market at ridiculous low prices. We bought silver from the local vendors that were also dirt cheap. The artsy vendors, local craftsmen and warm people made this a memorable visit. Also, loved the craft beer from the local pub. Highly recommend a Sunday visit, (only day the fair is open.)

Sundays for antiques and tango dancing at Plaza Dorrego. I always end up buying something at Plaza Dorrego amongst the plethora of antique stuff. Go on Sunday by 3 because they pack up the antiques by 5. Then, I always walk down Defensa to browse in the cool shops and check out all the "artesanias" on the cobblestoned street all the way to Plaza de Mayo. Carry your cash and camera in your pockets to be on the safe side, and be careful with your iphones! I would go every Sunday if I could! Love it!
Worth visiting . Busy market, great atmosphere. Recommend walking further down from the plaza de Mayo to get away from the tourist stalls and towards the antique market.
Great Sights. San Telmo is full of great sights, shops and places to eat. Sunday is the best for the San Telmo Market. Open Air music and dancing and plenty of hand crafts to buy. Well worth a visit.

Interesting flea market. On Sundays (perhaps Saturdays too but I am not sure) there is a very large flea market centred around Plaza Dorrego. For the most part, items being sold here are not junk. They are just very old items, some very unusual by North American standards. It is a nice area to stroll around in as there are many cafes and restaurants nearby and also some street music. It's probably a good area for pickpockets as it can be crowded so be careful with valuables. You could easily spend several hours and not see all of it.

Vibrant and lively part of the scity. There is one street in San Telmo which forms part of a comic tour – it has sculptures of various Argentinean cartoon characters. This is characteristic of the area which is lively and has a vibrant art and culture scene.
Go for a wander. Its up and coming. You take the nitty gritty with the improvements are have / are being made. There are bars, restaurants, hostels, and market as well to be seen.

Tango everywhere. On a Sunday in San Telmo you can see tango any where you look in the square. We had lunch right on the square and the tiny place with a miniscule platform for the performers redeemed the mediocre food with a free tango show. The stalls provide ideas for souvenirs and entertainers of all sorts crowd the streets. we never did see a nightclub show after that because we had seen such variation in the street tangos we felt no need for more.

Mafaldalace . Old neighborhood very classic and very Argentinian have good empanadas and few drinks close to our hotel ,lot of homeless people at the streets and varies a lot from one block to the other. Few good restaurants with empanadas and mate

San Telmo market is a great scene, but low quality stuff . Sunday- including Easter Sunday- Defensa, off of the Plaza de Mayo, a narrow cobblestone street lined on both sides with stalls selling decent leather belts with nice metal buckles ( bought 2 for under $30), but also the cute and colorful metal painted signs, drawings, socks, matte cups, and plastic junk, etc. The streets are packed from morning until almost 9 at night! We stopped at the San Telmo market (The Coffeehouse) for a lunch of a a variety of very good empanadas. Then we went on the Free Walks tour of the historic center, which I highly recommend. It starts at the Congress and ends at the Plaza de Mayo and the Casa Rosada, the Presidenial offices.In the evening, we went back into San Telmo and stopped for a "picada," an assortment of cheese, olives, salami, ham, turkey, bread, and then later tried a "submarino," which the Free Walks guide had suggested. This is a variety of hot chocolate: hot milk in which you dip a small chocolate bar, which melts into the milk. You can add extra sugar if you like this extra sweet. In some places, they also serve it with a churro ( think a 6 inch skinny long donut that's covered with sugar), which wasn't served where we stopped. Then we went to the milonga at the square, which begins around 8 every Sunday night. The milonga is a spot where the tango is danced by every day people. It was great, with many older couples truly fantastic. We left around 10, dancing out of San Telmo with a drum line group.

San Telmo Fair on a Sunday. We took the subway from Florida Street to get to San Telmo. On Sundays, there is a very big fair there and vendors sell antiques as well as other wares like mate pots, knick-knacks, music CDs, etc. Just wandering around the aisles is an adventure and a lot of fun. You can negotiate prices for anything you want to buy. Allow at least a couple of hours.
A must-see on your visit. You can't miss this old neighborhood full of antique shops, cobblestone streets and plenty of casual cafes and restaurants.
Great!. This is a not to miss place in Buenos Aires. Loved it! My friend Esteban recommended a guided tour of the best places of San Telmo.
Great place to be. WE had a very nice day on the weekendmarket at San Telmo. We bought some souvenirs for home in a nice atmosphere.

Very cool area of city. This is a historical area that is very bohemian in nature. In the Plaza Dorego, they tango dance. Follow the shade around in the plaza to decide where you want your coffee or wine for people watching. Explore the entire area. It's as safe as to be expected in any city. Don't look stupid or do stupid and you will be fine. This is my favorite part of Buenos Aires.
