After work, outside of the bodegas, people gather to drink their version of 40 ounces, funny, I just thought "wow, it's really just the same no matter where you are, just a different language". Happy travels!
Great place to get surveniers back home. All kind of surveniers you need can be found here. Also rich with arts and leather products. However its getting crowded after lunchtime.

Must Visit on Sunday. It's a very vivid place to go walk around, shop, eat, listen to music, dance or see people dancing, etc. They have street market along a street called "Defensa". I really enjoyed it.

Colorful and fun way to spend a Sunday afternoon.. The Sunday flea market in San Telmo is colorful, crowded, gritty, and wonderful~a full sensory experience. The people watching, music, street food, and energy all blend to make for a fun few hours. There are few treasures among the sometimes repetitive trinkets, but the shopping seems secondary to the experience. Wear sturdy shoes, as the cobblestones are uneven, and time is better spent looking in every direction except down.
Wonderful place to visit.. Classic Buenos Aires neighborhood, great restaurants, bookstores, etc. Go on Sunday, there's a huge antiques street market.
Classic. The area is a bit run down but has great shops and restaurants. On Sundays there is a flea market,,great to wander around. Be cautious after dark.

Great place to get the feel of BA. Once I realized we would be in BA on a Sunday, I turned the whole trip into a San Telmo-centric visit—and boy am I glad! The San Telmo market and La Defensa handicrafts market are well worth your Sunday. The primary ST/Dorrego square area primarily has many, many antique dealers, but we also found some artisans and tango musicians and dancers in the mix. So much to look at and all about the cultural history of Argentina (clothes, phones, plates and cutlery, magazines, everything). For us, this was a nice atmosphere and certainly a great central point for where we chose our hotel, etc., but we really went nuts for the 3-kilometer-long handicrafts market that occupies La Defensa (street) adjacent to the square. Not only are there crafts on both sides of the pedestrian-only zone, but there are people selling homemade empanadas, churros, and sandwiches everywhere. The area smells like grilled meat since all the restaurants on the street are open, and women are literally walking by calling “empanada” with their small basket of homemade pastries. There is music and stuff to look at for miles. We worked very hard to walk the majority of the area before buying anything. What we discerned by walking the length was that some people were selling items that appeared mass produced but many were selling truly unique, handmade items that were well worth the money. We were able to get wallets that were just made by the seller, art pieces signed by the artist on the spot, hand printed goods, and all sorts of souvenirs that are great reminders of our trip to Argentina.

San Telmo is a Sunday Must!. San Telmo is the area where the antique market is held every Sunday. The area has restaurants and music and a great selection of antique items. There were lots of people, lots of vendor and lots of great items. This is definitely one

Antiques and Tango. Interesting place to wander...antique and boutique shops...among Tango Dancers dancing in the square. Great place to simply sit in the square, sipping Sangria, watch Tango dancers and enjoy the afternoon.

Lovely neighbourhood. I stayed 2 month very close to San Telmo. I often went to this barrio. Its not as touristic as Palermo and the prices are lower. But you can find amazing restaurants and very nice bars. On Sunday it worth to visit the market. Here you can find a really good Choripan (my best in Argentina).

Not exactly quaint, cobbled streets. From the way this barrio is portrayed as the oldest area of Buenos Aires with quaint, cobbled streets and a romantic air, I was expecting an architectural delight and delve in to history. In truth it felt dirty and dishevelled and although the Sunday market atmosphere was an experience, I was left feeling decidedly underwhelmed.

There is a Sunday, very touristy, market, but the neighborhood itself is worthwhile.. My wife and I stayed in an excellent and reasonably priced hotel in the district and got the chance to walk around it for a few days. There are nice restaurants and other attractions in the neighborhood. In San Telmo you see a wide range of the people of Buenos Aires. We review a few of the neighborhood places separately, but our overall experience of the neighborhood was very positive.

Lots of Tourists. Had a quick stop here and there were bus loads after bus loads of tourists being let off. Much of the shops carried the same items and the shop employees were helpful and not pushing to make a sale. There were a couple of women in Tango outfits posing for pictures, which I found to be cheesy.

A must see when you are in Bueos Aires. San Telmo is one of the most famous neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. The old fashion Bohemian place that you can get lost thought the street markets, the tango bars and the antiques shops. During the weekends you have a full on day out just in this place. Do not miss it!!!!!! you might end up dancing tango in the corner of the street with some strangers!!!!! :)

Good flea market for first time visitors. If you are here for a Sunday go to San Telmo it is an experience everyone needs to be part of in the heart of the old part of BA. Very long but very interesting
Experience historic Buenos Aires. A must see part of Buenos Aires, just beside the Micro Center, wander down streets like Defense, Chile and Bolivia for an atmospheric taste of historic BA

Very interesting. The market "la feria" is very very nice you can find a lot of treasures there. Also just for 20$ you can make antic style family foto, if you are looking for vintage clothes it is also the right place.
Amazing part of old BA . Very cool area of old BA. Lots of markets, live tango shows, galleries, etc, etc. Should not be missed.

Spend a Sunday Afternoon Here. San Telmo was primarily on my must-see list for the Sunday Market. I enjoyed walking the streets perusing the handcrafted goods along lines of street stalls and people-watching. Bought a few great gifts and keepsakes. Found a great boutique jeweler that sells handcrafted gems with a wonderful Vinoteca across the street possessing an excellent selection of Argentine wines in a charming building. (Both are near the Antiguo Mercado.) I could have done without the huge "antique" market that felt more like one huge yard sale / swap meet but it's worth wending your way through the stalls to find the stage just to watch the Milonga dancers. If you're a legit antique lover, there are storefronts with antique dealers on Calle Defensa. I didn't explore any as I'm not a fan but per hearsay and the window displays, these stores are for the luxury shopper. We stopped at Mercadito Latino for a very good lunch where they served a variety of South American cuisine. We also explored the Pasaje de la Defensa which was a very attractive/atmospheric complex full of little boutiques. Don't forget to look-up as you stroll to admire the gorgeous historic buildings with it's character-filled details like sculptured dragons, wreaths, faces, and a few stained-glass windows. The neighborhood is on the "gritty" side, so keep an eye on your belongings and enjoy some of the few dilapidated areas as part of the neighborhoods charm. As a tourist, I wouldn't wander here at night without a knowledgeable local or two.

Sunday Market. I was in San Telmo market on Sunday. If you want to see old more traditional side of Buenos Aires, i strongly recommend to vistit San Telmo even better on Sunday as market on Defensa street. This is best place to buy souvenirs in good price. Live music and street tango dancers are certainly bonus for your day.

Huge outdoor market of trinkets and tourist stuff. This market is only for arts and crafts - no produce or farmers food available except for a very few stalls inside the original market building. This market is in a crucifix layout but the goods displayed are pretty much all the same. There are an abundant of those "Cups and Suction Sticks" so prevalent in the Buenos Aires localities. They are for their national herbal drink "Yerbe Mate" - taste is an acquired one so be prepared. The cups are very creative and beautiful - just getting one for the coffee table back home would be a good conversational piece. I did go for an orange juice freshly squeezed - wonderfully refreshing and sweet.

Gritty Neighborhood with Tons of Character. This neighborhood is gritty, and a little bit dirty, but filled with interesting little restaurants, shops, charming hotels, and on Sundays a massive craft fair. The neighborhood is inexpensive--last night three of us ate at a charming little restaurant for US $12 a person. What the neighborhood lacks in polish it makes up for in a "can do" attitude as it is filled with tiny galleries, restaurants, bars, bakeries, and nightclubs all bustling with people.

Antiques. Nice neigbourhood, a little ruff on the edges, great sunday market with a lot of stuff you don´t need but want. Has some great bars, cafés and restaurants aswell, try the "Pulpería", lovely place in a 100 year old building, where much didn´t change.

Gritty and interesting. We have lived the last two weeks in San Telmo. We felt safe the whole time. We enjoyed local restaurants, food shopping a just walking the streets. I would not hesitate to recommend this area of BA to people looking to visit,

7 nights in San Telmo. I must first strongly disagree with previous reviews that characterize San Telmo as unsafe. It is not. We stayed for a full week in a lovely apartment on Peru, so I know of which I speak. The barrio was the first established in Buenos Aires and after spending just a little time there, you will see that it was once a center of wealth in BA's earliest days until it was quickly abandoned with the onset of a yellow fever outbreak. I will agree that San Telmo can seem a little sketchy, at first, but spend a little time walking the streets, having lunch, dinner, or a drink or coffee in the many cafes, and the faded charm of San Telmo will quickly come shining through. In fact, I highly recommend walking the neighborhood at night when it really shines. We did several times, after midnight, and never felt uncomfortable. Note that most tourist maps do not orientate to North. The interesting parts of San Telmo are the Streets Peru, Bolivar, Defensa, and Balcarse, which run North/South, and their cross streets between Defensa and Ave. San Juan (east/west). I don't recommend going west of Peru as there's really nothing there and that area is pretty run-down. And yes, the Market is a must if you are fortunate enough to be in town on a Sunday. All of Defensa is closed to cars for the market, but the best of it runs between Independencia and Plaza Dorrego. North of Independencia is good, too, just more congested. There is also the San Telmo market, open daily, which is an enclosed, full square block building with vendors of all types, inside, including some of the best coffee we had in BA at Coffee Town. While in BA, you MUST see a tango show and the one I recommend is in San Telmo called Taconeando (see T.A. reviews). It's an intimate venue with an excellent show that's not crazy-expensive like some of the tourist oriented tango shows. In fact, on the night we went, more than half the audience were locals and we were the only Americans there. Loved it! If we return to BA, San Telmo will again be our base.

Fab market!. Great market here on a Sunday selling everything from antiques to jewellery and clothes and food. lots of great restaurants too. Make sure you take enough cash with you as most places don't take card.

Go on Sunday!. The San Telmo District of Buenos Aires is fascinating enough in its own right, but go on Sunday when the market stalls are up and the streets are closed to traffic. So many antique stores and lots of vendors on the streets selling all kinds of things. A fun way to spend part of Sunday!

Sketchy and not a lively neighborhood. I hear Sunday is the only reason to come to San Telmo and for Antiques. The bar scene at night is non existent and it's very unsafe walking around. We originally had all 5 days booked at our Airbnb and lasted one day and headed to a better safer more fun neighborhood Palermo. Only come here during the day for Antiques or Sunday for the market.

Tourist Town. We went to San Telmo during the week and about half the shops were closed. Some restaurants open. Then we went back for the Sunday fair, and it was packed, hard to move. The restaurant we chose was full, and the service was incredibly slow, over two hours to eat lunch. We enjoyed it in the past and would probably go again, but wach your handbag.

If you miss San Telmo, you haven't seen Buenos Aires.. The Sunday market is overwhelming with its colours, textures and people strolling along the cobblestones. In the evening, Plaza Dorrego has restaurants with little tables outside in a circle around the tango dancers. My favourite part to visit, don't miss it.

If you are looking for tourist souvenirs. Went on Sunday. Great if you want to buy that souvenir t-shirt, fridge magnet, & tea-pot. Or some local art pieces. Otherwise, too many of the same stalls street after street. Some live performances here and there. Preferred to hide in a cafe on the side under the shade for grilled meats and a cold beer. Or grab an empanada an fresh orange juice off the street vendors.

Old town southern Buenos Aires where it all started. If you like atmospheric streets full of cobble stones and crumbling facades this is the place for you! Reminded me a bit of Havana. On a Sunday there is a market which goes on from mid morning to late evening full of bric a brac, jewellery and souvenirs. But what you really want to explore are the antique shops, cafes and bars overflowing with locals and musicians. There's even dancing in the street! The main square is fabulous and you can sit under the huge trees sipping coffee or something a little stronger and savour the whole atmosphere

Street markets. What a treat !! They have these markets every Sunday. So easy to walk the whole distance, which stretches for at least 12 city blocks, but occasionally branches off into side streets too. You can spend the entire day here. The street Tango dancing and all the little bands and musicians along the way are incredible. What a talented community this is. If it weren't for these markets I'm not sure I would have enjoyed my stay in Buenos Aires as much as I did.
Interesting quarter.. A small square surrounded by shops and Tango bars. Great if you want 'antiques' or trinkets, or just a lazy walk around the many streets.

soul of historic Buenos Aires. The place is really great although some areas would request some renovation. Plenty of antic shops, palladas (grill restaurants), bars, very nice old historic market hall (Mercado), from 1897 year, history looking from every corner. Colorful "Sunday market" occupies the main square and nearby streets - not to be missed if you are right at that time in BA.

Go on Sunday!!. We enjoyed the market day in San Telmo. Fun people watching, enjoyed the street performers, the market. But bring pesos. Most establishments did not take credit cards and the ATMs were empty!
me gusta samta telmo. One of my favorite places in buenos aires, liked the rythm of the city and the neighborhood of san telmo. Very good. Dangerous at night.

Absolutely wonderful atmosphere. We went to San Telmo in the morning and had breakfast in one of the many nice cafes and restaurants and asked the waitress if she could recommend a Tango place for us for the night. There is a lovely market some days and live musicians played excellent guitar music. In the evening we came back to see our first ever Milonga and it was magnificent experience that is a "must" when in Buenos Aires. At first I was disappointed it wasn't a show, but then I thought it was absolutely wonderful to see people of all ages dance so elegantly and with lots of concentration obviously deeply enjoying it.

Love it. We went to BA to spend the New Year's for a week and on sunday we went to San Telmo neighbohood which every Sunday helds a famous street fairy.It was hot as hell but was great....a lot of people showing their works in the sidewalk...bands in the streets....a lot of stores and great restaurants.Its also the place where you can find the Mafalda's statue.Love this place!!!

sundays are a must here. on sundays during the day they have lots of open air booths celling various things. mostly handicrafts but differnet than alot of other south american places. in the eveing brazilian bands and tango dancers comeout. the square is great viewing tango. it is a neighbor hood things. locals dancing this is BA in its finest! lots of good resturants too. at night take a taxi back to your hotel is best and safest.
same street market as in any large city. ok market but stalls become the same after the first block--we purchased a wallet, some hair ties, and found prices much higher than Montevedeo

A must see.... Don't miss the Sunday market. Great place to people watch and you can did a lot of great little gifts to take back home. After a while it all starts looking the same and the crowds can be overwhelming, but stop for a beverage at the many cafes to recharge your battery. We ended up at the local community centre where locals were playing music and people of the streets just started dancing.

Sunday market - must see. Every Sunday there's a famous market that takes place in this neighborhood.....it's absolutely fantastic and a must visit!! mix of unique collectables/antiques, food, Argentinian specialties, live music, food....all along the streets and squares....highly recommend.

Sunday tango in the square. The action starts around noon on Sundays in San Telmo. The square is filled with vendors and in the center people are dancing tango. There are beautiful stores filled with overpriced antiques and some great cafes. But my favorite part is the street musicians and the older couples that you see dancing tango in the square.

Our Buenos Aires favorite!. We think this is the best area of Buenos Aires--very historic, eclectic, street art, interesting bars and restaurants, and very unique! Just walking these streets is very fun but a guide who knows the area helps a lot! Great food and shopping! Not necessarily a place i'd spend the night!

Favourite area in the city!. There is a real buzz around San Telmo, especially on a Sunday at the street market. Pop-up Asados, miles of stall-lined streets, great restaurants, bars, shops and around 30 mins walk from Recoleta for those wanting to save some cash on taxis or transport.Must visit!

San Telmo Shows Off Old Buenos Aires Along with Tango on the Street. San Telmo is a fun place to go to, for the antique shops, the tango on the street, and the park that has a flea market a couple days a week. Some of the restaurants are good, but the area is a little rundown. There's a great museum there of an old city apartment building that was formerly a private home that is well worth the visit. It has underground tunnels and the docents who deliver the lectures are very well informed. We sat in the square after the museum visit, watched locals tango and had a café. It was a fun day.
Street market on sunday arvo. Very nice atmosphere...good live music in the streets...area very trendy...lot of shopping opportunities too!

Great Sunday Street Market . What a great part of Buenos Aires. Sundays has the street markets runs about 8 blocks from the San Telmo Square (flea market) right through to May Square (artisan markets). Plenty of interesting things to look at and buy. Worth a look but you need a few hours!

Great outdoor market on Sundays !!!. If you are in Buenos Aires on a Sunday this mile long out door market is a must. Very colorful, crowded and many various kiosks hawking their wares. Artists , Antiques, etc etc. etc.

Sunday Feria and quiet residential neighborhood the rest of the week. WE arrived in Buenos Aires on a Sunday and shortly started walking towards the San Telmo fair-feria. There are no subways near this well known antique fair held only on Sundays. So we used a map and guide that suggested walking south from the Plaza Mayor and Pink House on Defensa Calle. . Immediately as we exited the plaza Mayor and the pink House we saw stalls on both sides of the streets for all sorts of crafts. No antiques. Our feet quickly noted the cobblestones and wore at our feet as we headed towards the San Telmo neighborhood. During the week this is an upscale convenient neighborhood On Sunday it is chaotic with crowds of locals and international tourists. leathergoods, wooden carving and other argentinine crafts croded beside tourist scarves, t-shorts and water vendors. Some restaurants have their own tango bands and people dance the tango. others have recordings and dance the tango seeking donations. as we approached the center of San Telmos we found the antiques and better quality goods and less tourist goods from China. leather jackets and boots abounded. WE felt the heat and sought water vendors. We grieved the abandoned church on our way. WE finally reached the park and sat to rest before finding our way back to the Pyramid . This is a memorable feria. it is not used goods or flea market it does have some nice restaurants in the middle of the activity.

Nice enough area during the day. We stayed in the San Telmo neighborhood, so we naturally checked out some of the area. It's really good if you like antiques, older architecture, and checking out trinkets and souvenirs. There are also some cafes and tango shows in the Plaza Dorrego, if you're interested in that. During the night, it's supposedly a bit less safe, and basically everyone advised us to take a taxi. So we did.The only difficulty we encountered was walking with a child in a stroller. That was due to the very narrow sidewalks that were made of cobblestone, which made it very slow and difficult to push the stroller. But if you don't have a stroller, it shouldn't be an issue.

Antiques galore . An atmosphere like never before! The food the people the culture! Ver rich and still part of these cobble stone streets! You transport yourself to a place of what people dream! Loved the tango and the live musicians! A well spent Sunday afternoon!

Shopping mecca. If you need sovereigns to bring back home, this is the place to get them. The market is very expansive, and although there are a lot of duplicates of items for sale, there are artist booths tucked in between, the typical tourist wares. Great place to spend an afternoon and although very busy, it seemed quite safe. Make sure you bring enough money as the bank machines either run out of money or are not stocked on the weekend

fun artsy street market, weekends. You can find souvenirs and a variety of clothes, hats, leather, art creations, water colors, etc - indeed, something for everyone. And, if you are not interested in objects, you can watch people!
Great market. Every Sunday San Telmo has a antique and crafts market together with many Tango dancers. This is a must for visitors.

Sunday what better way to pass the time than a stroll through the colorful streets of San Telmo. Sunday what better way to pass the time than a stroll through the colorful streets of San Telmo the place comes alive with vendors locals and tourists buying almost everything you could want.Watch impromptu Tango dancers, eat like the locals relax and just enjoy yourselves
Play the market!. San Telmo is a bustling district, with a large outdoor market. Here you can find interesting antiques, bric-a-brac, arts and crafts. Something for everyone, in fact!

Sunday Market in San Telmo. The best place to be on Sunday in Buenos Aires is the San Telmo Market, stretching down Defensa , with numerous stalls selling food and handcrafts, as well as singers and Tango dancers busking and adding to the flamboyant atmosphere. A visit to the restored townhouse , El Zanjon, at Defensa 755, is also recommended . It is an insight into the history of the area and an oasis of calm and coolness. The permanent market, selling fresh produce and antiques is also a destination on Sundays.
Not to bad. You will see this place in the plazo de mayo, the music is OK and the food looks interesting. The nearby toilets I woundn't use. There are some street vendors outside.
very interesting. such a nice place to go to on a Sunday because of all the antique stalls on the street. you can find so many pretty things!

Street market. Had a nice tour including cathedral, then wandered the street market. Our guide assisted us in buying several items. Could have spent hours there but we needed to continue on to the Recoleta cemetery and La Boca.

Great place for walking. I'm currently staying at a hotel in Plaza Dorrega in San Telmo (Anselmo Buenos Aires) and it's a great place to get out and walk around. The streets are old school brick and the buildings look pretty old school too. I've been told this is a Bohemian part of Buenos Aires. There are plenty of antique shops or arts and craft stores and the Sunday market here is amazing! On Sundays the streets are filled with vendors selling anything from clothes to antiques to food and there is live music everywhere. One thing I've noticed is that some of the restaurants don't open for dinner until around 8PM but there are plenty of other places to get your snack on and drink on until then.

It's the place to be on Sunday. On Sundays people congregate around Plaza Dorrego, which is surrounded by antique shops, and artisans spread their wares along the surrounding streets. The antique shops are expensive, so doing your homework is advised before making a purchase. There are a number of good restaurants in the area. Once the artisans pack up in the late afternoon, tango dancers fill Plaza Dorrego.

Stay in San Telmo. I stayed in San Telmo for 3 weeks. San Telmo is the oldest part of Buenos Aires. The colonial architecture and cobble stone streets are beautiful and quaint. There is also a lot of graffiti art throughout the area.There is a lot of good shopping for shoes and clothes; small family run businesses. There the San Telmo market; several small shops in one large warehouse, where you can buy all your groceries. Durago square has a flea market every sat and sun.If you love to dance there is live music in Durago square several evenings a week and tango every Sunday evening.
Lively area, lots of things to see. San Telmo is a nice area to walk around in, lots of things to see like street musicians, street art and a sense of history in general.

Great Local Eating Spot. if you want markets this is a great spot. All day Sunday. Tango Dancing, free music, probably the most interesting market in B.A. And fantastic architecture. Look out for the fantastic Antonio and his son in the local restaurant PulperiaPulperia Quilipan and don't be put off by the hole in the wall curtain covered entrance and dilapidated dining room. The food is great, the music fantastic, the atmosphere friendly and truly Argentinian and great value. We we told to keep our valuables safe and in wine hotel so we only took minimal cash but we saw no evidence of any untoward behaviour and the atmosphere of the whole place was very relaxed. Would definitely recommend.

one of the best areas of the city. This is a must-see .Duh Argentina soars here until morning.Good restaurants a lot of pleasant emotions is a fellowship of people all the things that you will meet here

great place to enjoy street shopping. This was very entertaining and walking through the area. A lot to see and enjoy Architecture, arts and crafts as well as other goods for sale. Who doesn't enjoy a street market???
Interesting district especially for Sunday market. Fun area if you like a stroll through a Sunday street market with many nice restaurants. Easy walk from Plaza de Mayo

I LOVE SAN TELMO. The high end boutiques and restaurants in Palermo and Recoleta are not my style. I love the older buildings and bohemian charm of San Telmo. I have stayed there twice in a rented older apartment overlooking Plaza Dorrego. You can't beat falling asleep to the sounds of Tango music below. The San Telmo Market is full of pohotographic opportunities as well as the best coffee around. The street fair on Sunday is a great way to spend the day (don't miss choripan on the corner of Defensa and Mexico on Sunday - the best!). One of my favorite things to do is stroll up and down the cobbletone streets looking at street art, talking to shop owners, and taking photos. There are numerous cafes and bars to eat eat and drink at. I can't wait to return.
Lovely area. We stayed at a local hotel in the area and enjoyed the ambiance of the area, the plaza Dorrego, and the many outstanding restaurants to choose from.

A feeling of traditional Buenos Aires. I spent a few days walking around the main streets of San Telmo, and attended the street market one weekend as well.It is beautiful with lots of old buildings, indoor markets, churches, stores, and good local restaurants. It was very interesting, and much safer than La Boca, for example, while having its own traditional charms. It also was not "touristy" at all in my opinion.There are some excellent shoe shops - not bargain shoe shops, but incredibly well made by hand, very good quality shoes in styles not easily found in North America. This is the place to splurge on leather good of any sort.As anywhere in Buenos Aires, you have to take reasonable precautions as robberies and pickpocketing are not unusual. Do not walk around wearing expensive clothing, accessories, jewelry, and displaying expensive tech like iPhones. Be discreet with your money, and leave most of it in your hotel safe except what you need for the day. Be familiar with the currency and what counterfeits look like otherwise you could be taken advantage of. I would not recommend walking here alone after dark at all, but I was fine alone during the day sticking to the main streets.It was one of the most charming neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires and a genuine pleasure to explore on foot.
The flee market of buenos aires. Very nice place to visit on Sunday (only) besides the market also beautiful buildings and things to buy. Music and food.

Best way to spend a Sunday. We saved the best for last. Stretching several kilometers along Defensa Ave.from Plaza de Mayo to Plaza Dorrego artisans sell their wares every Sunday. This culminates into an antique market surrounded by outdoor cafes and restaurants complete with tango demonstrations.

Perfect neighborhood to stay in. Definitely recommend staying in San Telmo. Don't let the appearance dissuade you. Great people and proximity to restaurants, shops, the port and downtown. A very walkable neighborhood.
Great place for a TANGO intro. Great place for a TANGO intro, the central square has a café where young Tango dancers perform for tips on the weekend. Worth a visit, easily combined into Boca.

Don't go on any day except Sunday!. It's dead from Monday-Saturday. Sunday is absolutely amazing. Streets are packed with vendors and and live shows (music, tango dancing, etc.) Very touristy but absolutely worth it. You can buy all your souvenirs and gifts here. You can haggle a little, especially if you have US dollars.

Loved it. Great day out visiting the market. It has something for everyone, bring comfy shoes as the cobbled streets can be a tad difficult. It is spread over a number of streets, has live tango dancers, musicians, artists, street vendors. Some interesting items for sale too. Sunday is the day to visit it.

Beautiful and historic. Take care of your belongings. I personally had a wonderful experience in San telmo. Walked around at night and through the Sunday market with no incident. However I am well aware of my surroundings and am used to busy cities. I was witness to a broad daylight mugging on my last day of an elderly lady with jewellery on display, video recording with an iPad and not paying any attention to her surroundings. A very traumatic and unfortunate event surely, but easily avoidable as well. All in all a great visit with great pubs and restaurants throughout.

Nice Sunday markets. If you are in BA on Sunday take a stroll to the markets, there is lots to see. If you hang around till 5pm around the plaza at the bottom you will be able to watch a live street tango performnace for free, very cool and different to all the shows that are on offer everywhere.

Such a lovely town. We arrived on the weekend and were told to go and check out the market in San telmo, it was vibrant and interesting filled with locals and tourists. By far the best bit however was the milonga in the evening, music plays and loads of couples dance tango it's incredible... Just wish I could have joined in!

Don't sit down or make eye contact. We visited this dirty little park on a hot sundry night. Too late for the market, we ate in the square and watched the tango dancers do their thing as a drunk bum/thief pestered us for beer and money. The tango part was interesting, the rest was dirty, graffiti covered old buildings. For me, not worth the trip.

Great coffee, markets, and vibes. One of the few places with good coffee, great little cafes, and a fantastic market on a Sunday. San Telmo is a great place to walk around and take in the cobblestoned streets or find somewhere to have a meal and a drink. The markets bring with it great street buskers and hundreds of things to look at.

San Telmo the bario - exactly as you have imagined Buenos Aires. I have to admit to a major love affair with San Telmo, bringing me back year after year to stay in this fascinating bario. This is where you will find fading architecture from the turn of the C19, arts, crafts, university students and the city's bohemian residents. Central is the glorious Mercado San Telmo - a fruit, vegetable, meat and antique market of enormous proportions. Visit the bario on a Sunday to catch the mile-long street market in Defensa. Stay for lunch at one of the plethora of street cafés - try El Federal in Carlos Calvo; and take a cold beer with the tango dancers in Plaza Dorrego. If you are not in a rush, stay for supper at El Desnivel in Defensa, and indulge with the late night milonga at Maldita, Peru 571, to watch the live orchestra El Afronte.

Great art and rare finds. If your looking for something to do on a Sunday while in BA, then this is a must. Here you will find an assortment of arts and crafts along with antiques, not to mention some cool and yummy street food

Sunday afternoons don't get any better. San Telmo is the place I would not miss on a Sunday afternoon for a few hours. The music and laid back atmosphere is different, Tango in the street and of course a cold bottle of Quilmes or 2 to quench your thirst. a truly relaxing way of spending Sunday.

Best barrio in BA. Great place to stay. Lots of bars, restaurants.Easy to reach el Retiro, Puerto Madero, Congreso and Minicentro by walking distance.Mercado San Telmo on Sundays with music, shopping, tango on Plaza Dorrego.

Sunday visit to markets. A great activity for a Sunday. The markets are huge, so wear your walking shoes. Very close to the pink palace, so both of these attractions could easily be done on the same day.

Exciting and Entertaining . I've been to the Sunday street market in San Telmo many times and always enjoy the bustling activity as well as the local color. If you are in Buenos Aires on a Sunday it is a must do experience.
Very charming . Stayed in San Telmo for several nights and so enjoyed the ambiance of the Dorrego Square, music, bars and cafes. Easy and safe to walk around wonderful antique stores

Flea market and Madero. Loved the area, old but trendy, with bars and restos... Sundays flea market from Plaza de Mayo up calle Defensa, It's nice. Stop at the icecream shop right at the square (opposite there's a starbucks). Go further, to the right you will find the galerias de la defensa (atrium like with shops and Cafés upstairs, picturesque), passing further, there's a zombie museum (haven't been inside, check the internet). Puerto Madero is not too far from the middle part of Defensa (10-15 mins by foot).

Lively and colourful city market. Everything you expect from BA - market full of colourful people, food and goods. Spent a lovely Sunday morning buying Christmas presents, listening to live bands and finishing off with some great BBQ/parilla.

A funky,vibrant street neighborhood.. Lots of nice old architecture in this slight run down old neighborhood. The highlight is the flea market on Sunday, wander at will. Somewhere along the street is on old covered market which is authentic and a little less touristy. I have on the authority of my coffee selling Italian barista that the the best cappuccino is in there. I certainly thought it was wonderfull. But it was warm inside the market, good job the ice cream wasn't. This area was a fun half day, I did feel the need to beware of pickpockets, we had no trouble but it had that vibe.

An entertaining and varied part of Buenos Aires. At first glance the area may look intimidating; there is graffiti (squiggles) on almost every building (as there is also in other parts of Buenos Aires). But as you look around you see up-market marbled-fronted apartment blocks intermingled with well-maintained and non-maintained traditional old houses (some are in excellent condition).Some pavements are potholed (tread carefully) but there is new pavement outside of the newer buildings. The streets are well lit at night and women walk around safely on their own. Taxis are frequent in all streets.There is a police station with police coming and going all the time. There are offices, hotels, numerous restaurants, bistros, bars, wine bars, antique shops, bookshops, offices and many small supermarkets and food shops. There are major supermarkets on the major roads, a few short blocks away.In Plaza Dorada you can watch Tango dancers in the open air as you dine. On Sundays the Plaza hosts a large open-air market, where artists, among others, sell their wares.All in all an entertaining and varied part of Buenos Aires. I shall be back.
A charming old world neighborhood with so much to see. Cobble stone street. Beautiful architecture. Flowers and vines cascading from balconies. Great food. Great music. What more could you ask for !

Stayed here during my trip to Buenos Aires - nice atmospheric area. Liked this area - and glad I picked it over my original choices in the microcentro. The area has real character and you feel like part of the neighbourhood. Would have to pick out Origen cafe as a favourite just a street down from where I was staying.

One of my favourite places in BA. OK OK hands up this place is touristy, the market is swarming with tourists on a Sunday BUT it is also swarming with locals. The whole of San Telmo is full of character and it is a little grittier than other parts of BA, it also has a really great hippy vibe. I really like San Telmo, I could have lived there for definite. I love the old rundown palatial houses which have been modified into antique and craft shops, I love the old bars with the mix of locals and tourists. I think the area is colourful and vibrant but you do have to watch out for the usual scams. The squares will often get the tango buskers come along and hassle you with a hat for change and I also spotted a few unsavoury pick pockets around. It is one of those areas which has character but also its fair share of characters and so just be on your guard and wander around and soak up the atmosphere. The market is great on Sunday as it has loads of musicians and a wide variety of stores.

We go to San Telmo every Sunday. Whenever we have out of town visitors, we always schedule a day on Defensa of shopping, people watching, and expierencing the vibe of the market. What fun. Then we find a cafe for a cold drink and a snack. There is always something to buy. Love the mimes, and the music.
Need a gift for family?. Stop in at the San Telmo market if you need to bring something home to family members. Keep in mind nothing really starts to open until after 12 - 1 pm.

The Sunday flea market. Bring plenty of pesos and give yourself a whole day to shop and browse. Stalls, shops, restaurants and street musicians and performers. A wonderful way to spend Sunday in Buenos Aires. Bring a big empty backpack to cart home your treasures.

Mardigras any Sunday.. If you want to have fun and get interesting, useful and beautiful things at reasonable and cheap prices, go there. Stay until sunset and join the people dancing and sharing everything as they play music through the streets. Sort of Mardigras.

Love the flea market!. St Telmo streets are great to just walk around in and there is a multitude of cafes and eateries. The residential buildings that line the streets are wonderful and each one has a character and a beauty of its own.There is music on street corners and a multitude of antique shops. You can also find a branch of Coffee Town (the best coffee and cheesecake in B.A.!!! inside the closed market). On Sundays there is a 'street market' and several blocks of artesian tables line the street with orange juice, empenada and choripan to keep you going. Also at the end of the market tango dancers do a show every half hour. These are all fun and worth a visit but these are not the best reasons to visit st telmo!! The Artesians and their wares are also available in many neighbourhoods and they are just as good, say, in the Recoleta park near the famous cemetry on Sundays. As for street tango everyday on the corner of the Recoleta park a group of tango dancers do a show for tips and Nadia and her partners can even arrange tango lessons by the hour!!!. So why go to St Telmo?? What makes St Telmo special is the flea market which is best seen on a week day! If looking through flea market stalls is your thing then find the hidden door to the St Telmo mercadona and walk into the Old Buenos Aires! There is all kind of stuff from old broaches and clip on earrings to silk nightgowns and dresses, I even found a pair of tango shoes (comfortable as someone has already worn it into shape and cheaper than anything you can find in the shops!)...The stall owners are friendly and approachable and we have had some wonderful conversations and purchases on every visit!
Has a vibe & history. Great cafes kept from the 1930s and the glory days of Argentina. La Poesia a treat good food cafe and service. You nearly expect Hemmingway to come in

The Sunday market. This is the 2nd time I have gone to this market and do not find it too exciting. The music and the people are what makes it interesting. I'm not an antiques person and most of the market is out antiques.

Lively antique/flea market. It spans sevelal blocks on Defense and the neighbouring streets with some picture galleries thrown in an real and fake antiques.Like everywhere else today - at least spacewise it is dominated by turist junk. At the end there is a small area you can watch tango on the street danced by younger and older couples (provided is not raining). The area itself is interesting with architecture spanning several centuries in Argentine history.

A great area to explore. San Telmo is a great neighborhood to explore in Buenos Aires. Dozens of restaurants and bars frequented by many people. Street fairs and street vendors. Always lively..day or night. Worth a visit..or better yet a good place to stay during your visit.

Great area to wander through during day. On Sunday there is a street market in the area but it's very busy and means you miss the lovely shops on either side so it's worth visiting twice.There are plenty of cafes to eat and drink, with couple paid to tango outside to draw the crowds.Our favourite area in BA.

Cozy Argentina. Very nice and safe neighbouhood. People are very polite. Bohemia place. El Federal is a must. We (two girls) used to come back to the hotel on foot later like 4am and we were safe and sound. We never get a taxi cause it's not necessary.

Go on Sunday for the markets!. It's not just about shopping at the markets, but about the street life as well. Everyone is out, walking down the middle of Defensa with hundreds of stalls all the way down to the antiques market. On Sunday night (before 11, at least) groups drum on various corners throughout the neighborhood, and people come out, listen, and dance. I was a little worried when we ran into the first of these groups, but it was pleasant and inclusive, and would recommend that anyone feel at home. Don't miss the covered market (mostly food!) and the smaller side streets. This is a place to stroll, sit in a square, or drink coffee at a cafe taking in the life of Buenos Aires.

San Telmo Sunday Market - Big, varied and fun. Six of us visited the Sunday market on a recommendation. Lots of clothes, trinkets, jewelry. Maybe because we had heard so much about it we had great expectations. It was nice but we found nothing unique about it. It was safe and interesting nothing remarkable or notable, at least for us. If we were staying nearby with nothing else to do we would return.

Super fun on a Sunday. San Telmo was an exciting experience. Lots of street venders and street artists. Popped into a few of the markets to scout out antiques... Some good finds if you're looking. Lots of great Tango to enjoy too. Sunday's are great days to explore this area.

Grrat Sunday market. San Telmo is a nice area with lots of restaurants. On a Sunday one of the streets is transformed into a street market. It's about 3k long. Give yourself 4 or 5 hours for the market. Lots of interesting things to buy. Tourist stuff, antiques and street food. There is also a bench where you can have you're picture taken with Marfala.

Try go on a Sunday. Unfortunately we weren't in town on a Sunday so missed the big market and festivities. Despite this, it was an interesting historical neighborhood. We visited the market and many of the stalls were still open (best fresh produce we saw in Buenos Aires). Other than that many restaurants, antiques shops and some tango on the streets for those who appreciate it.
Go on a Sunday. Large bustling Sunday market including antique and vintage stalls, small independant shops, bars and restuarants with bands and buskers. Great for a perusal and great atmosphere.
Love the walk!. Experience the Buenos Aires rhythm through its music, street artists, artisians and flea market. Be ready to walk.

Real Argentine Feel. Make sure to visit on a Sunday to experience the artisan market. It goes on and on! Really fun to walk through. Colonial architecture is a must see. Lots of great restaurants, shops & bars.

Lots of good finds. I highly recommend this place. It's worth a visit if you have time. You buy or not you'll enjoy this place. There was a pair dancing tango on the street, very entertaining. Lots of antique stuff if you're for it. Lots of leather bags and cow rugs. I bought a beautiful cow rug which I enjoyed now at home. Good price. You are free to haggle if you like.
Great place to spend a few hours.. Saturday late morning stopped for a coffee at the market then decided to stay for lunch and watch the street tango. Great way to spend a Saturday in Buenios Aires.

San Telmo is a great stop for antiqyes. If you are like us who love having a glass of wine while visiting antique shops, San Telmo will not disappoint you! The neighborhood is charming, full of personality, featuring old, traditional bistros, and a carefree atmosphere. We had a great time exploring the open air antique tents and bought a few-easy-carry silver pieces from the 19th century. A real trip in time. Sidewalks, though, are not always friendly and service could've been more attentive. Overall, a nice time!

Where everything happened. The heart of the old Buenos Aires: the first churches ( not to miss San Ignacio, San Francisco and Sto Domingo), schools and "conventillo".Offices and important headquarters mix with popular neighbourhood.So you are supposed to meet after office pubs, "manifestaciones políticas" and school pupils.

Old Buenos Aires. Sort of like Soho in NYC, San Telmo has that bohemian feel.You will find old sort of interesting things, from the market to small museums to just old stores, with a strong sense of the old Buenos Aires.A must although a bit touristy in some areas.

The street market is a must see. Once a week (at least) is there the San Telmo market, which have lots of things to buy for every kind of person. I love to take a walk and I always buy lots of things here.

Best way to spend a Sunday. . The Sunday market is the perfect way to spend a day. There are lots of restaurants and tons of kiosks selling everything you can imagine. The best part is that the sellers do not hassle you at all. You can ask lots of questions and walk away with no pressure to buy.

avoid Sundays. leisure and adventure to find intricate and lovely corners throughout this historic area. avoid Sundays to take your camera and shoot architecture, old market and antique shops. plenty of art and history museums private and public. you may spend a day (if you are a quick traveler) or two. always enjoyable!

Vibrant neighbourhood and Antique market. One of my favourite parts of Buenos Aires! Visit San Telmo on a Sunday to enjoy the antique market in Plaza Dorrega, as well as the music and Tango dancers. Follow along Avenida Defensa to the main Market building and the block after block of tables selling souvenirs. There are lots of cafes and interesting old buildings to look at, too.

The Sunday Markets along defensa are amazing. San Telmo is probably the best neighbourhood to stay within if you are visiting Buenos Aires. The suburbs of the microcentro, La City and Puerto Madero are all within walking distance while Recolecta and Palmero are just a short metro ride away. It's has a plethora of cheap accommodation options although some sections are safer than others.One attraction not to be missed here is the Sunday markets which set up for around 1km along defensa street. Classically these Sunday markets are associated with the Plaza Dorrego but in modern times it seems that they have extended significantly down defensa street - a street that also features a number of antique stores. It's a great place to purchase souvenirs that are unique and not mass produced rubbish.

The oldest district in Buenos Aires. Cobbled narrow streets, small houses. antique shops and a huge antique market in Plaza Dorrega and the whole length on Avenue Defensa every Sunday, this is the best time to visit, sit down and people watch with a coffee in Plaza Dorrega then browse the hundred of stalls along Defensa. Also lots of great restaurants, bars and cafes to drink in the atmosphere.

Great Place to explore but be careful with your cameras etc.. an interesting , poorer area of Buenos Aires. Many small restaurants and cafes some better than others. It is a place to which you should go with caution. There are small ga gas of people who would try to destruct you and steal your pisessions. Favorite trick: they spray you with some dirty water and then alert you to the fact that somehow an AC leaked from a window. You bend down and put your camera or bag on the side and a moment later it is gone. So be careful, but do not be discouraged from going there. It is an interesting part of the city.

My favorite part of BA. This is a nifty neighborhood. Tawny homes, lovely tree lined streets. It had a very distinctive personality from other neighborhoods. If I could live anywhere in BA, it would definitely be here!
Nice place to walk on Sunday. But not the only one where you can buy souvenirs and see tango. Drummers are awesome. It's really hard to stay at one place, want to dance together with everybody.

Don't get put off by the graffiti . At first glance, you'd think that all the graffiti on all available walls (n I mean everywhere!) would mean that the place was a little unsafe n off-putting. But really the street art is spectacular juxtaposed in an area famous for antiques n street markets. But please do be careful with your belongings as tourists. I was cautioned a few times by a friendly policeman abt my camera.

Lots to see and buy. Plenty of vendors fill the square and surrounding streets. This year we found a smaller collection of crafts than in years past. Plenty of "antiques". Found the fair in Riccoleta the day before to offer a greater selection.

Cool bar scene. Doesnt really get going until 11pm but lots of bars and good energy and some tango clubs mixed in. Nothing too expensive and seemed relatively safe walking the streets but I have read otherwise.
Sunday market for antiques, music and cool beer. Enjoyed walking through the market, atmospheric with music , dancing and relaxed pubs for cool beer or coffee.

Do your souvenir and gift shopping here. A charming open air market, not nearly as crowded as we were led to believe. We thoroughly enjoyed the charming booths that line each side of the narrow street.

Antiques galore!. I was so sad I missed the Sunday markets, but I did manage to visit some of the antique shops. If you're looking for something truly special and not run-of-the-mill-Argentine-touristy-SHTUFF this is the perfect place to shop.

Best to visit on the weekend.. A great square, with some nice cafes and tango dancers. There is an interesting antiques market, but on a week day, most of this was closed. Around the square are some really interesting antique shops, certainly worth a stop if you're in the area.

Fun to go on Sunday and walk the markets. This market on Sunday stretches for blocks and blocks. There are alot of local vendors selling all kinds of things from hats to art to leather goods, you name it. There are all kinds of antique stores along the street that are good for walking through or treasure hunting. The best part of the markets for us were the meat pies - more calzones than empanadas. They are sold on the street and are super cheap and super delicious.
Lovely San Telmo!. We enjoyed the area of San Telmo very much. Make sure not to miss there outdoor sunday market. Lovely area for just stroling and looking at nice arquitecture.

Sunday market. the best outdoor market in Argentina--- not the usual basura found----hand made items crafted by hand by these vendors---not made in China-- beautful handicrafts, wine holders made in leather, not the usual scarves and vests found everywhere-- go early on Sunday to avoid crowds

Sundays are best on Defensa Street. The Sunday feria from around 1pm or so is brilliant for good window shopping; picking up the local atmosphere and also street drinks and food (although I didn't try any of the asados). There were also plenty of street artists and musicians. A bit busy though so be a bit safe with your belongings.
A Must-see. A must-see while in Buenos Aires. Take time to wander through the shops and sit down at one of the outdoor cafes for a cold drink and maybe a lunch and watch the Tango dancers.

expect crowds and good music. we enjoyed out time on feria day but not as much as we enjoyed on an off day window shopping the wonderful antique shops. the san telmo market is very good and seems to be either partially closed in summers or on weekdays. we are here in the summer so it's hard to say. if you go the the square, you really only need to walk about 4 blocks before you get into schlock. it's a nice way to spend a saturday or sunday.
Fascinating old neighbourhood of Buenos Aires. We really enjoyed exploring the San Telmo area with its street markets, antique shops, musicians and sounds of the tango. Greatly recommended!

Stunning. San Telmo is such a nice area, it looks a bit historical, and theres a little passage with a huge tree and flowers, which i believe attracts a lot of tourists, where you can take nice pictures. It looks like from 1960's. Im not sure if its considered a safe area tho. Its good to have a spanish speaker with you since they dont speak english there (in shops and restaurants)! I definitely recommend everyone to visit San Telmo!

Embodies the essence!. We were told we had to see the San Telmo area. Indeed, it is an historic area that has many small shops of all descriptions and and interest.(also a great ice-cream store on a corner) The San Telmo market which had been suggested as a place of interest ran a little shy of its reputation. From our point of view if you have visited the market in Valencia Spain, then this one is pale by comparison. We had some very good coffee at Coffee Town located in the middle of the market and then left. We made our way back to Dorrego Plaza, located just minutes away and enjoyed a lovely breakfast sitting outside on the plaza. All small restaurants around the square have their outside seating areas under umbrellas. The sun can get very warm during their summer! The highlight for us was when 3 tango couples arrived and set up their music and 'floor' and started dancing the tango. It was so unusual for us to see this 'spontaneous' tango breakout. We were enthralled to say the least! We landed up spending the entire afternoon enjoying the ambience. From time to time we ordered a cold drink at our 'ringside seats'. Of course, after the end of several dances a hat was passed around by the dancers. A fifty peso bill (approx $4 ) was most appreciated. We repeated that 3 times that afternoon and took away unforgettable memories!!
Go if like of turistic places . It's not fantastic, but the mercado de San Telmo express more the Argentin spirit! But need a reform ! If you like of old objects and handcrafts, its your place!
San Telmo. Hundreds of shops you name it they have it, live music , good food it is more like a carnival atmosphere , this place is a must see if you visit Argentina
cafes bars markets. great area of BA for seeing free tango in the square, markets and many options for eating and drinking

Quaint, bohemian and full of antiques and surprises.. Walking through Defensa on my way to the museum of modern Arts, I walked throug San Telmo. BTW, it's best to walk everywhere in BA.This area is bohemian and full of lovely stores. Visit the quaint indoor market antique market on Defensa. Lots of treasures there. On the junction of Defensa and humbler to Primo (to the right) is an open area where you can see professional tango dancer in progress. This was a treat for me as one of the reason I wanted to come here was to see Argentine Tango. You can order a glass of beer and enjoy the dance. On the day I visited, an English girl named Karen was dancing (beautifully I must add) after the dance she came round for tips and we chatted for a bit. She told me if I really want appreciate tango, it's best to go to a milonga. Best advice I received in BA.She gave me the address of a milonga (humberto primo 1400) that was happening that night.She said the top tango dancing couple were performing that night and also one of the best orchestra was going to perform too. Best to get a cab to and fro. Of course, I went. This turned out to be the highlight of my trip to BA.The dancing couples - Young and old. Simply wonderful.The orchestra, just fabulous and the pros. Perfection.This show was a one off , but I think the venue is used for weekly milongas. It is a far better experience than the tango dance and dinner venues dotted around BA.it only cost 100 pesos to get in. WARNING ALERT: have a fan with you as it can get really hot in the milonga.If you read this and see Karen dancing, please encourage her and tip generously.I love SAN Telmo, it is a wonderful place. As I said, it best to walk round and just take it. Highly recommended.

Not really an antique market on Sundays. I have been to Buenos Aires many times over the years, but never managed to visit this market so I was quite curious. I was told it was an antique market, and even if there are a few stands that do sell old pieces, most stands sell handicraft, wallets, purses, or art. Still quite interesting and you can look around and buy some souvenirs. Cash only.The neighborhood is in the south side, considered more alternative.

very authentic peek into Buenos Aires rich history, really a huge fair. really a must for anyone visiting Buenos Aires, there are stores which sells literally everything under the sun, including high end antiques, and some very mesmerizing streetacts, so you will not be bored.

Sunday shopping fiesta for the ladies. In Buenos Aires oldest neighborhood walk Blocks and blocks of Shops and vendor tables selling Argentine crafted items,paintings,antiques, leathers goods at steal prices,many paperback books, Souveniers. Enjoy Live Bands at each corner playing Jazz, Rock,Tangos. Street is also full of Restaurants offering lunches under 80 pesos($6 dollars). Drink a Quilmes beer at neighborhood Bars. Expresso and Starbucks Coffee shops, Great Ice cream parlors. Enjoy local Havanna Alfajores(dulce de Leche cookie shops.

A fun, unique and spirited area with lots of great restuarants. Just don't show up on a monday/tuesday ad most of the restuarnats will be closed, but there are so many great little places, the renowned San Telmo Market, and close to two great museums and Nuestra Parrilla, a little hole in the wall choripan with great sandwiches and beer. Walk the streets, find the little square which has great little homemade jewelry makes and you won't be disappointed in your visit.

Cool area with lots of antique shops. It's a cool area in that it has retained a lot of its historic charm, such as cobblestone streets, squares, colonial architecture and tango influence. Lots of antique shops with really eclectic stuff. Nice restaurant to and lots of bars. It's the oldest part of BA and worth a stroll. Sunday is the flea market day and it's huge.

Just cross the defensa street and that's all. instead of this street, don't expect too much from there as streets are empty and shops not great. It a good way to go from the center from la boca but it is a looong walkvisit the Defensa street on Sunday

Fantastic street market on a Sunday. Antiques And crafts. Lovely market on a Sunday going on for miles . Good chance of seeing some Tango dancers dancing to local musicians, they will be touting for tip . Lovely bars and cafes great place to people watch and browse the antique shops. Great place to spend a few hours or the whole day if you decide to sit at one of the pavement cafes and enjoy the Argentinian Malbec !

Should have gone on Sunday. We missed the big antiques/flea market on Sunday which is probably the biggest draw even though we heard from local friends that it has gone down hill in recent years. Walking around during the week was not particularly exciting but we did enjoy a nice lunch at Aldo's which I highly recommend if you are in the area.

Gone down the pan. This was the second time we had been to Buenos Aires and stayed in San Telmo. Ok it's touristy but part of the objective was to dance tango in local Milongas and buy new tango shoes and it's a good centre. The first thing we noticed was how much the infrastructure had deteriorated since last time. 5 years ago it was possible to walk along the pavement in high heels. Not now. You'd break your ankle. You have to take your shoes with you and change there. Get ever so slightly off the beaten tourist trail and there are a lot more people sleeping on the streets - even walking along the main road opposite Puerto Madero. Having said that there was a great deal more city police on the street so as long as you stick to the main streets it's probably OK but you do have to know where you're going and be wary. The other thing to note is that new year is not the best time for a visit. Pretty much everything is closed. All the tango shops (except VB on Independencia) and even many of the restaurants. We had real difficulty finding somewhere to eat on New Year's Day. IF there's a next time I will probably stay somewhere else

A walk through. If you walk along Casa Florida and the on to Casa Peru then you are going through this district.Like La Boca there is a lot of broken sidewalks and ubiquitous dog poo however still some beautiful buildingsWell worth a walk through.

Secure your wallet!!!. It's a must see place - though you'll find a lot of cheap stuff on display in the streets. Real antiques and valuable pieces of this flea market are being sold in stores - where the owners wait for their prey..... Do NOT use a backpack, Be alert, try not to look like an absent minded tourist, and leave your jewelry in a safe at your hotel: San Telmo is also known for extremely talented pick-pocktes.

Dog poo everywhere, but still worth it. I would not use the phrase "curb your dog" and San Telmo in the same sentence, but this colorful district has a funky charm worth seeing. Its narrow cobblestone streets are home to lots of cool little shops, restaurants and bars, and some real jewels, like the indoor market on Bolivar near Carlos Calvo. You can easily spend a whole day meandering, but watch your step!
Street fair on Sunday. Nice stalls selling art, live music on the streets including a tango performance. Lovely antique shops in the area.

Overwhelming and Amazing . We were lucky enough to walk through this neighborhood twice: once on a normal day and once on Sunday. The neighborhood is very nice by itself but on Sundays it transforms into an enormous market where you can buy anything from antiques to souvenirs. We spent 7 hours walking that market. If you're spending any time in Buenos Aires, you have to check it out!
interesting neighborhood. As with other neighborhoods in BA this one is interesting to visit but you'll soon forget the details your visit.
Fun Sunday Stroll. It was a really good fun place to be. Lots of atmosphere! If you like antiques this is the place to be. There are lots of cheap souvenir stalls. Live music a trendy place to hang.

Not So "Unique". This long street with markets is sure to offer you all sorts of antiques and trinkets, but you can find this and sometimes more in other cities.This place is terrible if you are taking someone that walks very slowly, like your grandpa's, they are going to get runned over.

Lively Sunday Market. San Telmo is an Antique Market located in the old part of Buenos Aires. On your way to the market you'll walk along streets full of Artisans and thei colorful stands. Prices are reasonable.

Great market. Great market and very very big! Reminded me of Portobello market in London. Got some nice deals here on leather accessories and outfits. Great cafes and restaurants. Just beware it can be very hot here in summer and you are walking in the street... we sadly had to leave after an hour it was too much...

Happening and spirited area. Great area in Buenos Aires as there is so much to do, see and taste. On Sunday's markets are setup along Defensa (street) and runs for about 15 blocks. Loads of treasures and exciting stalls. Musicians and dancers on street corners. During the week the area is still alive with antique shops as well as interesting shops plus Plaza Dorrego always has tango dancers at some time during the day. Food is great. Coffee town for great coffee, Amicei Mei for very tasty handmade pasta and several good restaurants for good food. No queuing or booking!

YOU WILL BE TARGETED BY THEIVES!!!. So the market itself is great. But you are constantly being targeted by an organized ring of thieves. They do not want confrontation, just distraction and then your bag, backpack, or purse is gone. Likely placed into another discreet bag and then the thief can simply act like a tourist. They immediate go to a secure location, apartment, van, etc. and take the cash. Usually your CCs are fine, as they know u will cancel them. But replacing the passports, drivers license, car keys, etc etc. is now your problem. You won't find the discarded bag. Don't bother looking. Report it to the police. The number of reports might generate additional resources to the problem, but realistically, your stuff is absolutely gone. Take note of this... security cameras capture most of these "petty crimes", but the police do not own the cameras and due to bureaucracy, rarely get access to the footage. So u are on your own. If your hand or eyes are not on your bag, even if it is right next to you, it will be gone. People had their things stolen from between their legs, under the chair, between their chairs. You must consider that any and every street vendor is in on the rouse as well. Enjoy yourself, but be smart. According to my informal assessment at the police station, every 5-10 minutes, during the Sunday flea market, a bag is stolen. Do not let it be yours!

Best shopping market I visited. I loved this market it is definitely more varied when it comes to food, artisans, and souvenirs. I would say tourists have to be modest with their backpacks, cameras, jewelry, and all that. Sellers are the nicest but some people want to take advantage of tourists

Sunday Street Bizarre. Going to the Street Bizarre on Sunday was a great introduction to our vacation in Argentina. The street is pedestrian only lined with vendors, artists. Great place to find t-shirts, jewelry, leather goods, etc. or just walk with a beer listening to street music. It really put us in a festive mood. While having lunch, a couple danced the tango. Later that afternoon, a tango exhibition took place in the San Telmo square. Rub shoulders with the locals.

Free spirit and VERY busy. This little neighborhood has a LOT going on. It never sleeps. There are people on the streets at all hours of the day and night. Locals ( in general ALL throughout Buenos Aires) are very serious and miserable looking. I absolutely LIVE this city but the locals should really smile a little more. I was here for a week and only got a couple of smiles. People just don't smile. Most are friendly but with a dry to the point attitude. If you can get passed that, you will have a GREAT TIME.

Sunday market is great, but go any day of the week. The San Telmo Sunday flea market is a fun, must-do experience if you happen to be in town that day of the week. But there is still a lot to see other days of the week and, next to Palermo soho, is one of my favorite neighborhoods. Amazing antique stores, jewelry, formal art, street art and museums. No matter which day you go, start at the Plaza Dorrego and walk around from there.
What a Dump. There is no charm. There is nothing but a flea market full of crap.DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIMEDO NOT BOTHER GOING HERE

Must Visit on Sunday. If you are in the area on Sunday you must visit! I literally spent half a day walking through the streets, shopping and people watching. Very unique experience to learn about Argentina culture and bring home some homemaid souvenirs.

Worth the wander..... Enjoyed wandering about San Telmo - lots of terrific restaurants - a very cool little square - felt very "authentic" I felt like this was a terrific combination of local charm and traveler safety. Find one of the local restaurants in the Spring or summer and enjoy lunch on the patio.

Sense The Latino Passion. On a roasting hot December Sunday afternoon this makes a nice eventful destination. The narrow cobbled streets are full of stalls selling artisan crafts, freshly squeezed orange juice, antiques, junk. There is enough to keep every visitor curious and content. There are awesome bars to stop off on for much needed refreshments; the Bar Britanico, La Poesia are particularly recommended. There is an engaging Latino atmosphere throbbing through these streets. You'll feel it coming off the cobbles, off the graffitied walls, off the cries of stall venders. A superb Sunday thing to do in Buenos Aires.
San Telmo. This is a great area to stay. It is a mix of quirky shops, nice places, shabby places and interesting bars and restaurants. Families seem to live there. It can be dodgy too.

Sunday Bazaar. We walked the bazaar on a Sunday afternoon. It was a great way to see a slice of culture. You will see everything from junk to treasures. But if you have time, do it. Easy walk from tube station.

Highly enjoyable . We walked around Parque Lezama and marveled at the huge palm trees and other, more exotic plants here, then wandered down the Defenca street towards the famous Plaza Dorrego where we had some food and drinks in the shade, watching tango dancers. Afterwards we just walked on the Defenca and parallel Balcarce streets, looking up - such magnificent buildings here!

Beautiful part of BA!. The square where there is outdoor restaurants (Plaza Dorrego) may not be the best food in the area but the atmosphere is really nice. I wish I would have stayed in this area of B.A.. I had read (what I felt was) inaccurate information of how safe an area that San Telmo is... . It's not TOTALLY safe but what area IS totally safe. :) Please consider staying in this area and if nothing else DEFINITELY visit!

Best outdoor market in the world?. The Sunday market in San Telmo certainly competes with the best in the world. I've been to the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, which is one a whole other scale, but i enjoyed the San Telmo market more. Here walking down Defensa you can buy anything Argentinian that your heart desires. Its a must do if you are in Buenos Aires on a Sunday.

best part of Buenos. for me this is the best part of Buenos Aires.You must get there on Sunday when it becomes a huge openair market, music stage and tango place. just get lost in all streets, old shops and handicrafts strols.on sunday get ready for a long party.

Cool area off the beaten track. Relaxed part of BA out of the main tourist area with a lot of cafes, alternative art galleries and shops. Nice place to stroll for a while and have a great and reasonably priced meal.

Interesting market along Defensa. San Telmo is part of the inner core of Buenos Aires. It has some historical buildings, but, for me, the highlight was the market that stretches from Plaza Dorrego for, at least, a kilometre along Defensa and has an enormous range of goods, souvenirs etc on offer.
Best market in buenos aires. We came across the San Telmo market by accident and ended up spending an entire Sunday PM wandering the streets and enjoying the market and people. Wonderful market!!!

The place to be on Sunday morning if you like street markets. This was the longes street market I have seen in a long time. Never a boring moment as it has great variety from antiques, arts and crafts to music and life tango performances. A bit hard to find a place for lunch on Plaza Derrego, so don't get there too late.

Beautiful. What a lovely area. Lots of narrow cobbled streets and buildings with lovely balconies. Could spends days just wandering the streets but plenty of other attractions to see in this area also.

A collection of all walks of life and all works of products. That day, we walk from the lanes from the pink house all the way to San Telmo. Someone told me that because of a festival day, thus there is an extension from the pink house to San Telmo, took us hours to complete the San Telmo walk. We found a lot of interesting stalls selling different items. Then, there were a BBQ joint, look like someone's huge front yard or a huge empty space outside of a garage, on the way. We had our lunch there, good quality when comparing to the price. A must go on Sunday only.

Lively SUNDAY MORNİNG. We really enjoyed our stroll in San Thelmo. The antique shops, the artist stalls, the music, the people they were all lively,fun,exciting. We even waited in the line to have our pictures with MAFALDA at the corner of Chile and Defensa. There is a lovely bistro called PETANQUE ,we had lunch there and enjoyed every moment. A must to see place if you are in Buenos Aires on a Sunday.

Hip neighborhood, full of character. I love San Telmo. Lots of trendy shops and restaurants, fun graffiti art, and some cool antique/vintage shops. Make sure to check out Antiguo Mercado de San Telmo while you're here...a hidden gem!

Best place to be at on Sundays! . If you are in BA over the weekend, do plan to check out San Telmo market and the main square. The locals will be there from 5pm to 10pm showing off their tango moves and you are welcome to join in! It's free and lotsa of fun.

Vibrant sunday markets. Walking the length of defensa through the array of market stalls is wonderful - with music on most street corners, lots of interesting ships and cafes.The antiques stalls are interesting but the gem for me was the antiques shop on the corner of plaza dorrego that has a myriad of wonderful treasures, including a huge collection of hats in their basement.

A place where the love for Tango and Shopping come together. On Sundays there is live music and locals dance Tango and Milonga in the square of San Telmo. Plus, there are many places to purchase several items, including: Tango shoes, jewelry, antiques, and artwork. Take plenty of money because you'll want to buy everything!

Flea Market. Sundays are days to visit to browse through flea markets set up in the narrow lanes. You can find all kinds of stuff having antique value or exotic/wierdness value. Music by traditional musicians, people showing off tango moves...all of that!

San Telmo is good to visit on a Sunday morning. It is good to visit in the morning before museums open. It like a new and old street fair. Cafes are open so you can have a cup of coffee, breakfast and do some people watching and listen to music. There are also tango dancers to watch. The San Telmo church is open.

Impossible don't go. San Telmo is wonderful,be prepared to walk,because you will discover little and big places full of history.All the neighborhood is nice,but the best place is the square full of antiques shops.the best day to go is Sunday morning because the are a antique fair super interesting.I recommend to go and take a lunch in any good restaurants and good beer and peanuts.

Great Neighborhood! You can't go wrong on the Sunday market!. Bohemian neighborhood full of eclectic music, cool stuff to buy, neat things to look at. During the Sunday market you will see a ton of live acts. Bring spare change and take your time meandering through all the market stalls. I bought a belt, a doll, and two musical instruments.

Go there on Sunday. The San Telmo street fair is perfect for Sunday, when they have a fantastic street fair. Interesting and varied booths selling all kinds of arts, crafts and antiques. Sit along one of the surrounding avenues, get some Sangria, and enjoy the people watching.

Not just tat!!!. I managed to convince my other half that this was more than just a shopping trip....and then it really was!!!! Miles upon miles, blocks and blocks of art, music, stalls, shops, antiques, snacks....we set out to just have a look at a couple of blocks and ended up walking the full length of the market...and back again. Stop off at Coffee Town in the heart of the fruit and veg market for own-roast deliciousness - and just explore explore explore. We walked away with bags of christmas presents and a lovely leather jacket at an amazing price. Felt very safe, but we had taken recommendations to leave all jewellery and nice handbags at home, which I think was the right idea. Go go go.

Violently Mugged broad daylight next to street market .
