First time 30 years, 1:20 pm afternoon next to the Sunday market on the main avenue independencia went to ATM at Citi bank, at traffic light ran over by motorbike one then jumped off and hit, pulled off my watch ( a anniversary gift ) drove off Had witnesses but no ID or number plate everyone said a waste of time to report to police take 4 hours plus for no result, nobody cares of these crimes because so so common Even in broad daylight it's totally unsafe

A part of Old Buenos AIres. No place like it. There were side by side vendors on both sides of the street for blocks and blocks. Anything you can imagine. Lots of street food, music and dancing. In the Defense Square were booths of antiques dealers. Lots of cafes and stores along Defensa too. If you are in Buenos Aires, you must take Sunday and go to San Telmo
Nice place to hang at weekends. Lots of people at the bars and at the free market, overall nice, no more.Nice shopping mall and a visit at the cemetary might be interesting.

A must do.... This was my favourite area to just walk around and experience the atmosphere. Around every corner is a different kind of street art and the market on a Sunday is fantastic. Very much has the feel of portobello market in London. Would highly recommend!

13 blocks of street vendors on Sundays. Defensa Street hosts this amazing street fair on Sundays. If you can't find it there you probably can't find it anywhere. We found the electrical adapters we needed amid all of trinkets and handmade clothing. There are antiques and junk, art and not so art, lots of leather and wood carvings. We will go again.

The oldest Barrio or neighbourhood of Buenos Airs is full of fun!. On a long walk through the city we eventually reached this trendy, touristy, Bohemian, and with a general mixture of street traders and musicians in this part of Buenos Aires. Yes, we were there on a Sunday, market day, with all its array of artisan goods some excellent some trashy. The streets are lined with cafes, tango parlous and antique shops. The choice was overwhelming so we just walked along soaking up the atmosphere and minding our money pouches for dear life! We came upon a square and enjoyed an outdoor display of tango dancing which was a joy! As it was so hot on the day we were there we went into a lovely authentic café where we enjoyed a coffee and shared a lovely chocolate mousse.This part of BA needs to be on our list of "must sees" as we thoroughly enjoyed it!
Awesome and exciting. San Telmo is awesome and exciting, especially at night. hundreds of people on the street, bright lights and colors. Plenty of good places to eat and things to buy.

Scary Shopping District of Buenos Aires. Our hotel recommended San Telmo as a nice area for shopping in Buenos Aires. My wife and I went to San Telmo based upon the recommendation and at first we were excited to see many varieties of shops featuring work by local artisans. However, we left quickly because we did not feel safe walking the streets there. I also reviewed the Recoleta and Palermo sections of Buenos Aires and I do not recommend Buenos Aires for tourists at this time.
Great atmosphere and worth visiting. Really nice neighborhood with great atmosphere and street markets. I liked the coffee shop in Durando square

The best neighborhood!. We visit San Telmo when we were on a tour, and we all loved it! Old cafes and bars, the market was really nice and there are ! We liked the Lezama Square a lot as well! Dont miss it!
Fabulous atmosphere. Really enjoyable market but fantastic to see the tango dancers on the street in the main square and beautiful to hear the classical guitarists. Just nice for a wander round

San Telmo. We had a wonderful time visiting San Telmo. It is incredible to see so many artists in one location. It gets very crowded so have a plan on where to meet if and when you get separated. The live music was very exciting. We experienced a special treat when we decided to stop and take a break and we popped into a restaurant called Sagardi. It was on one of the side streets. It was fabulous! The goods were many and varied from very reasonable to relatively expensive. It is great for antique shopping as well. Truly fun for everyone.

Must walk here. It was so nice to walk here, there was live tango (free) at weekends, nice walking place without cars also at weekends, and there is a long market at Saturday's on Defense av. Worth to see it!!!!!

It's ok. I was stayed in San telmo Aries so it's ok nothing interesting in this place but there are many restaurant and just be careful when you walking at night and generally bunes airs safe to walking at the night and don't worry too much

Sunday in San Telmo. The streets are closed to autos and the shops all come out into the streets and sidewalks, along with musicians and the restaurants and cafes . You can browse to your hearts content over a massive array of antiques, junk, old music, furniture, artifacts and sometimes a real treasure. During the week it is a charming neighborhood but weekends with the feria are delightful.

the perfect market . if you love to walk around and shopping that is the perfect place...! also if most of the stuff is old and you don't have any space at home...! you will find also so many street artist with new created stuff....! perfect place to spend a sunday in buenos aires...!

Antique and arts street market. Great locale.
Sunday only market on the streets if St Telmo district. We found coins, antique tins; estate jewellery, and dropped a few pesos.
Great walking and lots of cafes and bars to relax in.

The coolest Suburb in Buenos Aires. a stunning area, with lots of stories, restaurants, bars, cafes, tango, arts (fare on the weekend), antiques and incredible atmosphere that catches the essence of the city in the finest way

Great walking historic area of the city!. The best day is to visit the fair on Sunday. You will have hundred of vendors along the cobblestone streets of San Telmo. Old cafes, parrillas, tango dancers and musicians bring these area to life!
Ok...it's a show but well worth the trip. My husband is going to enjoy forever the few coins he spent to have his picture taken with the tango girl on the street. A must see while in B.A.

Great Sunday market! Full of color plus all sorts of goodies & music!. Don't get there before 11---enjoy all the stalls, music, tourist treasures and knifes, furniture, antiques! A delight...don't hesitate to go into shops there are some real treasures too! Sagrada for tapas and vino is a must! Divine tapas, wine, ambiance....

Very Enjoyable Sunday Afternoon. This is a very colorful and historic area. There were so many interesting things to see and buy. I also felt very safe walking around. Beware of dog droppings... Humans also don't seem to mind peeing in the streets, so there were some interesting smells.
Nevertheless, I enjoyed my meanderings there. Check out the tango in the park.

a stroll in the city. the square and surrounding streets offer a wide variety of sights, enough to please almost any taste. The weekend is the busiest and most crowded, with an active flea market in the square

Beautiful.. I spent 3 weeks in BA and visited San Telmo several times. It's quaint cobbled streets, colourful houses, vintage shops and cosy cafes make it such a relaxing place to be.On Sunday they have the markets which is a must see. Hundreds of stalls line the streets selling everything you can think of but be warned, it can be quite busy.

San Telmo Feria. SanTelmo has a antiques and crafts fair along Defensa and anchored by Plaza Dorrega on Sundays. A lot of fun, but bring your negotiating skills as there a very few prices posted and I got the impression that bargaining was the order of the day. Along Defensa was a good place for picking up some souvenirs. Plaza Dorrega had some really good music when we first got there, and then it changed into a number of couples sequentially showing off their tango skills, though I'm not sure anyone was crowned a winner. All in all a great place to spend a few hours on a Sunday afternoon.

Santelmo--from Popes to Potpourri. The funky Santelmo neighborhood of Buenos Aires can now boast that it is home to Pope Francis. Capella San Roque was his home church. But since 1897, Santelmo has been home to the oldest flea market in Argentina, Mercado Santelmo. When we first went there in 2005 it resembled a square block of national attic--selling everything from old espresso machines to 1950s movie posters to anvils and blacksmith tools to wonderfully crafted facons, the traditional sheath knives of the gauchos. When we last visited in 2013 we found that many of the spaces have now been taken over by contemporary clothing and souvenir shops (GENUINE Argentine crafts made in China), but there are still enough of the traditional tiendas del Mercado to make it a worthwhile visit.
Best area of BA. San Telmo is the best area in all of Buenos Aires. There's heaps to do, with lots of restaurants and bars as well as markets and little stores. Stay here if you can!

Thriving Sunday market. We went on market day [Sunday] when most tourists tend to visit and it was mobbed with people.One end has very good hand made items for sale but the other end, closer to the main square, has much cheaper and tattier items.We returned two weeks later on a weekday and found the whole experience much more pleasant as a 'shopping' street

A Sunday stroll at the plaza Dorrega. This Sunday morning we were wandering around the famous antique market at San Telmo. It stretches several streets and the Plaza. It looks like a tourist trap. It is, but surprisingly also still very interesting. Good for a few hours walking around, watch, touch all the stuff. Good in glassware, and silverware. In the several shops you will find additional articles. Drink a cup of coffee, having lunch and enjoy.
Great area to wander around in. We walked over to this area several times, and there was always something going on - live music, tango dances in the plaza, people selling goods at an open air market.
Lively Sunday markets. We have wandered through San Telmo several times and live the bohemian feel of the neighborhood. The Sunday markets are lively and fun.

Festival of San Telmo. I happened to be there on the Festival de San Telmo. I walked down Defensa St. It was lined with craft booths for miles of blocks! Amazing. And then the antique shops. Unfortunately, I could not carry these back to the U.S. with me, but it was quite interesting. Also, the Tango dancing during the Festival was wonderful. So beautiful! Don't forget to eat lunch at DefensEvil. It is a Parillo with a wonderful grill. They were so kind to make me a salt-free lunch.
The East Village of Buenos Aires. Close to the centro, accessible by bus, subway and taxi, the Sunday Crafts fair is a must see for any visitor and popular with locals.
Traditional fair. The most amazing place to know the culture and to buy traditional things such as alpagartas, fernet and souvenirs. Definitely a place not to miss!

Excellent Sunday market. If you're lucky enough to be in BA on a Sunday then this market is not to be missed. It goes for miles great variety of items. Starts around 10am til late early evening - then market stalls gets packed away and you can have dinner at San Telmo square or lots of bars reataurants around - great fun and some Tango too!

Do not miss a visit to the oldest part of Buenos Aires. An amazing opportunity to step back in history by wandering through the maze of narrow streets, enjoying the local food, shopping at the old mercado for antiques, meats, cheeses in an amazing building.
Go on Sunday!. The neighborhood is very busy and fun! Lots of artists, singers, music and tango shows. Very recommended, maybe the best experience we had in BA in a week.

Good Sunday Tour in Buenos Aires. Sundays in San Telmo is a good way to experience Buenos Aires on the weekend. Street vendors, music and shops along the streets of San Telmo. About a $5 USD taxi ride from Recoleta. Very crowded so take caution of personal belongings - cell phones / purses. We did not experience any issues. As in any big city, self awareness and confidence is required.

the most bohemiam neighborhood of Buenos Aires. Buenos Aires was founded on the Parque Lezama, and from there the defensa streets expands itself all the way to Plaza de Mayo. In those streets, 450 years of history are displayed on the street. Great place to know the old Buenos Aires.Sunday mornings are great.

oldest neighborhood in BA. must see. Must spend a few hours walking through this historic and trendy neighborhood. art galleries, cafes(Bar El federal stop a must). Go on Sunday when the Plaza dorrego area and streets are transformed into a huge artisan and street fair with streete performers doing the tango with whomever will dance with them.

Loved this place. This is a cute little neighborhood, filled with little shops accessible by cabs or public transportation. Really loved the tango dancers outside that made the cobblestone neighborhood really seem like we were back in time.
Must visit . Different feel to the other streets in buenos aires. Centred on a small square with tango dancing. Nice cafes around.
Enchanting flea market. The plaza features all kind of local art, paintings, artefacts, music, tangoIt is a kind of showcase of real Argentinian urban culture

Fun market on the weekend. This is a maze of street vendors and artists selling some very interesting and unusual items at reasonable prices. There are also antique shops and galleries along the way as well with higher priced items. Great outing on the weekend.

Buenos Aires at its best!. San Telmo is my favorite place to go when visiting Buenos Aires. The San Telmo plaza is filled with local art designers and antique collectors over the weekend. San Telmo has tons of very traditional restaurant and the food could not be any better. Tango dancers on the streets perform just for tips and it makes the whole experience even better. It's just delightful to walk around watching the dancers and listening to some good tango music. If you're looking for a great and typical Buenos Aires experience. San Telmo is the place to go!!!
Super charming. Love San Telmo, from nice antic market to tango on the street to great food and bars.wish they renovate more buildings! Fast.
Cute neighbourhood. Nice and safe neighbourhood with lots of nice restaurants and antique shops. There's also a big antiques market.

Fun. Review about the Sunday fair - Bring cash, and dollars will go a long way, as they will provide you with a much better conversion rate than you would get through your ATM machine. There is a lot to see, and I do recommend it. Live music is always happening, and a street tango show happens right in the middle of the plaza. Beautiful to see. If you love antiques, this is a treasure of a place. I just like different and unique jewelry and pieces of art, and I found both kinds to bring back home. You can also find inexperience nice souvenirs. If you can, try to find Fulco, a beautiful stand in the middle of the plaza – his stand was very close to the tango area when we visited. Mr. Fulco's art literally stands out through the box-like frame barely containing each piece. Parts of the scenery and characters jump forward in a combination of shadow box and diorama techniques. The vibrant colors of each scene and palpable personality bestowed upon each figure within not only contribute to the depth. They draw each viewer into the colorful details including Fulco's signature "kioscos" or newsstands, which appear in many of his works.
Great part of the city. Fun place to wander around ... lots of interesting people and places to see. Take the subway for the whole experience.
I love markets :) . Nice market, a snapshot of Buenos Aires hustle bustle, but gets a bit overwhelming if you spend all day!

Wonderful neighborhood for those used to an urban environment and who like small unique restaurants and bars. We live in a very urban area of Denver (So Broadway zone) so are used to the occasional sketchy person at all hours of the day. San Telmo was no worse, for those that have heard bad reports. I felt safe staying there for the four days of our stay and we absolutely LOVED walking around, all the wonderful restaurants, coffee houses and bars. The people were fantastic and the Sunday market was incredible, even in the rain, especially with the music, unique vendors, and the conversion of a parking lot into Parilla for choripan sandwiches. DELICIOUS and CHEAP! Highly recommend the neighborhood. There is an inside market where the best coffee/espresso of our two week trip was served, and that market is great on weekdays and the weekend, including in the rain.

Fun Area. We could not make on a Sunday for the famous Sunday market but even Saturday was fun. We went to the main square and walked down La Defense and had a good time with trendy little shops, etc. One of the original areas of BA, so well worth a visit.

Great location. We stayed in San Telmo at the Telmho Hotel boutique. We loved the area and the convenience to downtown. Two poor meals on the Darrango plaza. Lots of other options. The Sunday market is amazing. It fills the plaza and about 20 blocks along the surrounding streets. It starts about 11am.

A Sunday in San Telmo. Easily accessed by metro (stop Independencia) and then a few blocks east through the charming streets of San Telmo. we went on a Sunday shopped the endless markets looking for treasures and souvenirs, and then had lunch...nice relaxing day

Historic neighbourhood. One of the oldest neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires. The streets, houses and squares reveal their history. You can buy handcraft made pieces over the weekends on the market or antiques of excellent quality in the stores over Defensa street. There are many restaurants and bars on this neighbourhood. It's a must visit in Buenos Aires.

San Telmo seems a bit sad these days, but still worth a visit. Worth a visit, but it is very touristy and a bit neglected. However, there are some nice little shops for clothes and gifts, a great artists shop, and at least one lovely old bar that isn't too touristy. There are better flea markets, and the parillas which used to be so good are now a bit scuzzy and definitely aimed at tourists. But worth a wander. Actually we prefer it when it's quieter - hoardes of tourists descend on this place at weekends. But it is like Camden or Portobello in London - still worth doing and you will see a lot of locals there too. Easy to get to from the Cathedral subte, and definitely worth a wander up Defensa. It is part of the "must see" tourist route, and worth a look, but don't devote too much time to it as there are nicer areas.

A Sunday must!. Love going to San Telmo on Sunday- the day of the outdoor fair. All the little shops and antique stores are open as well as vendors , crafters, jewelry etc. Have bought several well priced items there before.
Sunday attraction. San Telmo offers beautiful antique shops with unbelievable items ( open daily ) and additionally - on Sunday - flea market. Great place to visit. Recommended.

Miss the tango dancers. Some years ago, there was a great number of tango groups and dancers there, did not happened this time.
Interesting anyway, but a lot of people walking around the Plaza do Rego.
As a "first time" visit in Buenos Aires, it is a must.
Otherwise, I'd enjoyed a cup of coffee and quiet place in Palermo with my kids.

Take a step back in time and history. San Telmo has cobblestone streets,tango parlors,street cafe's and awesome weekend markets. Getting there is kind of expensive,but after you settle in its all pretty affordable. Probably 50/50 on english,take a spanish book to order food,most menus are all spanish. People are friendly and try to help you as much as they can,can't wait to go back.

Culture Explosion!. I absolutely fell in love with San Telmo and Buenos Aires in general. Such a cool spot especially on SUNDAYS. Why? There is an open air market that stretches forever! food everywhere, people dancing, music playing. Did i mention food everywhere? Grab a beer or some "MATE" ( local tea)I have a video on youtube of my trip to Buenos Aires on You Tube. Search under J Lito Diaz and check it out under "travel'.Ask me any questions about San Telmo or Buenos Aires ;)

Check out the weekend festival! . I'm not sure if it happens every weekend or just at certain times during the year, but the weekend street festival in this neighborhood is incredible. There are so many cool locally made products for sale. There's also some touristy junk but it's still a very cool experience. The market stretches for miles. I went on a Sunday and didn't finish the entire market due to time constraints. I'd like to spend more time there next trip!

The romantic and behemian side of Buenos Aires. JUst like any other huge city, also Buenos Aires has to be visited area-by-area, and the best day to visit the San Telmo borough is Sunday because of its weekly street marked allong calle defensa. On Sundays, this otherwise ordinary 2-mile long avenue that stretches from Plaza de Mayo right into the heart of San Telmo becomes one of the loveliest street markets you can imagine, both because of the bohemian atmosphere of San Telmo and because of the "different" stuff sold along the alley. Stands of souvenirs, antiques, crafts and clothes alternate each other in a lively environment, interrupted quite frecuentòly by live music and tango exhibitions. The best example is an 80-year-old couple who perform the world famous dance while some younger guy plays the live music. The borough is packed with restaurants, pubs, bars, souvenir and atique stores at every corner; and if you plan to stay here for just a day or two then you'll really have a hard time to pick the restaurant where you wanna have lunch or dinner.

Was hoping for more.. We were very interested in the San Telmo Market after reading about it. Unfortunately, it didn't have that really special feel for us. Maybe it was because we went too early in the day. We found out how the locals love the night life and start the day more slowly. We did go around noon and the market was starting to get busy but we were hoping for more local flavour from the artesans. It seemed that a lot of them were selling very similar touristy trinkets.

I want to live here!!! - Burada Yaşamak İstiyorum. This neighborhood is our favorite one. You can feel the retro and old fashioned soul of the district in every corner. All cafes and parillas look like from the previous century, however, you can still enjoy cafes, which are very modern and stylish. There is a very nice combination of old & new in San Telmo. On Sundays, San Telmo bazaar must be your #1 and only destination, and you should loose yourself in the market. Last words, coming from Istanbul, I found this place very similar to Cihangir district in Istanbul. However, San Telmo is bigger and more more beautiful than Cihangir.

Take your time. There are lots of thing to look at. Go with comfortable shoes and take your time. There is a bunch of junk but you can find good stuff too. Pay attention also to the restaurants behind ...sunday´s aren´t the best time to go there but if you have more time in town another visit can be worthit!

Indescribably genius piece of Buenos Aires. The oldest neighbourhood in Buenos Aires and the buildings are amazing. Please, please DO NOT miss this.Bohemian and laid back.Have you ever been to Montmartre in Paris?? That plaza?? Well there's one in San Telmo just like it, but the sounds of Tango let you know immediately where you are. There are Tango shows in the plaza for tips, and you should tip. Also small shops around it selling local art.Walk into any little bar/restaurant and get a panchit con lluvia de papas, with a Quilmes, of course.Don't miss the Feria de San Telmo every Sunday. You won't regret it and will want to go every Sunday, even if you live in Sydney. Believe me.
Interesting area. Nice place to walk around. Lots of local color. Felt safe there.Lots of leather shops and restaurants. Prices were very reasonable by US standards.
Nice "barrio". They have a very nice "feria" in Defensa Street over all San Telmo. Around they have good bars and restaurants.

Bohemian fun. We stayed in this funky neighbourhood for 2 weeks, and loved it. It's laid back, unpretentious and quirky. The old buildings with their wrought iron and wooden window shutters are charming. Each day different shutters would open to reveal interesting shops and eateries. The Sunday market was fun too, if a bit touristy. The highlight being the street tango dancers.

Good way to spend a Sunday. The San Telmo Fair was one of my favorite things. It is easy to access via the Subte. There are lots of different stands selling different kinds of goods. It is definitely a busy place, especially if it is a nice day, but worth a trip.

Can be interesting. Went on a Sunday, very touristic. If you really look you can find interesting stuff to buy or to appreciate. Some of the "galerias" are beautiful on a decadent way. Some musicians playing are actually really good. I stood probably half an hour just listening to Astor Piazzola being played on a guitar.

Such a cool place. We booked a hotel here without any prior knowledge of the area - what a score. Plaza Dorrego holds a very important place in the history of BA and always has something happening including live tango performances. The streets are full of shops that are stacked with character and there is a great old fashioned market where you can buy some odd things. If you love character with a bit of edge and art, this is the place for you.

Fabulous Sunday Fun. We visited the Saint Telmo Sunday market that runs on Defense Street from Plaza de Mayo down towards the Boca area. Very interesting stalls, a good long walk and great to be out with the locals. Take very comfortable shoes as the cobblestone streets will test your feet.

Crowded, articles are ok, but the atmosphere is great ... a Sunday morning walk. If you like loads of people, some handcraft (not really amazing, but nice leather bags) ... walk in Santelmo on a Sunday morning ... if are not intimidated by above description, there is a good chance of you discovering nice bands and hidden coffee shops in the neighboorhood. Whenever in BA, we do spend a morning there. If you want to visit MACBA as a combo, better you check their opening hours first and if there is a exhibit going on ... very frustraded as we could not walk in on our both tries
Visit Sunday. Sunday is the open air flea market that is fun to walk through. A lot of the same kitsch then finish up at the antiques and join the tango milanga.

Sunday Fun in Buenos Aires. I spent a better part of the day at the market in San Telmo. There are literally hundreds of stall vendors selling all kinds of handicrafts and antiques. What fun! This is a great place to pick up interesting gifts to bring back home.

Nice shopping - cheaper vintage shopping than in London or Paris. San Telmo is known as the flea market of Buenos Aires. There is a lot of things you don't need, but there are also great stores if you are looking for styles like Art Deco, Biedermeier, Classicism or Art Nouveau. We should not forget, that during the two World Wars, a lot families from Europe went to Buenos Aires to settle down. During the last depression just a few years ago, a lot of families had to sell off their art, silver, porcelain and jewelry. I found the prices much better than in Europe plus the good dresses ship worldwide...

A very pleasant Sunday afternoon outing. A Sunday afternoon stroll through the antique stalls is interesting, but if the guitar player is there, sit and listen to what should be a wonderful performance. But please protect your valuables from pickpockets.

Ferria . During a month long stay in BA went to the San Telmo ferria on Sunday twice. Great experience even if you don't buy anything- very low key no one in your face pressuring you. Besides the booths there are interesting/funny street performers from musicians to marionettes. Very entertaining!

Treasure in the trash.. It was disappointing to see how they do not have an opportunity to preserve their historic neighborhood properly and cover beautiful ornate walls with graffiti. They do have great steakhouses though where locals like to eat and you will feel real history there.

Beautiful, exciting and great place to see!. I loved this place, and already want to return! The Mafalda statue is a must for pictures. There is great eats, drinks, music and very friendly people. They have souvenirs and walking around the cobblestone streets and architecture is just awesome. The restaurants have great food and the best wine from Mendoza. You cannot miss it!!
Stayed a week. Nice area, Sunday market a must. Interesting buildings and side streets. But, watch out for pick pockets!!!

Exciting and edgy San Telmo. I decided to stay in San Telmo during my 1-week visit of Buenos Aires... and I totally loved it.This part of town, although a bit rough around the edges, is vibrant, alive and exciting: beautiful, creative graffiti adorns many of the city walls; cool little cafes and excellent restaurants are everywhere on the cobbled streets and the Sunday market (Calle Defensa) is fun and alive with atmosphere - not to be missed. The market itself had a wide array of items - some cool and creative, others a bit weird (and dare I say it, ugly!), but it was huge fun to walk around and discover the stalls, see the people and to eventually end up at the market square Plaza Dorrego where there are live 'tango' performances (as part of a marketing exercise from the the tango schools and clubs). Sit at one of the many cafes around the square and have a cold beer while watching the hustle and bustle of the market and the people that come there.It's a great area to hang around or to stay. I enjoyed every minute that I spent in this Bario.
a must in BA. surely one of the nicest places in town, lots of street artists, good cafes and restaurants, lively and beautiful

Sunday Market is a must!. The Sunday Market in San Telmo is an absolute must just for the atmosphere, the crowds and the variety of stalls.Hang onto your bags but don't miss this.Walking shoes a must as the street goes on and on....
Another must.. Long interesting walk...I loved the cobblestones.. just need sensible shoes. Had no problems with personal safety...friends had us worried.

Enjoy the walk. Don't rush.. The open air Street market in San Telmo Defensa street on weekends is worth visiting and takes you from Plaza de Mayo to La Boca. So it can be said that San Telmo is a must between two city's sights. The vendors are the same as any type market.

San Telmo Sunday Fair. is the oldest barrio (neighborhood) of Buenos Aires, Argentina. It is a well-preserved area of the Argentine metropolis and is characterized by its colonial buildings. Cafes, tango parlors and antique shops line the cobblestone streets, which are often filled with artists and dancers.San Telmo's attractions include old churches (e.g. San Pedro Telmo), museums, antique stores and a semi-permanent antique fair (Feria de Antigüedades) in the main public square, Plaza Dorrego. Tango-related activities for both locals and tourists are in the area.

A traffic officer begged me not to go, he said it was full of thieves lol. Sunday morning, still a bit groggy after the 13 hour flight from London we decided to brave the metro and go to the St Telmo street market.Using the metro was easyWe made a pact that after the the warning from the traffic person, of either of us felt uncomfortable then we would abandon our visit . We needn't have worried , although the walk from the metro is a bit run downThe market is huge with antiques, new stuff, some amazing crafts and not a feeling of threat.We enjoyed a nice Biriani at an Indian along the way and walked out onto the Placa Major just in font of the Casa Rosada.The metro back to Palermo couldn't have been easierDidn't take the DSLR, just a small camera and wasn't rude poking camera in people's faces.Would highly recommend this great day out

Well, it's the historic centre after all! . How can you not visit San telmo while visiting Buenos Aires? The open air fair on defensa street on weekends is worth visiting and takes you from Plaza de mayo to la Boca. So , it can be said that San telmo is a must between two city's sights. Plaza Dorrego can be quite lively at night. Beware of dark alleys and showing off, it can be quite hairy...

Bohemian place... great vibe.. This is one of the best places where you could feel that bohemian vibe on the streets. You could find artists selling their paintings, sculptures, and other pieces of art that are worth taking home. Among the artists, you will be finding musicians and bands playing tango, reggae, etc. For you to see all this you must go on a Sunday for the antiquities fair.

San Telmo breathes tango. I was in Buenos Aires for a tango workshop and stayed partially in San Telmo. I found this part of the city not nearly as safe or clean as Palermo Soho. But San Telmo does have an interesting history and if you are there to tango, it is a good place to visit. This part of the city is more casual than other parts, and the restaurants may be a little less expensive. Make sure you have a buddy if you are out on the streets at night. Overall, don’t miss this part of town for at least a visit, or if you like tango this is a must-see visit.

Liveliest place in Buenos Aires. The time to go to this place is Sunday, when there is a huge flea market on Plaza Dorrego, which sells everything imaginable. Much of it, of course, is junque. There is a beautiful Starbuck's on one corner, and there is usually a tango band playing and dancers performing.Lots of attractive open-air cafes around the plaza. Be alert for pickpockets.

lively place wort visiting. Nice and interesting place to visit. Unfortunately you can get harassed by various sellers, waiters etcAvoid going there by taxi as the taxi drivers in Buenos Aires take long unnecessary routes to increase their fare

Sunday flea market is not to be missed. The Sunday flea market in San Telmo is lots of fun. Vendors sell nearly everything and you will enjoy walking by the stalls and seeing all the things for sale. There are also several antique stores and restaurants in the area. Just be careful of your purse/wallet - pickpockets abound! I combined a visit to San Telmo with a tour of the Casa Rosada and time in the Plaza de Mayo. It made for a wonderful Sunday!

Great area to spend time. I stayed in a hostel in this area and did a lot of walking around even at night. I felt very safe and I found restaurants that served the best steak I have ever eaten. The wine was real good also. Markets in this area are worth a look. Within walking distance to lots of places
Good to walk.. There are several antique shops around the neighbourhood. Nice place to walk around and look at the shop displays. Several restaurants too.

A flea market that is a must to see. A fair is set up on weekends and takes several blocks. Is has unique things as a flea market, and lots of artisan work. I have heard so much that I had highe expectations, but is a must to see

Flee market. An opportunity to spend the Sunday strolling, buying local artefacts at a reasonable ( not cheap though ) price
Plenty of restaurants and bars to stop by if one wants to take a rest before strolling farther

Very cool and quirky.. We went here on the recommendation of a friend whilst we were staying in Buenos Aires.
I can only describe it as an Argentinian equivalent of Camden in London. It's teeming with life, street entertainers, bands, tango dancers, market stalls, restaurants, bars and cafe's.
Well, well worth a visit.

the spirit of Buenos Aires. San Telmo is the heart of the old Buenos Aires. it the place where craftsman still have a boutique, where you can go to dance tango in "real" places or go to the sunday market. the place is eveolcing now and prices are rising, touristic places are getting there ( ie strabucks) but the spirit of it it still tehre. go for a beer or for some small shopping at the stalls.

Fascinating, Diverse, Authentic San Telmo. We arrived in Buenos Aires on a Saturday afternoon, so we were lucky enough to get to the famous Sunday open-air market, which pretty much takes over some streets in San Telmo. Live music, street performers from living statues to marionette artists, people walking through selling local treats, and vendors offering almost everything you could think of, from souvenirs and toys to leather shoes and bags. Absolutely crammed with people, but still very enjoyable.
Established street market on Sundays worth a visit.. Perfect Sunday, walk from the south end northwards, and stop at the square for a coffee and soak up the antique market ambience.
Colorful. A very fun place to visit. Vibrant and historic. Try to go on a flea market day. Tango dancers abound.
Best place in Buenos Aires. I loved the atmosphere and the shops in there. Food was amazing! Specially in Cafe Town, in one of the markets.

do go!. In the San Telmo area, there is a great street market on Sundays. It covers street after street with colourful "artisanal" goods. Hand painted shoes, jewellery, leather goods, knitted goods, even antiques, to name a few. All at reasonable prices too. Lots of cafes and restaurants to sit in and soak up the atmosphere. Live shows and musicians too on the streets.Do try a steak sandwich!We drank mate, the local equivalent to tea. An experience though not one I wish to try againBe warned, high risk of pickpockets. Locals will warn you of open bags !! Also not really wheelchair friendly as too many potholes and cobblestones.

Street fair. This is a nice area to visit but the goods for sale at the street fair on Sundays was disappointing. It was pretty much the same old stuff you see at home. There are some very nice antique stores surrounding the fair, but not really worth the long taxi ride from our hotel in Palermo Soho.
Exotic SanTelmo. A hub of very exotic antique stores coupled with cobblestone streets that will delight the senses regardless of season!

Sunday street fair and flea market. Leave the subway (Subte) at Catedral and walk to Defensa street. For about 5 blocks there is an open air street fair every Sunday from 10-5. Most of what you find there is pretty high-quality local crafts. These include hand-made papers, books, leather goods, purses, belts, etc. and various forms of art. There is also quite a bit of "one-of-a-kind" craft work, some of which is transportable on a plane and some not, but all of it pretty much fun to look at--and at very reasonable prices. Together with the neighborhood, it's probably a must see for first timers to Buenos Aires.

Next big thing. Still with a lot to recover in terms of buildings and businesses, but with a lot of potential for expansion and development within artists community and design stores. Please do go on a weekday, crowds on Sunday are unbearable and won't let you enjoy the neighbourhood

Perfect neighborhood for exploring arts/culture in BsAs.. Perfect neighborhood for exploring on a weekend. Cobblestoned sreets, huge crafts and antiques markets (biggest on Sundays), locals doing tango, friendly neighbors, a variety of restaurants, bars and cafes, and boutiques to shop in. Easy walk to many art museums, Plaza de Mayo/Catedral area, subway, etc.

Great way to spend a Sunday!!. This place is awesome on a Sunday. (I haven't been on a Saturday). Start of by going to the Plaza at San Telmo, there are an almost infinite amount of stalls for Antiques, Art, handcrafts, you name it, you'll probably find it there! People from all over gather to sell there wares, and collectibles, I have found old Beatles Albums, Coca Cola Advertising, armor, WWII relics, watches, etc... Its a real maze sometimes, so pay attention to side streets, and shops that are also open. There is Tango dancing on the streets, great food either in Cafes or by Vendors. A great restaurant to go to in that area, is the La Brigada (see my review) it is quaint, very traditional Argentine Steak lHouse, and very good the last time I went..You can walk this whole area stopping to see the different things for sale in the street and literally end back up near Puerto Madero, all the while taking in all the things around you.

Quaint old neighborhood. I found San Telmo much more interesting to walk through than Palermo. The former was more lively during the day, with lots of interesting antique shops and a wonderful market. The market is best on Sunday, but there are plenty of stalls open on other days as well.

San Telmo Sunday market. You can not visit Buenos Aires without stopping by San Telmo on Sunday as the market runs for blocks and blocks down Defensa street. You will not only see antiques galore, but you will hear gifted guitarists, watch tango dancers (a couple in their 70s), puppeteers, stalls of all sorts, leather goods shops, paintings..you name it, it is there. As can be extremely crowded, I would be sure the wallet is in your front pocket, one's handbag zippered and eyes opened... A fun afternoon which ends up at the Pink House (if you start from Defensa and San Juan), the Catherdral and the park.

Old and fancy. You'll love it or hate it. Oldest neighborhood of Buenos Aires, thin stoned streets plenty of historic buildings and antiques shops.You'll love it or hate it ;)Nice to visit during daytime, watch your steps in the night. If you want to go drinking or just walking in the night (after about 2am) do it only around the San Telmo plaza and keep an eye on your stuff all the time.Nice place to visit at least once, otherwise you'll never know if you love it ;)Enjoy!

Cool place to people watch. We walked around this neighborhood on a Sunday. There were tons of markets open including San telmo market. To be honest it's mostly antiques and gets very repetitive. We didn't buy anything but got some cool pictures.

Tango, food, shopping--what else could you ask for?. The Sunday market is the highlight of the week. Shop for handcrafted leather goods to cut crystal stemware. There a lot to see in the outdoor market and the indoor antique malls and shops. A bit more of the local flavor of the area is better seen during the week, not so crowded.

San Thelmo,no problem..... While in BA our hotel were is San Thelmo. You realized it must have been a loveley place,many years ago,althougt,time took its toll in years gon by. The Morena hotel was situated in Moreno Av,close to Defensa Av,and we really enjoyed the Sunday Market on our doorstep. Walking 'uphill' with Morena,you reach Peru Av. Turn right,go straight and you will reach Florida Av,a pedestrian walkway,with lots of shops and the Cambios (money exchange). There is also a Laundry Service nearby(in San Thelmo (A$ 40,for a load,and they do it all!!!). Even though iSan Thelmo looks old and wheary,it is a good,central place to stay,loved it!

Over hyped but beautiful area. Over hyped but beautiful area. The day we went the crowds were too much. Prices have changed since the last time I was there. More expensive...geared to the tourist not locals.
Great Shopping. We stayed in San Telmo for about five days and enjoyed the location. We were near great restaurants and a wonderful street market on the weekend.

San Telmo was lovely!. We were staying in America Del Sur Hostel - great hostel located in San Telmo. Which is such a nice area - beautiful architecture and sunday markets :)Try the street BBQ! Amazing! - these are just pop up BBQs and they are incredible! The best BBQ I have ever had!

San Telmo , believe the hype. Cobbled streets, fantastic market ,shoe shops who will adjust the shoes change the heels put a different style of sole in a day or 2 . Classic architecture and friendly helpful people.Tango and film being made in plaza Dorrigo. Great selections of restaurants in the area....in fact I had the best steak I have ever eaten in my life in a small restaurant in this suburb. A few words of ( argentine style ) Spanish will go a long way. We were warned about walking about at night but felt completely safe when we did . Friendly arty gorgeous . Parisian feel almost with a Latin slant. I love this suburb ! A definite BA must go ..

A nice Walk. A street market that rivals some of the better ones i have been to. Must be a few miles long! Lots going on. that band in the picture is GREAT!!! They can really kick it! I could have watched them all day. Most of the items on sale are sold everywhere in Argentina but you do find the unique ones that make it all worthwhile. Don't forget the blue rate. most restaurants and shops will convert dollars or Euros at almost twice the exchange rate! Enjoy!

Historical Area. San Thelmo is a safer walkable more authentic and less hyped version of La Boca. There is an indoor (historical) market with plenty of fresh fruit & vegetables for reasonable prices. The neighborhood is very pleasant with tree lined streets with old houses, most of them maintained. The Museum of Modern art nearby is not worth the visit.

Magical. We went to the market on Sunday morning. Since we love outdoor markets this was high on our to do list. It didn't let us down. We found the items for sale were either uniquely South American or Argentinian. Local craftsman and antiques, magazines, music all were from the area. We bought several pieces of art and a handmade knife. Some local incense, leather belts. There was street music, and entertainers, and local food. Vendors were informative, helpful and patient. It was a wonderful enchanting way to spend a Sunday. Most markets are not so original but this one is. Walk thru the original Selmo Market, it is full of antiques and great food. We were fully satisfied.

Cheap stuff. Enjoy the ambience, but don't count on finding anything worth buying if you like good quality stuff. I enjoyed the festive air, the street performances, the local color. But most of the stuff on sale were of low quality and poor workmanship. Worth a visit, but wouldn't bother to go back.

Just Beautiful!. I stayed in the Heart of San Telmo, Perfect place to stay although sketchy at night, just be careful when walking through back streets.. The buildings were the highlight of this neighbourhood. Just beautiful! This is the area that made me fall in love with Buenos Aires! Lots of food and entertainment around.. You will not get bored!

Crowded but nice. If you have calm and want to buy things as gifts, you can go there.
But be careful, there's "thief" activities over there...

Excellent neighborhood. Some buildings are old, but it is such a lovely place for a traveller: it is safe (I saw cops every single night), it has very good restaurants, pubs and hotel. You can stay there for a while and have lots of things to do, like visiting San Telmo fair on sundays and it's Market Place where they serve very good "empanadas". Even being a night place, I could sleep very well almost without loud noise. For those who likes to walk, you can go to "Passeo de la historieta" and Puerto Madero easily.

For arts and crafts and incredible food!!!. San Telmo was the best place (event) I visited during my stay in Baires. In fact, I went to San Telmo three different times and the three times the experience was great. The amount of arts and crafts is uncountable and incredible. Better have lots of pesos because here you can find everything you need to take back home. In fact, it was here, in San Telmo where I bought all the presents I needed for my family and friends, as well as for my house. I, in fact, bought the most expensive item here, a painting for my office. What a place!

Sundays in San Telmo. . We lived 5 months in San Telmo. I really loved it. Everybody keeps talking about Palermo, but personally I found ST to be much more interesting and much more fun. Great bars and cafés everywhere. The indoor marketplace, and not mention the Sundays when San Telmo turns into a big market with everything fra souvenirs to food and dancing in the streets. Great place.
Lively. You can find people singing and dancing and on a long stretch of road. Definitely a must for Sunday!

Feria San Telmo should be on you "to go" list if you're in BA on Sunday.. Enjoyed strolling down side streets to see street performers and sellers of many craft type items. We bought a couple of gaucho knives to use for steak knives back home. Good quality for the price of about US$30 each. Main square is mostly antiques that are somewhat overpriced. Since we were so far apart on most of the better (silver) items, I didn't bother to try to bargain. Hat shop on one side of square is worth a visit if you're interested in a hat. Seemed like good quality for the relatively low prices.
Flee market. Street market with many different kind of products !!! A lot of people , I recommend go to the taxi ! Many restaurants in the market
Take your time and enjoy. Take your time and enjoy this nice place. You can "go" to the historic buenos aires, see the tango at street. Good food and drinks. Go by taxi.
Lovely Walk. San Telmo have lots of antiques shops to be seen, you can get lost looking the most extravgant things. Also you can enjoy your walk by watching some street tango.

Lovely Part of Buenos Aires. If I return to Buenos Aires this area would be one of the places I would look to stay in - maybe an apartment if for a week or more. Quite artsy, lots of cafes and restaurants.

huge...huge Market.. Visit on Sunday to see the market that stretches for miles and miles. I think this is the best market in the city with various antiques and artist booths. The market starts at 1000 on Sunday and goes almost all day, but best to arrive at about 1200 as all of the stands will be set up.
The SOHO of Buenos Aires. The SOHO of Buenos Aires, San Telmo is sprawling with cafes, restaurants, bars and all sorts of alternative startups. My favourite area of the city.
Bohemian and lovely. lovely neighborhood with a chic easygoing vibe. great retsurants and cafes and of course doint miss the Sunday market!

Best shopping in Bs As!. The market in San Telmo is a must-see for all tourists. It stretches over a couple of km, with 100's of stalls on each side of a narrow alley. You can get some really nice crafts here (and lots of junk too). Plenty of restaurants and food stalls: my travel partner and I had awesome hotdogs made by an ad-hoc street vendor. Check out all the tango dancing and the bands playing. It is plain awesome, we spent 4-5 hours there. The pink house is at the end, and from there you are close to lots of restaurants, shopping streets, the obelisk etc. in the centre.

Nice handcraft and antiques fair. On Sundays morning the San Telmo Fair is a show of handcraft made by local artisans. They also have wood scent and different kinds of antiques, including silver, crystal, china, and others. It is a long walk to see the whole thing.

Do Not Miss. San Telmo on a Sunday really is something else. The tango bars, the market stalls, the galleries and live music on every corner. The place jumps. The music, everything from American soul and blues, samba, jazz and tango, makes the area jump.A bit touristy but well worth the visit.

One of the coolest Flea Markets in the world. If like me you are a sucker for flea markets, enter San Telmo.Blocks and blocks of colorful offers mixed with street performers and the ever present Tango dancers, San Telmo is a must if you are in Buenos Aires

Fun Day in BA!. Interesting street fair full of vendors, tango, antiques and collectibles. Where else can you find a goat horn wine caddy, antique padlocks, antique jewelry, and beautiful leather....Also, got caught up in the Palm Sunday procession into church, and happy I went.

San Telmo, best place in town. An Awesome place, everyday of the week. This is a place where hand made art is next to very unique antiques. I got to talk to the artists, most are travelers trying to get money to move to their next step and a lawyer turn out to be a jeweler. The antique market is very special by itself. Ignore the tourists, enjoy the tango, the great food; admire what people sell. It is colorful and awesome

color color color. San telmo is an amazing area of culture, great food and art. La boca is nearby and a must see, it is full of color and fun people watching. Take a cab, no really we guffawed the locals when they said we could not walk there, both times we were almost mugged , so yep stupid americans. When they say it is dangerous they are not kidding. However, be smart , hide your valuables and enjoy the culture. I have been to BA four times and want to go there everytime.

Not worth the time. There is really nothing to see or shop at San Telmo. All you see are tourists.There are some old buildings. The goods are not made locally. There are some good restaurants around. The tango dancers are tired and overaged.
Very touristy. It was great to discover this area after taking the Subte and walking through the neighbourhood but the market and the 'Argentinian' experience seemed quite forced.

The real Buenos Aires. The perfect place to meet the local traditions and art and the best tango dancers too! At weekends the market gets full of crafts, antiques, painters and musicians.There are also many good antiques shops. Take your time to walk around and have a nice meal while you enjoy the real Buenos Aires.

Many good places to eat and drink. San Telmo is the barrio that lies six blocks from Plaza de Mayo, bounded to the north and south by the Microcentro and La Boca, and to the east and west by Puerto Madero and Avenida 9 de Julio. It’s the oldest barrio in Buenos Aires.
bazar. Please do not forget to visit this place special on Sunday,during the day a lot of local peoples sold traditional products very nice and very cheap like a bazaar.

Great place to stay and visit. We booked our accommodation here based on others views of it being safe & we found it a great place to stay. We were able to walk around at night, lots of great restaurants, close to bus& train and great markets on a sunday.

Too fun! Very diverse!. Just stroll and meet the people too and do NOT miss the artisans nor the private tour in Englisg (12, 1:00, 2:00 only - ring bell) of Zanjon de Granados, a private museum! It is $15 which helps to fund it a bit and it is fantastic! About an hour but well worth it and you won't forget it. Extremely professional, educational and interesting. The plaza is very fun too- best on weekends but any day good. As in most of BA, little happens before 11:00 small.

Cannot visit Buenos Aires without San Telmo. The place to go to visit the local art and artisans. Filled with culture, ideas, music and the people of Argentina. Words do not describe the events of the day, but no one is ever disappointed. You never know when the music comes one, dances start and those selling their wears will tell you their story. Sit for a coffee, go for a drink, either way, you will enjoy your time.

Lovely area. This is a lovely area to walk around. If you go here be sure to stop in for a coffee in Coffee Town. Really nice little coffee hut in the middle of the market. It also featured in the movie "Focus" with Will Smith and Margot Robbie.

A uniquely Sunday option. If you are in B.A. on a Sunday, you will probably be advised by someone to visit San Telmo. The historic neighborhood has tons of antique shops lining the streets as permanent businesses, but on Sunday the streets are also filled with vendor stands for blocks and blocks. In peak season you will navigate the pedestrian-only blocks moving shoulder to shoulder nearly the entire time. Pick-pockets are a known risk so plan accordingly. Also be aware that pricing may be variable. If something isn't marked with pricing, there's a good chance that the price will depend on how much of a tourist you seem to be (higher prices). Even if you don't want to buy anything, it's worth a visit to view the street performers and take in the unique flavor of this cobblestoned neighborhood.

Art, past, trends, culture and 'real people' inside. San Telmo 'oldish' appearance hides such an "underground" whose famous and traditional Fair is just the tip of the iceberg. And I am sorry, you are not allowed to get in touch with it through the web. It is demanded: you have to go there on a Sunday (Fair). Take your time. Open your eyes. Surrender to the antiques, to the different, to the old, to the trends you may not know (perhaps San Telmo is a 'planet' you not know already), to the Public Market, to the street artists, in a word: to a 'sui generis' world that drills the heart of the lovely Buenos Aires.
Set aside an entire week-end day to see this street market. Handcrafted items galore!! One of the most interesting places we visited during our stay in Buenos Aires

You like Antiques you must visit San Telmo.. One of the oldest áreas of Buenos Aires.Old buildings, mixed with new.Boutique hotels, quaint bars and old traditional bars.Street booths with antiques or great shops of antiques.musicians in the Street...Great way to spend a Sunday afternoon in buenos Aires.Be careful with your belongings...

From N.Y. to San Telmo. Although American, from N:Y. I chose to live in San Telmo. I use to visit my family,specially my Grandma Helena until I grew up and decided to make this place my home. I hope you like it, feel its magic like I do. Maybe you are also driven to stay. You never know...

Sunday fun. On Sunday's this place comes alive with antique stalls and arts and crafts. I bought several very unique neck scarves that always draw compliments and the inevitable "where did you get THAT". Tango dancers abound...and music too. We loved our several hours of cruising the stalls and enjoying the atmosphere.

Great trendy developing neighborhood. We had a great time visiting the antique shops in this area. If we could do our trip over we'd stay in San Telmo. It's nice with plentiful restaurants and close to downtown. Skip staying way out in Palermo/Recoleta and stay here instead!
One of the most fascinating districts of Buenos Aires. San Telmo is pure genuine old bohemian experience,cafes,old houses,cobblestone streets,i felt enamored with this place,a must go experience.

san telmo. the san telmo area is fun. lots of antique shops. a small square towards the end of defensa. fun night life without the working girls of recoleta. good restaurants, Des Nival on defensa and Don Ernesto's on carlos calvo. small little shops selling the best steak sandwiches in the world, get one right off the sidewalk while you are walking along antique shopping. and you have to go to the Sedonna Bar on the corner of defensa and chile, might be the oldest bar in Buenos Aires.
Nice place to visit on Sundays. San Telmo has its traditional fair on Sundays. There you can find anything to shop and is a good excuse to walk while enjoying the different stands.

Block your Sunday for that!. This open air market is full of awesome things to see. I saw people making great music, great food, funny things and many other great things to do. I believe it only happens on Sundays so make sure you reserve this day for San Telmo!

Fascinating glimpse into another time. San Telmo strikes me as something like an old woman who used to be wealthy, but has fallen on hard times. Streets are often lined with Belle Époque buildings which must have been the height of fashion, but long decades of neglect have left them in I'll repair. Despite this they still have charm and the antique stores along Defensa hold many of their former treasures for sale. The Feria de San Telmo on Defensa is a great chance to see artisan crafts, tourist souvenirs and listen to a wide variety of live music. People watching is as much fun as the goods and food along the way.
A must be in Buenos Aires. it's one of the classical in Buenos Aires. i would visit there not in the weekends - then you'll taste the real neighborhood experience

Weekends on San Telmo. Sunday is the day visit Plaza Defensa flee market in San Telmo, you will find a lot of stores and booths on the street. I you are looking for antiques can visit around every day and avoid all turist and local people.
Weekend flea market. A lot of options for cheap and authentic Argentine goods. Very beautiful and colorful. Try street food here.

Trio to see San Telmo. San Telmo is an interesting flea market, with many artisans as well as traders selling old stuff. We enjoyed strolling around this place, only takes a couple of hours and is not that far from the Presidents Palace

relieve Buenos Aires's colonial life. With its old houses and charming small and dirty streets, Sundays are the best days to see a permanent street show with its popular market, crowded streets, tango dancers, acrobats, beggarsThis area is full of small bars and restaurants where you can stop for a drink or a meal.You can plan 2-3 hours there.

A nice area to spend the weekend. This is the old part of Buenos Aires and is a nice area to spend a day. The artisan's market on Sunday 's is very lively and interesting . There is a subway station about six blocks from the square. Interesting local food is also available .

Great street fair every Sunday!. Love love love the San Telmo street fair. It's the largest street fair I've ever seen, everything from arts and crafts, jewelry to antiques. It's a must see and do on a Sunday afternoon!

Loved this place!. Small streets lined with interesting shops and restaurants are most entertaining in San Telmo. I believe working people live here and it is a good chance to see what Buenos Aires is all about on a normal day. The people were friendly and helpful in every way.

Sunday mornings and early afternoons in San Telmo. If you visit Buenos Aires city, you must go to San Telmo neighborhood on a Sunday. You can start by having a continental breakfast in one of the old and traditional coffee shops around San Telmo Square. Then go for a walk around the neighborhood where you'll see very old buildings, some of them almost 200 years old, churches and of course cobble stone streets. You can have lunch in a traditional restaurant and then watch people in the square and corners dancing tango, singing tango, painters working in the street. A lovely atmosphere. The shows are for free. You'll love San Telmo, a must in Buenos Aires.

Antiques Market on Sundays with Lively Atmosphere. We visited this market at Sunday lunch-time, early afternoon and there were lots of stalls with Antiques and hand-made crafts. There were some interesting stall holders with a lot of Art Deco styles of glass and an interesting Soda Bottle Stall! We were worried about pick-pockets so kept an eye on our bags, were extra vigilant. There are a couple of small 'arcades' at the beginning of the market 'La Defense' which have wonderful tiles/old architecture - no photos are allowed, but it's worth popping in to view. The atmosphere was very charming with live music and local artists, definitely worth a visit - we combined the visit with La Boca-Caminita.
Bohemian neighbourhood of BA. Rented an apartment in San Telmo for three months. San Telmo is perfect if you like little independent coffe shops, art galleries, antique shops etc.

Sunday is the best day of the week to visit. The Sunday market offers so much to see, and it's worth the visit to walk around the neighborhood. The architecture is amazing, but the neighborhood needs a lot of restoration. Clearly the economic set back has hurt the city.There are many restaurants, antique shops and interesting side streets. We went during the week this visit and were a little disappointed. We missed the Sunday flea market at the energy of the Sunday experience.

Fun to walk. Nice area for a walk on a sunny day. Lots of antique shops etc. If you don't like crowds, don't go on a Sunday. On the other days, it's more relaxed. Prices to buy something are high as they know you're a tourist but hey, look for something you really want and try to negotiate.

Awesome old school barrio. Very cool neighborhood in central BA with a ton of character. We stayed in the San Telmo area for 4 days and couldn't get enough, the restaurants are great, the cobblestone streets are classic and the people are very nice. Would definitely recommend staying in this area as your home base to see the rest of the city, an easy walk to Microcenter, Retiro and Recoleta and less than a $10 cab ride to La Boca.

Visit it on Sunday. San Telmo on a Sunday is a great way to experience Buenos Aires and it's inhabitants. There are street vendors selling all kinds of stuff, tango dancers and musicians playing. It gets quite crowded so it's good to keep your wallet and possessions close by.

Antiques and street fairs!!. This neighborhood hosts a weekly street market up Defensa Ave on Sunday morning which has a full range of local crafts, flea market stalls and mid priced collectibles lining the sidewalks in front of the permanent storefronts selling good antiques. It's a long walk from San Telmo to Plaza de Mayo. Along the way are some good stops for lunch. We opted for a delicious Indian Restaurant. And there is a very interesting Museum called 'El Zanjon' in a 1500's Spanish Mansion which was restored along with the tunnels beneath it. A guide will take you through and explain it's history from wealthy landowner, cholera epidemic to tenement etc. This Museum is not obvious so research the address before heading to San Telmo!

Nice miday walk. There is not much to see in San Telmo but with a guide to show you around you can find very nice and different places to visit. The market, the comic street with Argentinian characters as Mafalda which I love. Antique stores and plenty of artisans and artists selling their good. Don't miss the Cofffee Town place in the middle of the market owned by an awarded barista.

Great Sunday Market!. After arriving from the U.S. on an overnight flight, we decided to go the Sunday market / fair in San Telmo. The streets are closed from Plaza Dorrego to Plaza de Mayo down 10 blocks of Defensa street with temporary booths lining the streets (plus Plaza Dorrego is full of booths). We started at Plaza de Mayo, but you could start anywhere along the route (and I kind of wish we had started at Plaza Dorrego). There were lots of Argentinian crafts, art, handiwork, food...as well as antiques which is what I was looking for. They also had street performers and a couple performing the Tango. There is also a good weekend market in Recoleta - it's smaller but has more arts and crafts (we did that one the following Saturday). We had 3 people in our group...so felt safe walking to the Galerias Pacifico (only place to convert cash on a Sunday), then to the Plaza de Mayo and Plaza Dorrego...and back to the Hilton in Puerto Madero. This was a great walk...but long (probably 7-8 miles total). You could also take taxi's. Either way, be sure to wear comfortable shoes!
Perfect area to stay. We stayed in the area of BA. we always felt safe in this part of the city, no problems at all. The area is also very beautiful and it's in a great location to find anything

Not Impressed. Let me preface by saying this is our 5th staycation in BA for 2-3 months at a time. In 2008 we DID come down here on a Sunday........and perhaps once again in 2012.We actually took the bus to San Telmo yesterday to go to the BA Museum of Contemporary Art on San Juan Avenue. Due to the elections, the museum was closed.SO......starting at San Juan and Defensa at around 4:30 PM.....we did the "Defensa Walk". The streets were more than congested: LOTS of people.........the middle of the street was an accident waiting to happen: SO MUCH cracking, you really had to watch your step or break an ankle.........and don't forget the fresh dog poop!........and except for a few stands with quality leather purses....the handcraft was underwhelming.And yes....there were lots of "antique" stands......for locals? tourists?There were some musicians on the street......THE best group being Negra Candela at San Juan and Defensa. By the time we reached Defensa and Belgrano we had enough......walked down the hill....and picked up a #130 on Paseo Colon back to our ap't.In retrospect......if you are a tourist with little time.......go to Recoleta on a Saturday or Sunday. IMHO a much better experience. The BEST of all: FERIA MATADEROS: much more authentic. Actually, wandering Defensa and surrounding streets is much more satisfying on a Thursday,Friday or Saturday.But I do remember that: Different strokes for different folks........so have fun wherever you go.

Sunday walk round Defensa a delight. I walked from my hotel through Retiro to Defensa in San Telmo. It was lovely as I went past the Cathedral Metropolitana and then into this huge street lined with small stalls selling everything from leather goods to hand painted shot glasses, jewellery and handbags. I did lots of shopping for the family but it was a lovely place to amble on a Sunday when travelling alone and had a real buzz to it.

Historic, funky, and everything in-between ..... Stayed several nights at the Patios de San Telmo Hotel, and enjoyed this area immensely Plenty of sights to visit, restaurants, cafes, hide-away bars, historic buildings, museums, and the list goes on and on. Go out and soak in the culture, enjoy the Sunday street market, tasty food in simple places. Safe to walk the streets at night, but don't get crazy and let your guard down. Be safe, have fun .... you only live once!

Flea market not what I expected. Thought this would be a great place for interesting finds like European flea markets, but it turned out to have a lot of vendors selling the same type of items. Many things were tourist wares, not many original or one of a kind pieces. Dedicated a Sunday morning to visit, but an hour would have been enough.
Open market on Sundays. nice old part of the city.on Sundays there is an open market in the whole area full of cool things.

Everything cultural. Antique shops with quality (and expensive) stuff. Artists, musicians, shops, cafes, and a tree covered park with cafes. This was the first and last time I ever heard a street band (or professionals) play what sounded like tango/reggae/ska. Nice little cafes of which one I had a beer and lunch under a tree at their table. So many antique shops from what looked like old money peoples' estates. Safe and certainly a place you must see.
Nice. Nice part of the city, you can find a lot of art here. The market of San Telmo is crowded and they sell awesome things.

Sunday Market. We try to be in BA on Sundays, so we can hit El Mercado de San Telmo. There are lots of artisans selling leather wares. I got a belt last week. He cut it to fit. Added holes. Shined it up. They are very gracious. It was 100 pesos There are leather purses, bracelets, wine-bottle holders. You can get a beer to walk around the enormous market and add to the yummy taste of the churros sold in the street. There is also art, tango dancers in the street, assorted jewelry. Men, put ur wallet in ur front pocket. Ladies, I keep my money in my bra or front pocket. Carry an old expired credit card in your back pocket. :)

A fun sunday. We started our trip to Buenos Aires by spending the entire day wondering the streets in San Telmo. We loved the tango dancing on the street and watched several couples. There was a lot of variety of vendors and artisans to admire and our meals were excellent.

Bohemian neighborhood. If you love places that have an bohemian atmosphere, you should go to San Telmo. At night you can eat nice parrillas, chorizos and picañas at a fair price. There is a huge fair on Sundays at Defensa St.

We loved San Telmo. We stayed in San Telmo for three weeks and fell in love with the neighborhood. The small markets and shops had everything we needed, the restaurants were excellent and the people were friendly. Like most of BA you have to keep your eyes open as you walk because of irregular pavement and dog droppings. We felt quite safe and were often walking home after milongas late at night. Other neighborhoods might be fancier, but for a real immersive BA experience we prefer San Telmo.

Faded and graffitied beauty. Really much quieter than I remember on weekdays but Sundays still have plenty of life. Restaurants around th square are predictably less good than those on the backstreets. Don't wear flip flops- the pavements are really cratered.

Good any day of the week but best on Sunday's. One of the oldest neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires, with a number of antique shops and a great selection of cafes and restaurants. Check out the markets on Sunday which run the length of Defensa. At the square on Defensa and Humberto Primo, you will find a selection of bars and restaurants to suit all budgets and daily Tango shows.

Our Favorite Barrio!. During our visit to Buenos Aires we stayed in Palermo, but wished we would have booked a place in San Telmo. We feel that this neighborhood best captures the personality of the city. Beautiful, unpretentious, and loaded with culture. The Sunday market is amazing, just make sure you watch your belongings closely. We are seasoned travelers well aware of the common petty theft "tricks" and I had my iPhone stolen out of a zipped purse . . . regardless, we would go back in a heartbeat to this beautiful area.

Not to be missed. Sunday market stretches for blocks. Handicrafts, buskers, food & amazing people watching. Easy to get to - take the Subte A,B or D line to Plaza de Mayo & then down Defensa on the south side of the plaza.Not to be missed!

Fun place to visit. We went to the market. Great place to get a cheap watch, which we had been looking for all over. Fabulous selection of antique vendors, and all sorts of knick knacks, etc. very authentic. Excellent selection of reasonable leather goods. Easy walk from metro stop, just brush off the few panhandlers on the way. Pretend to be French!

Great Market in the Square, But Only on Sunday. A crafts market in San Telmo Square and surrounding streets - only open on Sunday. It is a very nice market with lots of local merchandise at good prices. Pesos accepted - USD preferred by most. Although we walked back to the Government Center, I would recommend taking a radio taxi from the market there - a long walk transiting some not so great areas. Walking around the San Telmo market, viewing the government square area and visiting the cathedral makes a very nice Sunday adventure.

Amazing and vibe. Did not expect such a great turnout in the rain but what a vibe. Delicious eats, trinkets, antiques and curious being sold, not to mention bands on the cobbled street corners.A must when in Buenos.

something for everyone. Blocks and blocks along Defensa that offer live entertainment, shops, stalls, food, and people watching. Tango, bands, and solo artists. Tourist items for sure, but lots of other things if you take your time. Allow from 10 until 2 for a good pace. Market opens at 10 and closes at 4. Blog sites have note thieves, but we saw no evidence

We Must Have Missed Something. We strolled the entire length of Calle Defensa from Plaza de Mayo to the end on a Sunday afternoon when the flea market was set up. We had the best Choripan of all in a parking lot converted for the day as a parilla. The BBQ was outstanding. But, walking Defensa, we saw very little of interest to us in terms of "things to buy", but admittedly, we are not the souvenir type so that may be the reason. We spent a little time in the Square with the antiques and that was interesting. Defensa has some interesting shops. Many, however, are closed on Sundays, due to the street vendors. Had a much welcomed ice cream along Defensa in a ice cream shop. Overall, we thought it was just a crowded street with lots of junk for sale. We saw some street entertainment, no tango. Possibly we needed to stay into the evening for more entertainment. We returned a couple of days later during the week and it was "empty". So, we clearly missed something, based on all of the reviews her and our Fodor's Guide Book.

Wonderful buzz. A fabulous way to spend a Sunday! Shopping and bargaining with the numerous stalls makes this an excellent destination for souvenirs - including some highly unique finds if you've got the dedication to wade through the antique stalls! Be sure to stop and watch the tango dances, pop-up bands and other entertainment along the route as it's a great flavour of Argentina and attracts tourists and locals alike.

not to be missed. So this is the place where I was boned and raced. I remember it as a child, the antiques market and the cafes with the unique atmosphere. Every time i go back to buenos .aires I make sure to visit Sant Telmo. .no trio to this beautiful city will be complete without getting lost in Plaza .dorrego and surrondings.

The finest area in Buenos Aires. We were there in Feb. 15. We lived in San Telmo and started our first day which happened to be a Sunday by strolling to Casa Rosada which is at the other end of San Telmo. After a short visit of the Square and the down town area, we walked through the flea market and picked up some really good souvenirs from there. This is a perfect place for souvenirs as it is reasonably priced and the stuff is unique and good-not the usual made in chine stuff you find every where.In the evening we came across a square where there was a band with locals dancing the traditional dance. The entire area is alive with music and dancing. Finally we ended up in the Dorrego square for the open air Milonga where locals and the tourist dance the Tango with a couple of performance thrown in for good measure. Absolutely delightful day.The area also has fantastic eating places, reasonably priced with good food.
Nice walking around area.. We got a good look at the neighborhood while driving around with our tour guide. This would be an interesting place to walk around during the day.
Best flea market. This must be one of the best flea markets in the world. I always find treasures. I can also be read as a museum of the city's glorious past.

What could be nicer on a Sunday than strolling the mile-long market to this delightful square?. San Telmo is a square, but it is also one of the most fascinating areas of Buenos Aires. A walk from the Pink House down the incredible open-air market on a Sunday afternoon to the square must surely be one of the maximum fun experiences available anywhere. Besides block after block of kiosks selling wares of every description, there are Brazilian drum bands everywhere (if you can find Sandomble, who often play in the area, you will find yourself unable to keep from dancing right along with the locals), delightful side streets full of cafes and bars, and people ambling along amiably, dogs and kids in tow, historical cathedrals, street food, and, at the end, the square itself, where couples of all ages and descriptions, glide around on the dance surface, tangoing with abandon. All around the square are fascinating streets with more cafes, small shops and interesting people. Don't know what the "18 and under" proviso was about. We were four old guys, from 67 to 81, and we loved it.

Pick The Right Day To Tango. Interesting colorful part of the city with a nice public square.
