To experience the "Street Tango" lessons the area is known for, a weekend day visit would be better.Stroll through Mercado San Telmo and you might find some bargains or cheap food including fruits and vegetables.

Vibrant Spot With Seedy Underbelly. if you are 18, wear a t shirt and jeans and drink beer on the side walk, San Telmo can be a great place.If you have gray hair and have a wallet to protect, go during the day and hit the famous cafes and restaurants and take a taxi home after dark.Late at night, the streets are full of party people playing instruments or drums and having a good time. The area is notorious for theft and robbery. It is however a hot bed for creativity and enjoyment.
a walk thru SanTelmo. Narrow streets Photo ops The Rivas Cafe had very good service. My husbands fish was excellent. my salad was fresh and tasty.

San Telmo is in a tourist destination class of its own........... i spent alot of time in san telmo, since thats where my great hostel - OSTINATTO - was. This is a funky - but fun - neighborhood with lots of places to look at for free like the antiques fair on the weekends, the open air markets, the sunday night tango dance in the plaza. there's lots of little stores to buy groceries at/practice your Spanish. It is close to the subway and bus routes, and , if you are a good walker, many other parts of town. At night it gets real wild, with the happenin bars, and can be dangerous, so you have to stay alert. - the sidewalks are disgusting, so stay alert when walking around or you could fall on something horrible.
Beautiful Area, Wonderful Sunday Market. Beautiful area full of galleries and antique shops as well as cafes and bars. Be sure to visit on Sunday for the street market.

Funky and fun. Visit on Sunday for the fair along Defensa street. All kinds of crafts and art and great prices. Plenty of little restaurants and strolling food vendors. Chile street has a bunch of good places and a shady venue. Street musicians, mimes, and an antique section in the small park at Defensa and Humberto. In the rear of it, watch the tango dancers in the evening. First a show then the locals dance. Try if you dare. Go back another day to stroll through the stores that you can't see during the fair. And if you're interested in BA history, take the tour at El Zanjon--a renovated home with exposed underground tunnels. Great history lesson of San Telmo and BA.

Fantastic!!!. San Telmo is a special place to visit if you go to Buenos Aires, every Sunday there is a Flea Market that you don't want to miss, and the antiques stores along the street carried from fine china to WWI uniforms to old newspapers, you name it and you probably will found it, and if you are a fan of Mafalda (like me) you will have a chance to have a picture with her, Susana and Manolito......great memories from my youth, overall San Telmo is a must if you are visiting Argentina (Buenos Aires).

The oldest neighborhood of Buenos Aires. San Telmo is not a street or a flea market. San Telmo is the oldest neighborhood of Buenos Aires. It is characterized by the cobblestone streets and old buildings. Nowdays they became cafes, tango parlors and antique shops.San Telmo's has lots of attractions but it is very dirty and not so nice to visit on weekdays.The better day to walk around is on sundays. Yo can see old churches, museums ( I recommend "El Zanjon" ), antique stores and the antique fair at Plaza Dorrego.Worth the visit... with caution by scams

Mercado de San Telmo. We walked by Defensa from Plaza de Mayo and found nice stuff, but nothing to much different from your typical flea market. But when we entered the San Telmo Market, Defensa avenue and Estados Unidos street, through the entrance on Estados Unidos I was blown away by the antique shops inside. I especially recommend the antique posters and newspaper store immediatly to right when entering through Estados Unidos street.

Warning of Bird Poop Scam. San Telmo for it's own is a nice old place to visit, especially on Sunday, where a Feria is held.Tango in the streets and many stalls selling used items and antiques.Although it is also a place where tourists are a target for scams.BEWARE: My husband was targeted TWICE in 3hrs. time by the Bird Poop Scam.Being always aware of our surroundings, fortunately,we were able to save our belongings.The first time, my husband was sprayed with the so called bird poop, a man approached us with a kleenex wanting to help clean up.My husband did put down his back pack on the floor but I snatched it up and held it tight. We were at the corner of Libertador and Independencia.At this point the man shouted to us that there was a McDonald near the gas station, where we could clean up in the bathroom upstairs.Here, back home a McDonald has always been a safe place where we bring our kids, so we thought nothing of it and went. The bathroom was upstairs, very few table and very dirty. My husband put down his back pack on one of the tables and went in the bathroom to clean up. I was standing right next to the table, had my hat in my hands and was thinking if I should put my hat down on the dirty table. At the corner of my eye I saw a movement, immediately I looked at my husbands back pack and in it's place was a different one!! I turned around to see a man running down the stairs holding OURS. I grabbed his, through it at him and grabbed ours away from him, yelling, " This is yours and this is mine!!" I yelled so loud he ran away , my husband came running out of the washroom and another gentleman who was reading a newspaper, shook his head saying that these people were not Argentinians but Colombians. Anyway I was glad to have been quick enough to have saved our back pack which contained 2 cameras, condo keys,a watch etc. These two were working together and the second man was waiting for us in the McDonald.The second time, my husband was sprayed at the corner of Independencia Av. and Balcarce St. very near also to the same MacDonald. This time, he yelled at the man telling him he was not going to the McDonald to wash up where his friend was waiting for us.So, be very careful when you go to San Telmo, enjoy the day there but BEWARE of the Bird Poop Scam.

Plaza Durango Sunday Market. I had heard about this famous antiques and craft market before, but I thought it was limited to the small Plaza Durango that I had previously visited. Oh how wrong I was. This enormous affair stretches for several blocks down Calle Defensa in San Telmo and is covered with an amazing variety of things for sale. Souvenirs, antiques, hippie handicrafts. You name it, they have it. Many are locally made too. I got a wallet made from old food packaging with collaged images of ancient Egyptian mummification on the front. Very unique. Although immediately after I saw a vintage street sign I really wanted. Only bring as much cash as you want to spend, because it's likely you will spend it all. Be sure to watch out for the blind guy who bumped into my sister and reached for her purse. Not everybody there is making money honestly.On other days, San Telmo still has a few stalls in Plaza Durango, but it's better known for it's cobblestone streets, chic restaurants and turn-of-the-century architecture. A great place to go explore, shop, eat and soak in the atmosphere of this historic neighborhood in Buenos Aires. To get here, take the metro (Subte) to San Juan and walk over to Calle Defensa. Alternatively, you can go to Plaza de Mayo and walk down Defensa from there.

Fabulous Sunday antiques market. We went to the lovely market on Sunday and we were blown away with the variety of stalls and goods available, with the added bonus of watching impromptu tango dancing in bars and on the streets , we bought some beautiful antique cut glass , the bars and restaurants in this area are quaint and not aimed at tourists therefore great food and good value, we can't wait to go back

Disappointing. Having read about the famous Sunday market in San Telmo we were really looking forward to visiting this attraction. How wrong can you be. Lots of tourist tat and thins that are available in markets all over the world. There one or two stalls selling more unique products but they were certainly few and far between. We saw little street theatre or performers to make this of any real interest. After walking the length of the market moved on to more interesting sights.

Souvenir hunters paradise. Our very first day in S. America we took a taxi to this amazing, bustling, crowded market - a mix of 'antiques' and junk and souvenirs in the square and then all down Defensa street. We bought 3 or 4 items, but restrained ourselves from buying any more thinking this is just day one and we have almost 4 weeks travelling. In fact almost everywhere else in Argentina and Chile we could not find gifts and souvenirs that appealed and we regretted not buying more at San Telmo.

Flew & antiques Market. The famous flew and antique Market in San Telmo (Defensa Street) on Sundays is a multicultural and colored mixed market. You may find a lot of different things, from real antiques to modern, alternative handy crafts, as well as food and drinks. Even tango lessons on the street.On the corners of Defensa and Chile, you may take a photo with Mafalda and friends. But if this is your real intention, than you should better reserve another day, during the week, otherwise it make take more than half an hour standing in a cue for the picture.

San Telmo markets on a Sunday. Don't miss this! Step back in time to the old cobbled street and enjoy the hand craft markets. Get the spirit of the very friendly people and you may even get your bottom pinched ha! Have a Tango lesson in the street. Buy some Tango music. We loved this visit - a great was to be a local.

A crowded delight of Artists of many media. A Sunday in Defensa Street was a bevy of noise , heat, accents, crowds and music. A browse here would bring the reward of a present for someone or yourself.A place to watch your purse but definitely experience.

Very interesting!. San Telmo is the proof of what happens when global economy hits a neighbourhood that has so far been sitting in the Basement of global growth: some streets and some squares go: "booom!" and grow like crazy, around the Corner nothing happens.Interesting quarter however and I'm sure it will look very different in a year or two.

Interesting mix. Apart of the fair, which has some interesting things to see, the art presentations atracted me much more. Watch people playing and dancing tango was quite interesting. The main market, the one that is in door, had also some good things to see. Just be aware that it only happens on sunday.

Great old barrio in Buenos Aires... We stayed in an old, beautiful home in this district and really enjoyed the wonderful restaurants and shopping. We didn't get to a Tango show, which I regret...but this gives me another reason to go back.The Sunday market is really great. Interesting shopping, musicians and if you're into people watching, sit down at one of the many cafes and watch the tourists and Portenos wander by...As this is one of the oldest barrio's in Buenos Aires, there are lots of interesting buildings and you can wander the streets for a good part of the day just looking at all of the beautiful architecture and facades.Well worth the visit when in Buenos Aires...

Wow! The Sunday market is crazy!. You need great stamina to walk to whole length of the market. It's worth it. We saw street Tango, artists, musicians, the lot! The roads off the market are a little dicey with loads of street people and run down buildings. I wouldn't advise to walk there at night.

Interesting walking. This area is great for walking during the daytime. Lots of great antique places and really old and wonderful restaurants. Sunday should not be missed - the street market is great people watching and you can get some really good street food along the way also. My wife picked up some unique items in the main square for a fair price.

A wonderful weekend activity. You must go on a weekend day and check out the local artisans that line the street along with live tango exhibits. Bring small bills. Great deals on Alpaca, interesting jewelry, handmade artisan purses and for some reason, colorful seltzer bottles in the square. Across from the main square is one of the most amazing Art By God/Antique Stores with rare and interesting items.

San Telmo. I lived in San Telmo for a month on Calle Humberto Primo. I think San Telmo can be described as a mix of regular middle class Porteno's and self described bohemian artists, writers, musicians, and film makers. San Telmo is very touristy and as a results the bars and restaurants tend to be more expensive than similar places in other neighborhoods. Excluding of course Palermo and Recoleta.In general I think Buenos Aires is a fairly dirty city and one must be ever mindful of the ever present dog droppings on the sidewalks but perhaps as a result of the general bohemian attitude the streets in San Telmo are dirty and the smell of urine and dog feces was even more noticeable than in other parts of Buenos Aires.The Sunday arts fair on Calle Defensa in San Telmo is a must see but one visit was enough for me and watching the amateur Tango dancers each evening and weekends at the Plaza was a good way relax.

A Must See When in Buenos Aires. Probably the one place that binds all the flavors of this magnificent city... a flea market extravaganza, tango shows, artisan merchandise, foods from around the country, and people, people, people... if you have the time, spend the entire afternoon there before heading out to dinner.

Biggest and Best Flea Market. On a Sunday around noon start strolling through the center of San Telmo and you will have an amazing experience. Combine what feels like the world’s largest collection of antique sellers, with an equally large collection of artisans, and intersperse it with tango dancers, and great outdoor restaurants and you get a sense of what this experience is like. It goes on block after block, spills over into side streets and takes hours to just give it a once over. There are great items to buy from Gaucho artifacts to hand crafted leather goods and jewelry. Tip: Like any crowed area in Buenos Aires beware of pick-pockets and the frequently used “bird-pooh scam”

Feria de San Telmo. Worth visiting on a Sunday if you are in Buenos Aires, this market stretches on for blocks. Every block or so, a busker or a troupe of performers (most of them are actually quite talented) provides some entertainment. The shops lining the market spill out onto the streets, and you can wander in for some air-conditioning and knick-knacks. The quality of the goods sold at the market is varied; with the right care, you'll be able to find goods that were handcrafted by the seller or their family and of reasonable quality at low prices. Wander into a bar along the way for alcoholic refreshment, or buy the pastries sold along the way if you get hungry.

Things have changed...... We used to love San Telmo on Sundays - great finds from old Argentinian families. Fun to poke through with high hopes of finding a treasure. There are still beautiful silk bed jackets, the likes of which you cannot find today in retail outlets, the knives are large and varied, but the T shirts and cheap tidbits outnumber the wonderful handmade goodies of the past and I doubt the antique value of most of the items. One vendor actually got mad when we questioned her "ivory" frame, as we had seen the exact thing in many other stalls. A reputable dealer downtown told us they were Bakelite (one of the first plastics). If you duck into some of the old homes where the courtyard space is rented out, you can find special goodies - Maria Mateos is one such place. She weaves absolutely beautiful, colorful scarves in silk and mohair. Enjoy the day if you have never been, but BUYER BEWARE!

Amazing Sunday Market. Only on Sunday, a street fair is held that goes for miles! Artisans, street performers - watch the Tango dancers - and food about. Don't be a stingy tourist thoug. If you stop and watch a performance and especially if you take pictures, leave some pesos. They are working hard!
GREAT SUNDAY MARKET. There is a Sunday market here. Good fun to stroll through. There are lots of shops and small bars to go and visit. Street entertainers as well as Tango in the streets!

A REAL neighborhood a la tango!. We booked in at a guesthouse called "Lina's Tango Guesthouse" on Estados Unidos and Chacabuco. THis is the oldest neighborhood in Buenos Aires...lots of "artful" graffitti on most walls, broken up sidewalks, old tall trees, and wonderful little shops and friendly people. No, it's not the upscale Palermo or Recoleta, it's a REAL place, the home of weekend tango on the street, street markets, and antique stores. It's only blocks from the upscale parts, or just walk to the ecological reserve for a day surrounded by nature, or taxi/subway (subway is about 5 pesos/50 cents US for a one-way trip) into the shopping/museum neighborhoods. Friendly people, history (the oldest neighborhood in BA - you'll love it if you like the real thing and are not snooty.

San Telmo (Plaza Dorrego +). I enjoyed visiting Plaza Dorrego and walking the streets surrounding on a warm Sunday (January is summertime here) seeing the vendors and their wares. In the Plaza were the promised (read about them on Lonely Planet), spontaneous Tango dances. I enjoyed watching the people in the plaza as well. On my walk back to Av. Paseo Colon to catch the bus back home when I stumble across an open air live music venue on the corner of Balcarce & Humberto Primo (the backside of La Meja Remates, an antique store). There's a grill back there and on Sunday night (the only night I can vouch for) walk on by and check it out... you won't miss the music.

Worth seeing. I assume San Telmo is more than just the Defensa street, but that is what I saw and it was worthwhile. We walked through the whole length of the market on a Sunday, and also the antiques market in the park near the end. I am not much of a trinket person, but the prices I saw were better than I had seen elsewhere for the same things. There were also various stores and additional giant indoor markets and restaurants along the street, but the overall effect was pretty overwhelming. And it was really really hot. I might have gone in some stores just for the AC. Overall the markets were worthwhile, but it's not something I would do twice.

Super Sunday!!. Apparently, this takes place every sunday and we discovered by accident. We went to Mass at the Cathedral and were looking for a toilet along Defensa road when we saw the flea market.They sell all sorts of interesting goodies and there was something for everyone. We saw live bands playing and apparently they even dance the tango on the streets. The antique shops are just mind boggling. There are also a few out doors street-food areas as well as more upmarket restaurants. We spent 5 hours looking around before ending off at the San Telmo antique fair. Was one of best days in Buenos Aires.

Cool only during the weekends. I find San telmo to be nice during the weekends but a bit unsafe during the week days, specially at night. I like the Sunday San Temo Fair and I think that building are very nice and also the history and culture of the place but again it can be unsafe. I would say that Palermo is so much better in every way.
Go to the feria!. Go to the Feria de San Telmo. It was very vibrant and eclectic, and you can find so many things to buy there!

Feels like real Buenos Aires. Mix of run down grand buildings and fully restored old colonial mansions and townhouses, jostling together among graffiti, local shops and restaurants, cars, dogs, people sitting in doorways, music and abundant life. Rubbish piles up during the day but is miraculously cleaned away in the depths of the night. The Sunday market is not to be missed - bands playing tango and guitar music, incredible variety of things to look at and/or buy, tango dancing in the evening. San Telmo has the heartbeat of Buenos Aires - don't be put off by its scruffiness - its part of its immense charm and life.

Oldest. San Telmo is the oldest, and for me the most interesting neighborhood in Buenos Aires, due to the colonial buildings, art galleries, restaurants and bohemian atmosphere. On Sundays there's an antique fair, with lots of street sellers, where you can find everything.

Go to the Mercado, lots on doesn't have to be a weekend. Initially the area looks touristy but move away from the main square and it feels more authentic. The Mercado is a must, the bric a brac fascinating. Some cute cafes too. Very different to Palermo etc.

Great neighborhood! Antiques, street tango! The authentic Buenos Aires.. It should be visited on Sunday afternoons! The flea market first, then, as the sun sets, watch the "street tango" on Dorrego square. This is no professional show, it is a spontaneous street gathering where anyone can dance tango. Not to be missed!!!
Just ok. It is ok, but not that much. I mean, it is a nice street market, but most of the products you will find in a souvenir shop.

Make sure you come on a Sunday for the Market. Very cool antiques market that many other street artisans and vendors pile on. Streets closed, lots of crowds, but doesn't feel too touristy (like La Boca). Reminds me of Sunday markets in San Francisco. Not sure what its like other days of the week but read that specifically Sunday is the big day for the market. Cool indoor foodie market as well. Seems like 11- 1pm probably the best time to go. Many vendors take USD, Euros etc, which is good for making peso change since ATM withdrawals are nightmares for tourists (they will give change in pesos).

I'd have enjoyed this district more if we weren't pickpocketed here. I know, I know. Tourists should know better and do more research and keep more aware of their surroundings etc.etc. However even though we had read tons about keeping careful, we still managed to get hit with the 'bird poop scam' (though we somehow missed reading about the details of this particular trick on the internet until after we got robbed). We got hit just as we were approaching Defensa, on the corner of Belgrano and Bolivar. Anyway, aside from that, there are plenty of tourists and street stalls selling touristy knick knacks, if you like that kind of thing.

It is not only Defensa!. San Telmo has more to offer and to show that only Calle Defensa. There is a Museum of modern Arts, there are other roads with interesting shops, cafes and buildings. There are small places to discover. Of course the feria on sundays is a must.

Going back in time in Argentina!. Loved this little area---walking the cobblestone street, tangos and other entertainment, colorful buildings, lots of fun pictures to be had. We went on a Sunday, so not sure if this is an everyday thing.

Well worth a look. This area of Buenos Aires is certainly worth a look, although it is very much geared up to the tourist trade. I would not want to come here at night, unless on a guided tour. The multi-coloured houses are iconic, and the many bars/bistros are very much targeted at the tourists. Many have a demonstration of the Tango, to which you are encouraged to 'contribute', particularly if you are sitting at the tables. Walking through the area will lead onto Puerto Madero, which is similarly geared up to the tourists. Bars/bistros abound.

San Telmo market a must!. We visited the markets twice during our recent visit (Sunday 10am - 5pm) it is great. Atmosphere great bargains, food/drinks and music...don't buy from the first stall! Plaza Dorrego after 5pm turns into a Tango lovers paradise, not bad. San Telmo is also great on other days when the market isn't on with less people. Like any part of BA be vigilant with your belongings, we didn't have any issues but we were robbed that next day at the Retiro bus station. Argentina is still on my 'must revisit' lists. It is an amazing place! Best Tango teacher is located in San Telmo - Alejandro Puerta, professional, knowledgable and talented.

Beautiful picturesque and atmospheric neighbourhood. San Telmo is one of the most beautiful neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires. With the small cobbled streets, the old mansions and merchants' houses, some derelict and other refurbished, graffiti, street music and the Sunday feria, it has an artistic and historic atmosphere combining a quite european-looking environment with the latin vibe. Must see if you are in Buenos Aires and a convenient place to stay during your visit, as it is not far from the centre, the metro is 10-15mins walking distance and has some cafes, restaurants and bars. Do some research on where exactly to stay as some streets are more deserted late at night (e.g. on Calle Defensa and close to Plaza Dorrego is a very good location)
Amazing culture. While the area was a little rougher then Recoleta or Palermo it still had charm and watching the locals Tango at dusk was great!
Very European. San Telmo is very similar to Madrid in many ways. The colonial houses and stone streets are beautiful.
Mafalda . Make sure to check the Mafalda madness on the weekend, too much fun :)Different blocs parade during the afternoon and night every Saturday and Sunday. Music, customs and lots of fun .

Best on a Sunday. Onetime fancy section of the city, now a Bohemian area with many good art galleries, restaurants, bars, and tango shows. It's best to visit on a Sunday when the flea market is there, but a worthwhile destination on any day.

Pick pockets, scammers, and Thiefs. Hold on tight to everything all the time. I've traveled around the world and have never seen such coordination in stealing. Even Rio was actually more obvious with kids doing the dirty work. Here the adults do it.
And the stuff is generally crap. Go see the Japanese Garden or the Teatre Colon instead.

My favorite part of Buenos Aires. We spent the better part of a day here, wandering the streets of this interesting part of BA. It is all here, good shopping (some very fine artisanal shops), restaurants for every taste, a square where you can even catch some tango, and an underground museum. Don't miss it.

Great, true atmosphere and high level antique-shops.. The cobbled streets surrounded by classical buildings alone makes San Telmo well worth the visit. If you add the cosy restaurants and small shops and not least the very interesting antique shops, San Telmo is a mus see. When we first visited San Telmo 8 years ago the prices of the antiques were about half of what they are now, but the shops still have a vast selection of all kind of antiques.

Street Fair. It's a street fair that happens every Sunday. Be prepared for walking a lot (wear comfortable clothes and shoes) - the street is made of stones. There are a lot of popular artists, selling stuff and making some musical performances (Gardel is, of course, the preferred impersonated character). It's enjoyable even if you don't go there to buy anything. By the way, we visited some stores along the street and the prices were not so much attractive. The top spot of the visit is to take a picture at Mafalda's statue.

Sunday Markets. We were initially concerned with theft / pickpocketing; but after 5 hours walking with the masses there was never a hint of any security issues as we looked at the 100's of market stalls. Common sense is all that is required. I have a big set of Canon L lenses but managed to use both a wide zoom and a longer tele to get many interesting scene and participants images.Sunday afternoon from 10 until about 17:00 is the time to be there. The connecting street from Plaza Domingo's back north to the main city square is the main shopping street of stalls on a Sunday.Plenty of food options in the established cafes that line the square and connecting streets.If you are in BA on a Sunday this is the place to be.Plan your trip in South America / Argentina to be here for the Sunday afternoon.

A great neighborhood in old town BA. This is a wonderful and old part of BA and really worth a visit. The streets are narrow and often busy, but a really good vibe exists here. This place is know for its churches, small cafes and absolutely world class antique shops. Several small squares allow for an expensive but enjoyable coffee break on a long day of sightseeing. Don't miss this neighborhood when visiting this city.

Great atmosphere on a Sunday !. The markets are huge and they come along with lots of street side artists and shows A must do in BA for sureLovely Italian place on 1st floor overlooking the square makes for a nice lunch with a great view overlooking the buzzing streets

San Telmo One-of- a kind place to visit. San Telmo is one of my favorite neighborhoods in Buenos Aires: Mix of old and new features.If you travel downsouth you cannot possibly miss: Plaza Dorrego : You´ll have the chance to walk around and enjoy a great fair during the weekend!, Paseo de la Historieta, Up and Down Defensa Street .You will also have the greatest chance to drink "mate" and good coffee in any of our typical coffee houses.Hope you´ll enjoy San Telmo as much as I do!Cheers!Sandra

San Telmo - wonderful place to visit. It's such a small area, but check out the artists and markets in the small square. On Sundays it comes alive with tango street dancing and music and festivities. Once a month the people celebrate a country - an even bigger event!

San Telmo. I stayed in San Telmo during my stay in Buenos Aires. I discovered two gems that should be experienced. Biking Buenos Aires for a fantastic tour of B.A. and the Federal bar for dinner and an entertaining evening out.
More and more and more. This is a huge market held on sundays and well worth a visit. It stretches about 5 km so seems endless but has lots of local items. It's just buzzing with life!!!

San Telmo ... don't forget to look at the arquitecture.. The good: One of the oldest areas of Buenos Aires with beautiful buildings. Few are well taken care but many are not. As we were walking around we dreamed of having the resources to purchase them all and bring them back to their earlier splendor. Look at the wood and brass work on the tall doors of these buildings. We also recommend the feria where among the crappy tourist's junk you can find original and beautiful products. At Plaza Dorrego we heard Concierto de Aranjuez performed by real musicians al aire libre. Walking away from Plaza Dorrego stop at any bar (cafe) and experience what Argentinos enjoy every day: un cafecito! (at almost every bar they will bring the little coffee with a cookie and a little glass of water to wash down the coffee taste at the end). The bad: dirty sidewalks from selfish people who think is not their duty to clean after their dogs and dirty walls (not talking about the paintings which we liked but the graffiti done intentionally on recently painted walls.

A Perfect Sunday: Market plus Tango. We walked blocks and blocks through the street vendors. Lots of cutsy crafts, inexpensive belts and such. We purchased a leather jacket in a store along the way. Once we reached Plaza Dorrego we watched some professionals give a little show after 6pm on Sunday and they just passed the hat. I understand that there is a milonga in the square on Sundays at 7:30pm for all to dance.

Cool Sunday outdoor market. It was my first day here and it was pretty cool to walk and check out all the stuff! There are souvenirs, antiques, food, clothing and so on along this long street. We enjoyed checking everything out. Wear comfortable shoes, cobblestone streets partly. I watched my bag as normal, but I keep seeing people writing about pickpockets. I never had a problem in this city. Reminded me of El Rastro, in Madrid. It's a cool place

still a colourful market but know the traps. I live parttime in Argentina, just in one of the streets where every Sunday the Feria of San Telmo takes place. A few do's and dont's: do's: two times to walk around and eventually buy: at the beginning at 11 hrs (not very crowded and sellers willing to offer a deal to start the day) and at 18 hrs, when it official ends and prices drop very fast. Besides, at the end the free tango-milonga on the square Dorrego. In the mean time go to Defensa and San Juan, just around the corner of the square, to listen to a ska and reggae group. Another great music event: the tango groups playing in the Pasaje San Lorenzo and the one on Humberto Primo. Drink Colombian coffee of the guy walking and selling delicious Colombian coffee. Or eat a empanada or vegetarian cake of the many sellers on street. Negotiate price if you want to buy something on the market. Dont's: the sellers of "souveniers". Most of them horrendous in shape and form. And very expensive. Got better to buy souveniers to the Feria de Mataderos. And the sellers of antiquary on the Plaza Dorrego itself: crap being sold very expensive. Skip also any of the coffee places around the Plaza Dorrego: all places to get ripped off as a tourist.

Sunday Feria is the Place to Be. Great way to pass a Sunday afternoon. Many antique vendors have stalls in the plaza where they are selling their wares, but extending out from that are booths with all kinds of souvenirs. Some of the things are handcrafted by the individual and others are items you will see on every block but this fair stretches for about a mile and is a fun place to spend the day. You will also see tango dancers, hear street musicians and just generally have a good time.

San Telmo Market Street Party. We went to the Sunday market and wow what a crazy, enjoyable way to buy some souvenirs. There were so much cool live music everywhere, on random streets. And we were not expecting the circus atmosphere with all the crazy costumes and dance party. Loved it and it showcased the vibrancy of Buenos Aires.

sunday market. 12 block of wonderful shopping beautiful handmade scarves at great prices, beauttiful silver, knives, jewlrey amazing and so much fun music and street food too great way to spend a sunday afternoon

Sunday Market. There is a Sunday Market at San Telma all along Defensa street starting at Plaza de Mayo up to Plaza Dorrego. We took the subte (subway) green line and got off stop Est. Catedral and walked all the way up Defensa street. There is something for everyone here - shoes, second-hand books, jewelry, clothes, antiques, crafts. There are also street artists playing music and it is a very fun vibe. There are tons of restaurants along the way. You can spend a whole day here. We were warned by our Airbnb hosts of pickpockets but didn't encounter anything so would just recommend exercising a regular level of caution in a crowded place.

Sunday market full of value, artists and thiefs. Enjoy with care. We enjoyed the artists and values at the Sunday market. Many artists very honest with great values. We got some wonderful Rhodochrosite stones and jewelry (I import gemstone to US so know quality) Not sufficient bargains for resale but great bargains for supporting local artists. Also bought some Mattes to take back to the states with wonderful craftsmanship. Great values overallThe down side is there are also the thiefs. I got my pocket picked and lost an Iphone 6 at the market. I felt a bump and my phone was gone from my pocket. DId not see anything Professional job. So keep your valuables safe and enjoy the artists. Much to enjoy and great values to be had.

great place. If you like antiques there's a lovely market on Sunday and the surroundings are quite typical from Buenos Aires with a lot of good quality bars and restaurants. As well as street artists playing music or acting, a must visit!

Antiques at Bargain Prices. The best time to get the feel of San Telmo is at the Sunday market when the locals come out in force lining the streets with handcrafts for sale. In the square, even if a bit pricy, you might be lucky enough to pick up a "genuine" antique. Keep an eye out for the street musicians...anything from a grand piano to a string quartet or a classical guitar concert is on the cards. Generally there is a Tango show...or two. Restaurants abound and don't miss out on on the little alleys where you might pick up a bargain. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes.

Trying too hard. Nothing really special here, as far as I was concerned just another tourist trap. A lot of brightly painted buildings and ex tango ladies, "No I do NOT want to have my photo taken with you" gets a bit tiring after the 6th attempt. Just like Bourbon St in New Orleans, people think they just have to have a good time.Give me a genuine flea market any day.

don´t miss it if you are there on Sunday. We arrived at the hotel, settled and went down to ask for suggestions for a Sunday. The concierge told us to go and walk around in the San Telmo open air flee market! boy, was he right? the market is just fantastic, lots of old stuff, and not so old as well, but the best thing was the people, the artists, the music and the atmosphere! it was the first time we saw a band carrying a piano on the street and on the way back to the hotel, we watched them playing! Surreal...
Must take a picture with Mafalda. I'm a huge fan of Mafalda. If you are also a fan must go to take a picture. A nice place to eat also. Try La Brigada if you want some Argentinian tradicional beef.

Sunday market. It was very busy with tourists, locals and vendors. I did not see any problems and everyone seemed to be having a good time. My wife and I started at one end and worked, or shall I say she worked, and I watched until the other end. She found some great gifts and a few for herself. We had a good time.

san telmo. last time i visited san telmo and plaza dorrego was 15 years ago. i was very happy to see the improvement of the barrio, cleaner streets, more art on the antique shops and more good restaurants. going down on Defenza st and the little restaurants with theumbrellas and decorative plants is a beauty.Plaza Dorrego is beautiful, nothing beats a homemade good pasta dish (good portion) a cold Quilmes under blue skies and watching a tango couple danze in front of you.

Lovely neighborhood, cheap. I lived here for five months and got to know it fairly well. The Mercado San Telmo has great antique shops and a cool old book and map store, and a decent coffee place. The Sunday street market is great, but a little more expensive. La Continental is a chain that has excellent and consistent empanadas. La Poesía has good coffee and sandwiches. Open squares are good for eating and drinking with friends, and there are tango shows on the streets on weekend nights.

Amazing Neighborhood. Great atmosphere; a lot of local shops, antiques and souvenirs; great cafes; A historical neighborhood; Definetely the best one to stay if visiting Buenos Aires! Don't miss the sunday flea market

A Not To Miss neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Charm just overflows from this neighborhood ... quaint and inviting ... little cafes, stores, antique stores ... and definitely do not miss the flea market on the weekend ... one of the best I have visited in all my travels. Have your shoes ready to try some street tango dancing!

Street market with real Argentinian "flair"!. I loved this Sunday street market in Buenos Aires! I arrived at what I thought was the market to discover I had only found the very "end" of the market and that it goes on for miles. Antique shops, vendors, jewelry, artisan crafts, coffee shops, street tango, musicians and fantastic cobble-stone streets. If you've ever been to the Portobello Road market in London this is similar in size and fun but with its own Argentinian soul. You can find everything from antique coins to Eva Peron magnets and beautiful leather work. Plan on strolling for a few hours just to soak it all in (with stops for coffee or maybe a beer along the way!) You'll love it!
Amazing place from the past. This old neighborhood is wonderful to be visited. There are a few blocks that concentrate a lot of history of the city of Buenos Aires.

Antiques and cobblestone streets. Main attractions of San Telmo are its antiques shops where you can find almost everything. Currently is a tourist neighboorhood going upmarket through the invetsment in boutique hotels for tourists. Its streets are an antique in themselves. Try to avoid a visit during weekends. Full of people, no space to walk wihtout bumping on another tourist trying ot take the same phjoto you want to. Sometimes remind me the crowds around La Gioconda at the Louvre.

Flee market with character. Headed to the san telomere flee markets Sunday morning with my partner. We started at the pink palace and strolled through, it's an enormous market down one long street stretching 5 km. it has everything for anyone and a must to stroll if you are in BA on a Sunday

Very nice weekend flee/antique market. I went there on my own and founded to be one the best flee markets in the world, plenty of antique shops, unusual items, plenty of street artists, great coffee shops and food and one of the most lively atmospheres with plenty of street Tango and Drama.A must in Buenos Aires

Tour its trap worth visiting. San Telmo is very interesting especially on Sunday's. It's a first class flea market and souvenir place. The French restaurant, Planque has excellent food and good wines at good local prices.

Mafalda!. Besides all the attractions in San Telmo, especially down Avenue Defensa, tourists should take a break in the stretch of Avenue Chile between Defensa and Balcarce. This is marked by the cute statue of the comic book character, Mafalda, at the start of it. There you'll find a good selection of bistros and bars with reasonably priced food that's basic but filling and tasty. It's a good place to put your feet up for a while, away from the traffic. If it's a bit chilly, they have heaters outdoors. And, if you're lucky, you'll get a free concert of old time jazz by a group of gentlemen decked out in blazers.

Energy. This place has an energy all of its own; it's a bit artsy, very colorful, a bit run down, and just a bit touristy. The day I was here, there were far more tourists out and about, which is never a good thing in my book.

Nice place you should visit in Buenos Aires. I love San Telmo, it is a nice place to spend a Sunday afternoon. Perfect place for some coffee, or some pizza for lunch, and just walk through those streets, see all the street performers and soak in some of the Argentinian culture. They sell all kind of stuff, and you can find amazing antiques for good price. Honestly it was one of my favorite places I visited in Buenos Aires.

Nice Sunday Stroll. This is a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon, strolling through the street, looking at lots of trinkets and some arts and crafts, stopping for drinks, listening to music and enjoying being outside.

Travel in San Telmo. We loved San Telmo. It was packed full of things to do, try and eat. There was an incredible energy, the streets came alive with art, pop up markets, live music and tango. Slightly more rustic and less fancy pants than Palermo but full of character. If you're a food lover you will love San Telmo, every street is filled with cafes, restaurants, bakery's and bars and all extremely reasonably priced. If you haven't already, research the 'Blue Dollar' before going, it could save you money. The antique markets on Sunday are a must see!

A great way to spend a Sunday afternoon. On the recommendation of a friend I visited the market at San Telmo on a Sunday afternoon.What a great time!I heard at least 7 different live entertainers and picked up two CD’s – one of funky Argentine inspired tango style music and the other of acoustic guitar.There was also lot of great art for sale – from oil to water color and other applications. I picked up a great water color for 500 pesos.I also found a couple of great leather/metal bracelets for my wife and daughter.I didn’t get a chance to stop for a drink or some food but there were plenty of choices.There were hundreds of vendors which made for a fun and pleasant three hour tour of the market.I would highly recommend to anyone looking to pick up a unique gift or just experience a fun afternoon.

Go on Sundays. I loved San Telmo and the historical cobble stone streets. What a beautiful, old historical place. On Sundays there is a market going on with tons of cheap buys, music and wonderful food. It's on Avenida Defensa. If you happen to be in Buenos Aires on a Sunday then you can't miss this event.
turist friendly places. This is a lovely place to walk arround alone or with friends, principally on saturdays. Very turist friendly! I decided to stay here for some time or forever, I don't know.
Street Artist. Local street artist on display gives the most amazing atmosphere in this amazing city of so many artist

A must do in Buenos aires. Was probably living in the past as had been here before and loved it - perhaps the weather which was terrible on this Sunday influenced it but have been to so many markets around the world that I felt a little let down. Lots of stalls, lots of belts and hats but very little that I wanted to bring home. Wanted to see tango in the streets but I think too wet and cold for that.

A lot of fun on Sunday. . Streets and streets lined with vendors selling goods at great prices. You will find knick knacks that you won't find elsewhere. The only point of caution is that the area gets a little questionable as it gets dark. The crowd is full of rowdy young people, the alcohol comes into full view, and atmosphere gets somewhat aggressive. So be aware and focused and on your game if you are there at that time.
Markets are a must... The markets are just awesome. Reasonable prices, great products, some great restaurants, cafes and food along the way. Perfect way to spend a Sunday.

Sunday markets are fantastic. San Telmo on any other day is great in it's own right - cobbled streets, bars, shops etc, but Sunday the whole of Defensa becomes alive!Start at the Plaza de Mayo and walk the whole way down, I even linked it in with my trip to La Boca and kept walking (in the middle of the day). To avoid crowds, start early. And have decent shoes on, the roads are uneven
The lovely place. A beautiful place a must to visit a mix of soho , Montmartre In Paris or usaquen en Bogota so much history, live and mix of people love the market with so much art.

The Sunday market is a must-see!. I had read about the sunday-market in San Telmo and couldn't wait to visit it. It was a lot of fun, you can buy typical Argentinian things like mates, bombillas, etc. There were loads of people but still it was quite easy to walk around. You can buy food and drinks anywhere on the way and if you're lucky you'll meet some local bands playing music!Visited August 2013

An Old town in the middle of a city. Many times I heard a lot of people saying that Buenos Aires has lots of different attrctions. It seems like different places become one in a single city. I say: YOU´RE RIGHT! The first Buenos Aires has many satellite towns united by rail, and with the passing of time these villages became part of the city.The original Buenos Aires includes San Telmo, a neighbourhood located very near the Government House and it has centuries-old buildings. During the week it doesn´t seem a great attraction, but on weekends San Telmo literally explodes with local craft, music and street dancing shows, people offering typical dishes and its main attraction: the sale of antiques.Many celebrities like Madonna o Michael Jackson bought one or many of this ancient stuff during their stay in this country. This stores has a wide palette of prices. San Telmo also offer good and affordable gastronomy, and a great diversity of shows, like Tango at the VIEJO ALMACEN restaurant, or modern music at LA TRASTIENDA theater.It is good to give the pleasure of letting ourselves be carried away to the galleries of ancient houses of immigrants (named conventillos) and enjoy rare objects that can be found in little stores or street sellers. This place is tourist friendly, so you can walk safetly for the streets.I recomended to visit San Pedro Telmo church, in front of the first Buenos Aires Medical school (now an elementary school), The Russian Orthodox Church and the Lezama Park. Near to San Telmo you may visit Madero harbour (Puerto Madero), a beauiful and quoted sector of Buenos Aires. Every places has public access, so you don´t have to pay to stay, except private spectacles. Enjoy!!!

Loved the Sunday Market. Fun place to shop for local goods crafted by artisans. Also, there are several really beautiful churches, many with ties to Pope Francis to visit. We really enjoyed shopping the market and purchasing belts and some jewelry. We also got to see some tango dancing! In addition, local food and treats are being sold throughout if you need a snack.
Must go on Sunday. It 's one of the place you have to visit in BA , on sunday afternoon they open market full of antiques . There is also a lot of street performance .

Tango and kids. Start early and enjoy strolling and shopping the market starting from Plaza do Mayo towards Plaza Dorrego. There are actually talented artisans scattered in and about here. Sample choripan along the route (and, if you pass a Columbiana hawking pan de yuca, do yourself a favor and buy at least one). Enjoy (and tip) the elderly tango dancers near the Starbucks, but don’t miss the real tango happening in the center of Plaza Dorrego. Around 4pm, an expert group of dancers trade off and perform for tips alone. My 6 year old is mesmerized every time we go. It’s really the only kid-friendly tango show in town.

Experience the soul of Buenos Aires. San Telmo is one of the oldest neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. You can find the best antique shops all over the place. Do not miss the Mercado de San Telmo where you can still buy groceries and food as well like in the old days. In Sundays there is a massive street market with antiques and amazing articles. Traffic is not allowed and antiques are offered ll over the places. There are also street performers that makes the experience even better. Nice cofee shops and restaurants are available. Highly recommended.

At its best on Sundays. On sundays a huge market runs all the way along Av Defensa. Its full of artisan items and towards the centre of San Telmo in Plaza Dorrego there is an antiques market. There were also lots of street performers. A very cool old man was performing a live Tango show next to the Plaza which was definitely worth watching. The cobbled streets of the area and the beautiful buildings all combine to create a very enjoyable atmosphere. We loved this are of Buenos Aires.

San Telmo (and Sunday thieves). We stayed in San Telmo, in an apartment and a hotel, so we didn't have to go far to see its cobblestone streets and graffitied buildings. It has many cafes and restaurants, some worth more than one visit. There are a number of these in Plaza Dorrego, a favourite spot. San Telmo also has antique shops, bars, a permanent market and a weekend street market on every Sunday, which stretches far down the street. However, the large number of tourists in the area on Sundays attracts thieves. During the day we were molested on three (!!!) different occasions by thieves whose trick involves spraying you from behind with a foul smelling concoction meant to resemble bird poo. They then helpfully draw your attention to it and pretend to help wipe you down with the newspaper or paper towels that, very conveniently, they happen to be carrying. Since we'd read about this scam, they didn't steal anything, but by third attempt to spray us we were rather annoyed.The rest of our stay there was uneventful, however. We went out to dinner each night without any concerns for our safety, taking no more than the precautions usual in any city.

Beautiful on Sunday. I'm not sure if this is referring to a specific group of shops but if you're here on a Sunday you have to take a walk through the seemingly unending street bizarre that extends down this street almost all the way south to La Boca. Lots of interesting knick knacks including some handmade clothing and accessories. My boyfriend bought a handmade leather belt for almost nothing. There's street performers, food vendors; a fun way to spend the afternoon.

Do not miss this great flea market. On weekends, the streets of SanTelmo are turned into a wonderful flea market with lots of things to purchase such as handcrafted souvernirs, leather goods, clothing, shoes and you can even get a neck massage.It can be crowded but it is so worth it! And to top it off a coffee and a sandwich in the neighbourhood or stopping up to listen to the street musicians playing on their cello and, if lucky, some dancers to entertain the crowd.

Just a market. Wasn't really anything special, although it's worth seeing if you're in the area on a Sunday morning. Careful: our hotel manager was really concerned about us bringing a backpack or purse - i guess thieves are really active there. We left them at the hotel. (We'd had a problem on a previous day with someone targetting us due to our backpacks in front of the senate building. They sprayed brown liquid on us, told us it was the pigeons and "generously" offered to help us get cleaned up. They didn't manage to steal anything from us though.)

o lot junk but fun to see people and tango dancers. a lot of worthless old stuff being sold, I wouldn't buy any of that. Poor restaurants, don't go eat there either. But worth spending two hours watching people and tango dancers.

San Telmo. This is the best antique show I have attended in a long time. But only on Sundays do they have the San Telmo flea market. You can find just about anything, but mostly stuff that has to do with some of the traditional Buenos Aires old stuff. Be careful, sometimes they try to put one over you with the prices. However, haggling is OK and expected.
Not Impressed. All it is is a tourists trap. Not much to see, not much I wanted to buy, and not much I wanted to eat. I give you this - it is different!!

flea market central. If you like to shop and browse and are not particular of the quality, this is a must go to place when in Buenos Aires. The stalls along the street extended for blocks and perhaps a mile or more. I'm not sure about the price, but the quality did not seem that high. A lot of home made/artisanal products that may have appeal to some and no appeal to others. The place is very crowded too and at the very least an experience that one must have when in Buenos Aires.

Something for everyone.. Great grills, tango dancing on the street, fresh squeezed orange juice, flowers, crafts, antiques and so much more. I was there on a Saturday and I am not sure if the stalls are open every day. It was a stop on the Hop on Hop Off bus..Good souvieners

Very interesting place. I spent the whole day in Mercado San Telmo. A lot of musicians, stalls with very interesting staff, coffe shops, open grills, souvenirs, gifts,... Especially tango dancers have attracted my attention. More when the day turns into night, more the visitors to get into the scene. Very funny! "Must see" in Buenos Aires!

MERCADO SAN TELMO is a must!!. This area is full of artisanal bars and shops, along with antique shops. I checked out Mercado San Telmo market, for my love of local markets. And I found out it was not just a daily goods market. Actually only 1/3 of the stores were the grocers and the rest are antique and vintage shops! I could find Vespa cap, signs of library, and vintage suitcase stickers! They make special souvenirs. And in the middle of the market is a charming coffee shop, which I didn't get to have a cup, but it looked really good.

Very pleasant neighborhood!. It really worth spending some time there, walking around.You can find many small (and not so small!) shops selling very nice handicraft, and antiques.There are many coffee shops and parks, also.Going there on weekdays (not on Mondays, when many shops are closed) is better than on weekends.

San Telmo, Birthplace of Tango. Although La Boca is more famous, this neighborhood exudes nostalgia and grace. There are pleasant cafes, including one where I asked for apple juice with my cafe and croissant, and they ground it fresh like a smoothie. The landmark here is the French Solar, named after a Mr. French. San Telmo is a step back in time, very European, and slow-paced. We walked it one morning after an "espactulo" which demonstrated and narrated the history of tango, which included dinner (steak of course). I loved the lilt of Argentine Spanish, which they call Castellano, and it was interesting to be told that my Spanish has a North American accent (when I go to New York, they tell me my Spanish has a West Coast accent). San Telmo is off the beaten path but just ask any taxi driver and he can take you to a good starting point to explore.

Lovely antique shops. Nice area, worth a stroll. There are plenty of antique shops with every manner of antiquity squirrelled away. Keep going until you get to teh square, tehre are a couple of tango dancers who perform at lunch time, and if you fancy a more substantial lunch, there's a nice Italian on the first floor overlooking the square.
The neighborhood where to stay. Hurry to stay there before rampant gentrification kills its unique atmosphere. Easily travelled on foot. Small but varied.

Artistic and cultural delights. After a visit to San Telmo you may fall in love with Buenos Aires and put it in your list of favourite cities. This little district south of Plaza de Mayo is home to an eclectic mix of boutique shops, art galleries and restaurants filled with the rhythm of tango. The main cobbled street Defense is a good place to start your exploration of the area. On Sunday this comes alive with the Flea Market. It feels very safe, even down side streets. It is obviously a very creative and tolerant part of the city. I found gay bars and extensive street art around the backstreets. Walk down Calle Balcarce to see some brilliant graffiti. There are information panels around the district which describe notable buildings in the area - too many to mention here. One is the narrowest building in the city down Pasaje San Lorenzo.

Beautiful historic cool area. Buenos Aires is so versatile. There are areas like Puerto Madero, all brand new and there areas like San Telmo. Is so beautiful and fabulous, so many bars and cool restaurants. During the day is nice but at night can be a bit unsafe. You have to be careful with people asking for money since they are studding you and what you have. I love defensa street, lots of beautiful buildings and lots of history

something in between chaotic and vintage. its an area where you can find old but recycled buildings right beside and old, destroyed and occupied by homeless building. You can also find great places for furniture, art, bars and restaurantes. Totally worth a visit, just take care at night to avoid streets without people.

It doesn't get more "porteno" than this. San Telmo, is so traditional tango and Buenos Aires as it gets. Sunday's flea market is fantastic, just to roam around and see not only trinkets but also the area in daylight. It has many options for tango shows at night, some more touristy than others, all worth your time if you love a show of fantastically well danced tango.

Buzzing Sunday market. We arrived in Buenos Aires on a Sunday and after reading the reviews here, we knew we mustn't miss this. For some reason, our transfer guide had advised us not to stay there past 5-6pm, stating that some of the nearby side roads can be a bit dangerous. We took her advice as it was our first time in Argentina but in hindsight, I think we probably missed out by doing this as I think this is when more of the locals come out, more of the street dancing etc happens - it certainly didn't feel dangerous or threatening in any way when we were there but perhaps there is more that I'm not aware of.The market itself was fabulous - so buzzing, lively, crowded but not in an unpleasant way - there is something for everyone with a good mix of antiques, food, jewellery, handicrafts. There are places to sit down and eat and drink eg. we stopped for some traditional street food in a makeshift cafe with some live music. It has a real feel-good sense about it. We had read a lot of reviews about watching out for pickpockets.We therefore took precaution with this - my husband padlocked his rucksack and we saw many men carrying their rucksacks on their fronts. I held onto my bag at all times and just took general common-sense precautions and we were fine. The roads are all quite pedestrianised with cobblestones - this is fine but choose your footwear accordingly - I went in just flip flops and found them a bit uncomfortable on the stones.Don't expect everyone to speak English (not that they should, I just wish my Spanish was a bit better!) but we saw a few tourists really struggling to order food in English from street vendors - if you're going to come to a lovely local market like this, it'll help to be equipped with a few basic phrases.What's nice as well is that people don't really hassle you too much if you do just want to browse, which is something that can be a real problem in other parts of the world so I found that quite refreshing here.I'm so glad we did this on a Sunday in Buenos Aires - it's great fun and a wonderful place to buy gifts or souvenirs of traditionally made items.
Nice. Is a cool place to go, on Sundays is very full of people and you can see local artists, is a pleasant walk to do.

Antiquing at its Best. If you're the kind of person for whom "antiquing" is an activity - or even a word - San Telmo's your place! Although noted for tango, the antique shops in San Telmo are much more reliable for quality. You can find everything - if you move away from the street vendors and take the time to go inside the shops. I even found one lovely vintage lingerie shop with absolutely exquisite 20s era gown. Art Deco pieces hide out in the smallest most remote stalls. Everything and more for the dedicated and experienced antique, and an exciting experience for the novice.The restaurants are hit or miss, and you can find decent tango pretty much anywhere (some of the best in Palermo), but the antique shops in San Telmo are not to be outdone - and it need not be a Sunday (but don't go on Monday).

Great market street on Sundays.. Have a great time wandering the markets in the streets, and some indoor areas with loads of stalls. You will also see a few outdoor street performers. Quite a few cafes and ice cream parlours as you meander around. Good fun.

If you are in BA on a Sunday, be HERE!. Everything from antiques, to leather goods, to street performers, to a myriad of local handcrafted goods and jewelry and that's just in the market that goes on for blocks and blocks and blocks! Then there are the shops on the streets that start opening up around noon and the side streets that lead to other established markets with everything from meat to produce, pastries and cheeses. Plenty of restaurant options all around...great people watching as the locals seem to enjoy the social aspect the market as much as the tourists do the spectacle of it all! A great way to spend a lazy Sunday in the city.

Not that good. If you're looking for antiques, this is not the place. There are a few antique stores that may be interesting but the sunday feir is terrible. You will see junk -old and new - and risk being pickpocketed. Since I'm the kind of person who likes to see for myself, it was worth the visit for the music band that was playing at the square.

Better than expected. We came here late afternoon and our taxi driver dropped us off where the street was a bit bare, bland and the stalls were already closing! We walked down a bit further and the atmosphere just came alive. Heaps of people lining the streets, street vendors, little trinkets here and there, small shops inside a few old buildings, live music and great freshly squeezed orange juice from a small cart on the side of the road. Such a pleasant surprise and really such a bohemian type feel/culture.
since mostly everything is closed on Sunday. this a good place to spend Sunday and buy your souvenirs and watch street performers and get your choripan and biondola. It doesn't get going till 11 am.

San Telmo Fair. We walked the length of the fair, ending at the Plaza de Mayo. Wandering through the antiques and curiosities, stopping to admire the jewellery and leather works along the way, and visiting the Convent of St Francis, it was a delightful way to spend Easter morning! I noted a vendor remind a tourist to wear his camera bag strap across his chest. Vendors were helpful and pleasant in dealing with our English and poor Spanish!

A weekend delight!. Heard that there was a weekend market so we started at the autopista end and walked the length of Calle Defensa all the way to Plaza Mayo. Encountered a delightful collection of street vendors ranging from (my favorite) artists selling their own quirky creations, to antique dealers, to resellers of cheap artsy kitsch. Highlight? The mid day lunch of chori-pan (sausage - on - bread). Yum!

The San Telmo fair is a must. Went on a Sunday, a lovely local fair. It doesn't have the feeling of a tourist trap - most of visitors are locals that just have fun. The fair is very large in the authentic San Telmo quarter - it offers all the you can think of - antiques, hand crafts, souvenirs etc. Plenty of coffee shops, nice restaurants and street shows, Tango dancing and so. The atmosphere is very relaxed - a very nice place to visit on a weekend..

Great market...but watch your valuables. We visited the San Telmo Sunday market in March. Lots of antiques, character and other crafts. Also interesting old colonial architecture. However, in spite of what we thought was a perfect place to hide our phone....it was pickpocketed at the far end (away from the square) of the flea market. Looking back, there was a group of young women blocking the center of the street, who didn't seem to want to move, forcing people to squeeze by...and that's likely where the dastardly deed occurred. Getting robbed can happen anywhere (although first time for us while travelling), but one thing that troubles us was the total lack of police presence in an area known for theft from tourists. We saw police everywhere during our 2 1/2 weeks in Argentina - in the smallest of towns, in safer areas like Recoleta or smaller cities including Salta or Mendoza...having a few officers on foot patrols would at least demonstrate that Buenos Aires takes crime seriously. We're rating this a "3" as the market is quite fun and interesting, but watch your stuff.

A must do on Sunday. It is all about the San Telmo market on Sunday's. That is all there is to it. A several kilometer stretch of leather goods, jewelry, and antiques... all at ridiculously cheap prices. It is a great place to load up on gifts for family and friends at a bargain.

San Telmo Suburb of Antiques and Tango. I love the weekend market stretchen all the street Defensa from Plaza de Mayo to the Autopista. The variety of stalls and the culinarious offers have something for every taste.One can spend the whole day exploring. The stall holders are very ridgit and don't allow haggling. Howerver, their merchandise is not overprice. A great day out exploring the taste and culture of Buenos Aires.

Lot's of antiques, and you might even catch a great tango band. You can easily spend a full day wandering through the old cobblestone streets of San Telmo. Have lunch at a great parrilla, and a leisurely afternoon tea in Plaza Dorrego. Many antique stores, museums, churches, markets, cafes and restaurants. If you don't mind crowds, go on the weekend and catch the street markets. You might even catch live tango music on the street, ( Fernandez Fiero are not your average tango orchestra, they look more like a rock band) and the odd dance performance too. A word of caution about safety though, crime is on the rise, where it used to be harmless pick-pocketing, it is getting increasingly violent. ( no doubt to the economic situation). You will see armed police on some street corners again, (like it was 10 - 15 years ago), especially in areas frequented by tourists and the wealthy Portenos.

Quaint. What a quaint part of the city. This has the cobblestone streets, cute shops and great restaurants. It also is where a lot of the Tango shows are. A very touristy section of town but a great place to just wander and take in the sights and sounds. Sitting at the outdoor cafes will often have you seeing a couple or two doing the tango. Great vibe.

Antiques and street market. The Sunday street market is too crowded for my taste and lots of the stuff fits my definition of trinkets. The area is nice to walk around at other times as well The antique stores are amazing, some nice jewelry stores (silver) and clothing boutiques.
Close to Mayo Plaza. Loved our hotel (Moreno), but felt the area was quite rundown. However, still was safe, touristy, and close to many nearby areas & sights that you can walk to.

Very good. San Telmo is a neighborough you can t miss, lots of fine antique shops , in the center of it there is a plaza with coffe bar and smal restaurants where you can watch couplesdancing the tango

The place for antiques. This cobblestone part of town is very romantic and quaint feeling, here you almost forget you are in a city of millions. There are shops upon shops of antiques from art deco to 60s kitsch, but the Sunday market is where you can find some gems. Get there early before the masses invade.

Buenos Aires best attraction. If you are lucky enough to be in Buenos Aires on a Sunday you have to spend your afternoon at this market on Defensa ave. , which has everything from crafts , leather, antiques, food and music and tango. I just wish I could have spent more time but our flight was leaving at 6 pm . It left me wanting more of Argentina! Best tourist thing to do in Buenos Aires so glad I was able to get a few hours experiencing this gem of a market. Vendors are very friendly and not aggressive sales like in some markets of the world.

Enjoy your Sunday afternoon with tango. San Telmo has a huge antique market on Sunday afternoons, but the real attraction is the tango dancing in the central square. The folks who perform there are first class and worth dropping some pesos into the hat after the show. Very seductive dance and a chance to do some yourself after they finish.

Wonderfully scenic street and square. This neighborhood has one scenic street and a very atmospheric square. This is a great place to shop for antiques and indie clothing. The square has excellent coffee and ice cream. Try the Super Dulce de Leche at Iceland, and watch tango dancers perform for tips as you sip a coffee or drink a beer.

Top rate market and first-rate attraction .... just go!. The weekend is this busy city is much quieter and this is one of the top attractions for visitors, so allow 2-3 hours to walk the half a mile of sellers along a road called "Defensa". You can buy all manner of tourist and practical items along with a wide range of food. Look also at the side malls in which are hiiden many cafes and shops of interest. Don't rush, take it all in, take your camera and when you reach the plaza at the end, buy a coffee and watch the tango dancers.

Sunday people watching and shopping..... This is a great way to spend a couple of hours on Sunday afternoon. Great people watching, local shopping and local eateries make for an enjoyable day. The flee market has indoor and outdoor markets. enjoy!

Unique experience. My husband and I spent one morning exploring San Telmo during a weekday. Defensa and Boliva were beautiful streets with a unique feel. We absolutely loved going into the many different antique stores and exploring. If you are an antiquer, like us, you will be in heaven and we found many, many things we only wished we could take back to home with us. After a stroll and a stop at the penitentiary museum, we stopped for lunch at the plaza, which was excellent. Overall, the area didn't offer much beyond the two streets and definitely be careful of pickpockets. However, the area had life and was a great experience. After our first visit to San Telmo, we will definitely be going to the Sunday market on our next stay in Buenos Aires.

Bohemian, gritty, inviting and just damned inspiring!. This is by far my favourite district of BA, and I actually wish I had stayed here instead of Palermo! The Sunday markets are a sight to be seen- sprawling, vibrant and buzzing in all the best ways! Plenty of cafes and bars, all which seem to have a more grounded and earthy vibe than the gaudy pretence of the Palermo scene. On one particular Saturday, there was a community BBQ with great live music; that really lifted my spirits as I was particular homesick and little bit lonely on that day :) Had some amazing pasta at a restaurant I can’t remember and was served by the kindest old man at some quite corner side cafe. I also picked up some great vintage clothes at one of the many second hand stores, and some out of print English books on art, communism and Picasso. I would go back to BA, just to spend time in this fantastic place! Of course you need to be vigilant since pick pockets and petty theives abound, but that is what makes San Telmo a part of the real BA, with all its grandeur and troubles.

Sunday Evening in San Telmo. while San Telmo is justly praised for its plethora of fine art deco antique store and ambience, it is San Telmo on a sunday evening that will remain a highlight for me of my trips to BA. Around 8pm the locals relax from the weekend crowds and tango in the Plaza Dorego. Young and old mix to share in the joy of a well danced tango under the stars. This isn't an event staged for tourists, rather it is a local and very personal evocation of what tango means to Argentinians. The joy and beauty of these dancers speak volumes about the beauty of the Argentinian soul. On other corners of the Plaza informal groups of drummers beat out rhythms that combine African and South American themes and dance in the streets. The scene is eclectic and entirely real...it reminds me of similar scenes I witnessed in Havana. Pure joy, pure emotion, pure enjoyment for us.

True Buenos Aires neighborhood . Very nice and typical Buenos Aires neighborhood. Plenty of nice restaurants. Be aware for thieves. Tourists cannot forget to watch their belongings, pay attention to their surroundings and cannot wear watches, jewelry, etc.

Be careful !!!!. Started my stay in BA with the Sunday market in San Telmo. I was mugged in the middle of the day. It was noon a man came up from behind me and we went to the ground and he tugged on my watch until the metal band broke. The police saw the man a bit too late - they gave chase but he got away. If you go to San Telmo or La Boca DO NOT wear any jewelry, watch your cameras and handbags. I have traveled to many international large cities and had no trouble. Go but be alert more than usual. Most of the other areas in the city are beautiful and safe.

Fishy fish and chips. Great place and people. Great vibe. Great beer. And what used to be the best fish and chips in the city. But the last few times it has been super 'fishy' tasting. You know what I mean. Is the fish old or did you change the type you are buying. Please fix this.

Walk and walk and walk.... Sure a walk through the Sunday market is a must... if you must.For me San Telmo was best at night... all night... walking on the nearly empty streets, with the feeling that the old buildings were coming to life.The little corner bars, are open with a table and chair on the sidewalk, a couple of people from the neighborhood... And of course there are the cooler bars, if you have the local insider scoop and find out which unmarked door you have to find.

first stop after hotel. had to see the flea market on sunday so off we went.....not disappointed!! lots of color, flavor and great start to our family trip (even being separated for 30 min. as wife and daughter went side shopping). stopped in for lunch at some local restaurant along the path (wouldn't recommend but can't remember the name, sorry) first taste of empanadas and BA feel.

Sunday market in San Telmo. We walked along Defensa from Av de Mayo right up to San Telmo Square, which is a great route and took about an hour in the crowds. The streets were lined with vast amounts of hand craft stalls selling all manner of things. Great way to spend a Sunday, we loved it and rounded it off with lunch in San Telmo.

Lively, bargains and Tango!. We visited the market on a Sunday and had a great time. It wasn't too hot in November and we walked both parts of the market. One side leads to San Telmo square where we enjoyed some Tango dancing. My wife bought a lovely floral leather bag that has been greatly admired by many since our return to the U.K. On the other side of the main road we discovered Brasserie Petanque where we had a most enjoyable lunch. My wife then had her picture taken with a Jack Sparrow look-alike. Lots of different music as you walk along - all in all, a good day out.

Market day - San Telma. We went the the market today. While it was hot there was not a dull moment. Listened to some great music, saw Tango for the first time and purchased some artwork and have good memories of the market. Highly recommended.

Taste of "real" Argentina. Came here on a very hot Sunday afternoon. The market is huge, goes on for many blocks and there is a huge array of items for sale. Lots of junk, antiques (although I am not a good judge of "good" antiques), hand made knick knacks, kitsch, clothing etc. it was very hot so it was tough to wander. We did come upon a parking lot that had some shelter and there was a makeshift BBQ restaurant serving up the most delicious lomito we have had so far. Cold Cervezas and a young couple doing the tango on a plank of wood for tips. It was dirty, gritty and seemingly authentic. We sat on plastic tables, broken cobblestones beneath our feet and some rusty tin over our heads. It was pure heaven. The couple really showed us why he tango is so sexy. We didn't buy anything but it was a very enjoyable way to spend the afternoon. Very crowded.
sunday. if you like antiques it's the place to visit on a sunday. the square abs surroundings are very nice to stroll, there are tango dancing and you can get a coll beer around the square

Tango. Plaza Durrango is a great place to sit , drink and watch a tango or two. I liked this area. We walked lots and there are interesting OLD buildings lots of character and a boho feeling. Antique stores are of interest and just seeing the people is a kick. Fleur, a pretty girl from bus 130 directed us to this district and it was very different from the rest of Buenos Aires. Again lots of graffiti, crumbling old mansions and a huge old bldg with tons of gorgeous crystal chandeliers. We went at a quiet time but worth the walk.

Sunday at San Telmo a must. Not just a tourist attraction, ST is a weekly gathering spot for locals and travelers alike.The crafts range from mundane junk to exceptional rarities. But it is the entire experience which merits a visit. Food, drink, music, artisans…just go!
