The only place to be on Sunday when visiting Buenos Aires. Like other reports say, this market goes on for miles and is well worth it. The shopping can be interesting and the people watching is second to none. There is a lot of junk for sale but also some very interesting artisan stalls that are worth checking out. If you are with people, do yourself a favor and make arrangements to meet at the end in plazza durrango. This market is big, you will separate so best to cut your loses and plan to meet at the end. This will allow everyone to enjoy at their own pace and celebrate together over wine or beer at the end.

Music, Food, Shopping and Culture!. The San Telmo market on Sundays is just amazing. You can find great groups playing tango or any other kind of good music on the street, have local food as the Choripan or a great cheeseburger at Perez-H, can buy little gifts or visit the underground historic city.
Amazing flea market, great cultural area. Very nice area, people dancing tango in the middle of the street, lots of artisans, guitar players... very cultural. Must-do.

Do not miss San Telmo market on a Sunday afternoon. To see "EI Indio" (Pedro Benavente) dance was worth it alone to see the Tango become an art form. He performs ona Sunday afternoon and has done for years. He is amazing (Find "El indio" on YouTube) - it is best free show in BA! Do not miss if you get the opportunity.The rest of the market is fun. When we were there, many stall holders were in terrific costumes (see photos). I do not know if this is a regular thing or just some sort of festival day. Usual variety of market mechandise from junk to quite nice souveniers and clothes. Also, many stall along the side streets and up Defensa street.To find the event, you must go to Plaza Dorrego (rather than Marcedo San Telmo which is a block away). El Indio performs inside the square on Suday afternoons

Tourist market; watch your pockets. I'm not a "market" person, but went to see what the fuss is about. If you like bumping shoulders with others who enjoy trinkets or old stuff (debatably referred to as "antiques") then you will probably enjoy his place on a Sunday. If not, don't bother. You will wade through 15 blocks of people gawking at "junk" and calling San Telmo "charming colonial" is a sound exaggeration. Through in the ever-present chance you could find yourself sans wallet after a visit here and you might prefer to just sleep in after your Saturday night out.

Watch your pockets and soak in the activity. This is one of the most beautiful areas in Buenos Aires, where you can find the colonial style of the city and also many things to do. I would recommend going for a stroll down Defensa street on Sundays

The market goes for Miles!. Watch your pockets and soak in the activity. This Sunday market that runs the course of La Defensa for miles has more for sale than one could ever imagine. I have never seen such an enormous grouping of individuals selling things. Who's left to shop? Plenty of people, apparently. Choices are vast, and most things are cheap. We had already shopped for two weeks and our bags were full. I told my wife, "No more!" But it is impossible to leave this place without buying something you thought you never needed or wanted. Savor the spectacle of what shopping was once like everywhere!

Do not miss it!. This is one of the most beautiful areas in Buenos Aires, where you can find the colonial style of the city and also many things to do. I would recommend going for a stroll down Defensa street on Sundays. There´s a market where you can buy just about anything. Also restaurants, bars and clubs, so fun at night, too. A classic of Buenos Aires!

Antiques in the Plaza Dorrego. Every time I go to Buenos Aires I try to go to San Telmo on a Sunday and make a bee line for the Plaza and I always buy lots of fun antiques; usually at a good price (if buying with dollars). The open market always has something to offer and later I nip over to the Dorrego Cafe or La Pergola for a beer and some cheese and ham. A wonderful day out and don't forget to haggle.

Beautiful place to visit on sundays if you are an antique lover. On sundays vendors come out to the street and is a beautiful place to hang out. They are really good vintage restaurants that you should go!

Charming, and authentic. Fun area in Buenos Aires. Narrow cobble stone streets with tons of antique shops, restaurants, bars, and shops. Wear flat shoes for your visit. The sidewalks and streets are not for high heels. Everything is open very late and the area generally felt quite safe

Best on a Market day. It is probably best to go nice and early in the day to avoid some of the crowds. Most of the items for sale are antiques and hand made crafts and some real bargains can had. There is some fantastic live music as well. I would suggest not to bring a backpack as it gets quite crowded and you need to keep a close eye on your belongings as we were told pick pockets can be a real problem.

Good but overwhelming and a bit junky on market day. I would suggest to go to San Telmo twice. Once on market day (Sunday) and once on a non-market day. The market has some nice things, but also has lots of junk. Some fake antiques in the market stalls for sale at real antique prices. The antique shops are more genuine than the stalls. Feel free to haggle on price.

Variety of Interesting Stuffs to buy/watch.. =). Sunday would be the best time to visit the area. It's a very long line of street market with several musicians/entertainers to watch as you walk along to the end of the street. You can buy variety of souvenirs in this place. Decent restaurants are also found along the streets. It's better to check the weather before coming into this place. Probably not a good idea to go on a rainy day.. Good luck.

Another great Buenos Aires area. When visiting BA you must, of course, visit the San Telmo area; a big attraction is the Sunday outdoor street market that seems to go on forever. Have seen such a large outdoor artisan market anywhere else on the planet. Lots of great people watching too. But be prepared for crowds.

Weird. San Telmo is tourist heaven. And justifiably so. The market is an eclectic mix of dressed up stall holders selling antiques and other stuff. They vary from Laurel and Hardy to Native American Indians and Zombie brides. It is a very interesting neighbourhood architecturally speaking, but also a cultural melting-pot that never feels threatening. The empanadas in the different cafes are excellent too! Highly recommended even if you are in BA for just one day.

Glad we visited the flea market. We were not so sure about visiting a flea market thinking that they are all one and the same. The experience was amazing we walked around for hours as it was so festive. Street side tango....all kinds of stuff to buy (we just bought a few items). We went to amici de (italian restaurant) on the first floor on the main street. must visit if you are in BA on a sunday. We went there are visiting the pink palace.

Don't miss the sunday's flea market. San Telmo is a very nice neighborhood in Buenos Aires.Lots of restaurants, bars, nice enviroment.The key point in San Telmo's is its flea market on Sundays, if you are in BUE in a Sunday, don't miss it! Really worth it!!

So far our favourite Barrio.... Restaurants abound! This area is very eclectic, fun and full of antique shops... Don't miss the Sunday market in the street! The streets are easy to navigate. By SubTe, get off at Independencia and head over for a great time!

Visit it on Sundays. You can go to San Telmo any given day, but you will get it's best on a Sunday, because that's when the Feria happens!  There will be many street vendors selling all kinds of things, from food to souvenirs, clothes or antiques, and you will surely find whatever you look for.

Sunday street markets are fantastic. Tango exhibitions in the square, booth after booth of antiques, collectibles and Argentina chotchkies. We had lunch at Amici Miei Ristorante, and snagged a balcony table overlooking all of the melee below. Very, very crowded on a lovely February afternoon, but worth the crowd management!

San Telmo is Special. Yes! San Telmo is a zoo on Sunday..be careful, be crushed, be hungry but know that only in this place is there an antique, tango and people circus with no admission charged. The vendors have invaded Defensa but take a street on either side and enjoy the express lanes to Plaza Dorrego.The really nice time to visit (after experiencing Sunday) is walking around on the uncrowded and casual weekdays. You can get into great cafes and restaurants...you can stand back and admire the old buildings and street art...you can wander into the beautiful Mercado San Telmo (circa 1897) with easy entry off many streets. It is a working market with stalls of fruit, meats and shops of all kinds. In the very middle is the Coffee Town kiosk..Many portenos rate this has having the best coffee in town...I agree.. (Starbucks has opened on the Square...but support the locals if you can).

One of the nicest areas of BA. this district of the city is easy to find and a great place for some good food, cold beers and nice old antique shops even better on a Sunday as the markets are going on, more to see here than in Boca or Puerto Madero
Photo Tour of san Telmo. I toured san Telmo on a walking photo tour. The architecture and wall paintings where wonderful and are worth seeing on a long 4 hour walk

Eclectic old neighborhood that mixes the oldest and hippest of Buenos Aires. This is a great place to discover small cafés and old restaurants as well as cool new botiques and eateries. Make sure you so to the Sunday market on Defensa - every tiny from tourist trinkets to great artisanal crafts and antiques. Parts of this neighborhood may look a little scary because of the graffiti, but I never felt concerned day or night.

SIMPLY A MUST. San Telmo is a district of Buenos Airea adjacaent to Boca, Puerto Madero and the City Centre. Butt it has a character all of its own, with numerous restraurants, cafes, bars, antique shops and arccades, as well as some iimpressive wall murals.Sunday is the best day to visit the district as there is a flea market offering local handicrafts, antiquees, toys and traditional style clothing.The easiest way to find the flea market and San Telmo from the City Centre is to walk Eastwards doown Florida. In about half an hour you reach the main shopping street.On Sundays the flea market seems to stretch from Florida in the city centre all the way to San Telmo and out the otherside. A relaxed stroll can take a few hours, especially if taking in all the stallls, shopping and antique arcades en route.Refreshments are available from the many restaurants, bars and cafes along the way, as well as from the mobile street vendors plying their wares amongst the crowds.Definitely a must for a relaxed, but interesting shopping expedition on a Buenos Aires Sunday.

Go on Sunday!. The neighborhood is one of the oldest in Buenos Aires. Full of cafes, restaurants and antique shops. On Sundays there is flea market although not very unexpensive. There is also a craft fair so you have plenty to see. It can be combined with other sights if you don´thave much time like the Plaza de Mayo, cafe Tortoni, Cathedral.

viejo BsAs. very touristic^place where to buy some very very expensive antiquities.some touristic shows of very average dancers...A nice place very cmlose from vinotango where to buy good argentinian wines

My visit to San Telmo. After checking online and asking friends who are locals in Buenos Aires, I was told that San Telmo was a 'must visit' place most especially since it looked like 'balogun market' in 'Lagos Island' where I come from and I looked forward to it. I was told to be careful because it was filled with thieves, pick pockets and all sorts, fortunately, my visit to san telmo (with a bunch of African friends) was devoid of such nasty experiences. I will have gone with a digital camera to snap the market and with enough money to buy soverniers. Overall, it was fun been there and I discovered that the porpular Florida street shopping centre is on the same lane as San Telmo

Only at Sunday. One of our Sundays at Buenos Aires we went to San Telmo, in particular to Defensa street and Plaza Dorrego. There is a flea market at Plaza Dorrego we walked around then headed to Defensa street, it is about 11 or 12 blocks long and ends at Plaza De Mayo. At both sides of the street there are many stands selling all kinds of souvenirs at decent prices. Few closed markets are also available with some open air restaurants and cafés. This is a nice place for shopping at Sunday.

Paseo de la historieta. There is a "path of the comic" with statues of argentine comics that lead to the "comics museum". The comics museum is kind of boring to me, but my family liked it better than me.

Worth a visit. Everyone told us that if we were in BA on a Sun, we should go. Gave us a good excuse to take the Supte, which was a good, easy trip and cost about 50 cents each. We wandered around for a few hours, first in the main plaza and then down the long street where vendors sold new items. Grabbed some lunch before heading back to hotel .

outdoor fair. A great outdoor fair with antiques and local artisan products on Sunday. Some of buildings are picturesque. There are lots antique stores, small restaurants, cafés, and even a Starbucks.
great place to wonder around. A longside the great market is an old restaurant that sells amazing empanads ! The actual restaurant does not look like it has changed since the 30's -

San Telmo. Sunday Markets a must when visiting B.A.. Visited San Telmo area on a friday when the area is quiet. Checked out the old buildings that are full of character and history. Revisited San Telmo on a Sunday when the area is transformed into a hive of activity during market day. A must to do for visitors to B.A.

Cute, Very Euro-Style!. Loved the area. Cobble stone streets & little hills similar to streets of Europe. Charming area indeed. Beware at night. Not for the tourist to roam around. Very safe during daytime.

Crowded but worth it. San Telmo on Sundays has gotten even more crowded over the 20+ years I've been coming to Buenos Aires but still worth a visit. The central market is a bit claustrophobic but once you venture down the side streets to visit the small antique shops the atmosphere improves dramatically. Plenty of restaurants in the area.

Fun, but hang on to your stuff. We enjoyed strolling, browsing and shopping, but a word of warning: keep your stuff firmly in hand. We stopped in a cafe, left a backpack at our feet while having coffee, which someone tried to switch for an empty backpack. The waitress alerted us and we ran after the guy, forcing him to toss the backpack and run off. So a good ending for us, but if the waitress hadn't spotted it, we would not have realized until it was too late. The area is well known for pickpockets, purse snatchers, etc so just remember to be alert.

Sunday markets and Tango!. Ok, we haven't seen every district of Buenos Aires, but still, I think San Telmo is one of the best places to go in BA. We really felt safe here (day and night) and specially on Sunday you will have a real good time here!On Sunday, start your trip at Plaza Dorrego. Big chance to see one of the free Tango show (don't forget a small donation). Going south from this market you will find some nice artwork, paintings and antique. Going either north or east you will find all kind of marketshops, from clothes to souvenirs, books, vinyl, antique, traditional Fileteados etc. for very reasonable prices.Lunch tip: get some empanadas from the people walking around with baskets full. They are cheap and good!
not to be missed. A visit to B.A. is not complete with out a visit to this section. Sunday's street market is a hoot with mimes and tango dancers. Excellent restaurants through out the area

best place to get handcraft and antique. there is huge handcraft and antique market on Sunday. If you are visiting from US dont convert all your dollar to peso in the bank, you may get a better exchange rate in the market!

Fun, beautiful neighbourhood. Nice place to visit because of the market and liveliness (tango/music) on the streets. Had lunch at a restaurant in a small courtyard that served the best argentinian steak.
Lets to shopping. shopping at San Telmo was an awesome experience, from a tango dance, to shopping from local Artisans, to eating pizza or street empanadas. It is truly an experience.

Tango, and more. San Telmo has not only Tango places it also has a good antique market 'Mercado San Telmo' and some of the best parrillas in Buenos Aires. Be careful with the poop from dogs when you are walking around and do not go with any thing of value. The subway station San Juan leaves you at no more than 7 blocks from the main plaza Dorrego, Usually the free tango shows are on Sundays and the plaza Dorrego is cover with antiques stands. The free Tango classes start around 5pm and you can stay in the bars for more professional dancing shows.

Everyone said it was charming, but.... Unfortunately, I found the area to be quite run down and covered with graffiti. We went to Defensa on Sunday to the open market, and it was just an Argentina swap meet with local Rastafarians.

My favorite neighborhood!. Some people prefer Palermo, but I love San Telmo best of all. It has a wonderful artist vibe and feels a little more like the "real" Buenos Aires, but still extremely tourist friendly

Sunday Feria. You have to go here on Sunday for cheap souvenirs to take home to the family. There is also plenty of surrounding cafes and restaurants to take a break from the shopping at. They sell a lot of funky antiques there as well.

A‘joie de vivre’ day or night..... We enjoyed wandering around this old neighbourhood barrio with a knowledgeable guide on an all day walking tour of BA. What we saw was awash with history and if being proud is labelled ‘attitude’ then locals have it in spades. In some parts time had taken its toll but much is a well-preserved enclave of colonial buildings, plazas and cafes with a fantastic street scene – a whole lot like Paris a half world away!Museums,Cathedrals, churches, San Telmo Market, Defence St with a its neighbourhood map painted on a building and one of the narrowest residential house on Pasaje San Lorenzo are some ‘must see’s’ here. This area is also home to the tourist tango where you can see shows, take lessons or watch it in the open at Plaza Dorrego. Who said the national sport is football? Tango is for the masses full of self - expression in a dance!I just love this city with its ‘joie de vivre’ day or night – even when people are working they manage some café time or a late empanada lunch. This barrio would take a few days just to capture the history, see the churches, visit the museums and market stalls so next we can perhaps do it on our own – congratulations to our tour guide though, she had a generosity of spirit and cared deeply for her city.Enjoy your experience here!

It's a must!. In the center of San Telmo we can really feel the Buenos Aires heart. You can see free tango shows, you can enjoy street food (grilled chorizo) and also local handicrafts. The people are friend fully and we really feel the relaxation. Take a special care on pickpockets.
Must do!. If you come to Buenos Aires, make sure you come to visit San Telmo on a Sunday. It's awesome. Love it. Tango dancers, flee market, good food at Cafe San Juan! Loved it!

Nice place to visit.. My husband and I visited Buenos Aires in June 2013. We stayed in the San Telmo neighborhood so we were walking distance from the square where they tango in the street. Great experience and not something you see at home, so definitely worth doing. However, be aware that the tango dancers ask money afterwards and the general feeling is that you can't watch them without paying. The surrounding restaurants are nice but expensive. All in all, worth doing if you are in Buenos Aires.

Sundays at San Telmo. On Sunday, From the Plaza de Mayo proceed down to Plaza Dorrego in San Telmo. Vendors pave the street with bargins, stores of all sorts, neighborhood resturants, locals, tourist and much more. Great shopping experience.

Very bohemian. Great vintage shops, old time cafes, trendy shops, bodegas....... And on Sundays the whole length of the Main Street turns into a market full weird and wonderful things. On the square, the antique stalls are full of bargains to be had. Good restaurants and bars too!

San Telmo. This suburb is loaded with antique shops, fashion and souvenirs. The market on Sundays is great entertainment and lots of goodies to buy. Street performers keep you entertained and food is available in restaurants and street stalls. You can remain hours! I love it.

Old town. The most important thing to say, is take care of the thieves, pickpockets... Full of them. Be carefull!!
Is the oldest part of the city, with a lot of antiques shops.
Never, but never go at night.

back in time.... A place to live like years ago...full of tipical argentinean cafes to enjoy all the week and on weekends the antiques exhibition at san telmo square. Be aware of your backpack and cameras, the place can be very crawded on weekends!. Dont forget to visit the san pedro telmo church!
Lively, full of armosphere. The market in San Telmo is vibrant with great characters, full of fun - and motion. Don't miss the tango!

Take a look to colonial Buenos Aires. San Telmo is part of the first Buenos Aires, where inmigrants choosed to stay when they went down from the ships they were arriving due to the proximity with the harbour. Te place stayed similar to what it was in 1920´s, and now is full of nice bars and tipical grills, but the main atraction of this neighborhood is Defensa Street where you will be able to find marvelous antiques and take a look to Buenos Aires past. It´s a really nice place to walk during morning (not to early) or afternoon.

A favorite area!. San Telmo is a great neighborhood for eating and browsing and people watching. On Sundays there is a great street fair that is blocks long on Calle Defensa that has all kinds of great "stuff" from jewelry to leather goods to clothing and housewares. There are many antique stores open during the street fairs as well.We ate in several ethnic restaurants many nights on Calle Defensa...French, Italian, Indian and more. This was a favorite neighborhood of ours during our stay.

A NICE QUARTER WITH AN INTERESTING FAIR. This was one of the ancient quarters of Buenos Aires, where aristocratic old families used to live. But after the yellow fever explosion of 1871, that group started moving to the Northern parts of the city, leaving this region to immigrants and middle-class people. It was then when it took it´s present day characteristics. Lacking conservation from private owners and from the town government, this quarter retains interest anyway, and you can here, in some places, imagine the Buenos Aires of the first half of the XX century. A lot of antiques shops are concentrated here, some of them very interesting, though expensive. And an extremely attractive antiques fair is held on Sundays. Be very careful with your bags and pockets, try to look as local as possible and avoid public concentrations (for example, where street performers are acting). Do not show money in the streets, specially dollars or euros!

curbside capitalism. I love outdoor markets but the Sunday antiques market in Plaza Dorrego in San Telmo is a phenomenon. The antiques are around the plaza but the shopping continues with arts and crafts vendors for many blocks. It is curbside capitalism at its finest. for more info and photos see my blog. http://havefunflysafe.com/2013/07/24/a-perfect-day-in-buenos-aires/

Colourful !. We spent an enjoyable afternoon walking around the street art in San Telmo. Colonial buildings, antique shops, street performers. One of the oldest parts of BA. We explored it with a guide. Excellent !

Delightful walking. It's a neighborhood where is concentrated many antiques stores. There are some galleries located in old buildings. At the Sundays, you can go through the Defensa street where there is a market with antiques and souvenirs . At the end of it, you will find a square with more things, tango dancers and good restaurants where you can enjoy delicious tipical foods.

San Telmo. Unfortunately for us it was a cloudier day and about 4 hours into the market it began raining. Although from the experience i was allowed to have it was awesome! Tones of locals selling anything from food to trinkets and everything between. The numerous cafes are always teaming eith local life and reallt allow you to immerse yourself in the culture

San Telmo Flea Market. The San Telmo Flea Market has vendors selling new merchandise, antiques, art, and knick knacks for the souvenir hunter. It is definitely a must see/must do experience if you are in Buenos Aires over a Sunday. The prices offered (when asked) are merely a starting point and bargaining is expected... great deals if you know what you are looking for and the price you are willing to pay. A short taxi ride from Puerto Madero
Very Cute Square.... It is fun to walk and some street tango to set the atmosphere. Great little bars and restaurants, fun people..but i was pick pocketed... so be careful!

Good place for a few beers. Stopped into this place with friends late afternoon for a few beers, ended up staying for longer than expected as it was happy hour and had a good feel about the place. Got busier later on in the night and was fun to watch the soccer, could of quite easily stayed for longer.

It's more romantic than Paris. That lovely narrow streets. Great restaurants and a lot of caffeis. Tango, that you hear everywhere. Markets with antiques. Prison museum. A lot of art. Love that place!

A must on a Sunday. The market in San Telmo was one of my favourite ways to spend a Sunday in Buenos Aires. It's a great place to pick up gifts and souvenirs, as well as some really gorgeous jewellery and handbags. There's also an outside tango display by a really cute old couple.

Lot of tourists .... It is nice to walk around the neighborhood ... and some of the funky shops and the street scene do merit visiting ... but in the end the flood of tourists put me off a bit.If the guided tour is your thing then this may be a good stop, but for me it just was not the vibe I was looking for.

Shops with antique and tango places. Nice to walk and visit all the shops with old stuff for every one there is something to collect. At some plaza's the demonstrate the tango so you can relax with a drink and watch this beautiful dance.

Favourite part of the city. A great place at altimeter of the day. It was our favourite place treat out with some lovely street dining. The Sunday market is a must, it is full of life, with some great street entertainment and a huge variety of stalls.

Amazing Sunday street fair!. We stayed in an apartment in San Telmo, and despite being told it may not be the "safest area" we thought it was wonderful and loved staying in the area. On Sunday's there is a street fair that seemed miles long, it was amazing to see locals and tourists just milling around, people tangoing in the street, vendors selling freshly squeezed orange juice, everything was great.In addition to having typical tourist items, a lot of vendors had tons of antiques (San Telmo is known as being the antique district), so you may come across something very unique and unusual!Also, while in San Telmo, make sure to stop by La Poesia, the literary cafe, it's great for breakfast and just a super cute place in general!

A huge market worth wandering through. We arrived back in Buenos Aires mid afternoon and so caught a train to San Telmo. There are streets and streets of stalls selling all sorts of items and antique shops along the pavements. Also from time to time you happen upon a jazz band or a couple dancing the tango. Along the way are cafes and restaurants and it is a fun place. We did not feel it was unsafe but then we kept money and possessions well hidden.

Interesting Neighborhood. Very colorful but crumbling neighborhood. The Feria on Sunday is well worth the time and effort to see. Watch out in this neighborhood for petty thievery. While walking around I was constantly reminded by locals to hide my camera.

Nice place to wander the streets and have a meal/drink.. I have been to San Telmo a couple of times and enjoyed it both times. It is nice to spend some time wandering the streets and looking at the old buildings. There are a lot of restaurants and bars in this area, many of which are aimed at tourists but are still nice to visit. The weekend market was also interesting and I enjoyed spending an hour or so there looking at all the stalls. I have heard/read about San Telmo being dangerous. I have only been there during the day so I can't speak for what happens at night but this wasn't my experience of San Telmo at all. Normal travelling precautions such as wearing your backpack on your front at the markets (as most people do all over Buenos Aires anyway) and keeping your bag/pack in your lap rather than putting it on the floor under a table should mean you avoid any petty theft incidences. Certainly don't let the horror stories about travellers belongings getting pinched stop you from spending an afternoon here.
Busy Sunday Market. This was a large market that went on for many blocks, lots of people, lots of junkier crafts for sale and no tango in the streets.

Dirty, dangerous, but also beautiful.. We stayed in San Telmo and enjoyed the convenience to various neighborhoods and landmarks but I'm not sure we'd stay there again. It was just a little too rough for our liking. But there are some good bars and restaurants. Also, the sunday street market is amazing. Could be an amazing neighborhood if it was a little cleaned up.

Great markets but beware of scams.... Our guide warned us about people that squirt tourists with maynaise or mustard. A group of people surround you and offer help. Among the diversion, people are then stolen from without even realising it. Other than that, the market is amazing on Saturday. It has distinct sections: craft, antique and art. We loved it.

San Telmo, one-of-a kind neighborhood in Buenos Aires. You cannot miss San Telmo if you travel to Buenos Aires. One-of- a kind neighborhood in the heart of the city. Full of old buildings, Antique shops,sidewalk coffee houses. It´s so nice to have a coffee in a coffee shop at a table in Plaza Dorrego! `Personally I love walking on Defensa Street!What´s San Telmo like? If it´s the first time you´ve come downsouth, and you´ve been to NYC, San Telmo will certainly remind you of SOHO.Have a great walk around San Telmo!Sandra from Buenos Aires

My favourite barrio. San Telmo was definitely the best neighbourhood where I could have stayed in my six weeks in Buenos Aires. Its bohemian charm makes it an ideal place for thinkers and artists, leaving each day to be discovered for inspiration. Placed in the oldest part of the city, hosts many decadent buildings and preserves the magic of a city that lives of its nostalgia. Day and night it’s lively and on Sundays delights the visitors as well as the ciudadanos with the famous San Telmo feria: a market where live music, street artists, flea market stalls and artisanal ones join together for a big party that lasts all day. The downside, but also a reality check, is that the barrio is not as well looked after as some other richer neighbourhoods of the city: it is normal to see people living in the streets and smell every sort of smells on the way. Still, this also makes it ideal to live Buenos Aires in its full, as it doesn’t leave much space for hypocrisy. I was happy to live there and I miss it dearly.

Stroll Down Calle Defensa from Avenida de Mayo on Sunday. Street vendors selling handicrafts, foods, and trinkets as well as a variety of musicians will amaze and entertain you on a Sunday afternoon. I did see a police presence, but of course watch your wallet and be aware of your surroundings.The quality and variety of handicrafts are varied and there are restaurants all along Calle Defensa and on the side streets. Very friendly vendors and crowd; the street was packed solid while I strolled south and then north on Calle Defensa.

Interesting markets on Sunday. We went on a Sunday so that we could go to the markets. There is a huge variety of stalls there - many with original craft. We bought an enormous empinada from a street seller for $3 (look for the baskets that look like they have come from a bakery rather than home made if you are worried about hygiene) There were entertainers in the streets. Keep some small change handy to tip them as they go by or as you come across tangoing couples. Some of the surrounding shops up at the Plaza Dorrigo are really interesting and there are some lovely bars and restaurants there too for your well earned rest. Leave yourself at least 2 hours to see the markets and add another hour or so if you ar staying for lunch

Cool place to stroll around.... Luckily my Scala Hotel was adjacent to San Telmo - an easy stroll. Interesting markets -especially the "big one" on the weekend...streets and streets alive with local artisans.Felt very safe here but still don't advertise your wealth.

Visit on Sunday. Sunday is when the large market takes over Defensa. There's a large variety of stuff being sold, some of it quite worth browsing. The neighborhood is lovely with some interesting architectural features.

Lovely neighborhood. Through airbnb we stayed in San Telmo, very close to plaza Dorrego. A very nice little square with terraces and a market during the weekends. San Telmo is a great neighborhood with the characteristic cobble stone streets, nice and diverse architecture. Small boutiques and stylish restaurants and bars. For some reason most of them really know how to create beautiful interiors. Don't forget to Mercado, the indoor market place in a nice building in glass and iron architecture.

Good to visit, but wouldn't stay there again.. San Telmo has a lot to offer. The Plaza Dorrego antiques market on Sunday is crazy, heaving and liveley, with a raffish atmosphere. My friend nearly lost the contents of her bag to a pleasant looking middle aged couple, who were also pickpockets. There's tango music and buskers everywhere. One old couple have been busking there for years and must be in their eighties. Young bands of musicians play with gusto.On weekdays, Plaza Dorrego is completely different and much quieter. There are lots of fabulous antique shops and a permanent antique fair there. The area is full of bars, boutiques, cafes, shoe shops and milongas (tango dance events), tango houses, hotels and hostels. Many people say that it's the "real" Buenos Aires, whatever that means. I enjoyed my two weeks here.Is there a down side? Definitely. It has a seedy atmosphere, which worsens at night. Groups of boys and young men sit in doorways, or lean against the big rubbish bins in the street. I was never menaced, but often felt uncomfortable walking back to my hotel late at night, sometimes leaving events earlier than I would have liked, rather than walk back alone at a later hour. My hotel was locked, day and night and I had to be buzzed in. Other hotels do the same. Buildings are grimy, covered in graffiti and in a shocking state of repair, but there are some attempts to fix things up. Generally though, I was always surprised to see any evidence of repairs anywhere.The sidewalks and streets are quite dangerous. Gaping holes and piles of rubble appear without warning. Lots of loose paving and cobbles in bad condition can make walking a trial. My friend fell in the street due to the bad state of repair and was lucky not to have been hurt badly. As I have commented before, I'm not convinced that a place needs to be grimy, dilapidated and menacing to be "real." After two weeks, I was over San Telmo and decided that for me, it was a place which should be visited several times, but that there are nicer places to stay, even if they are a bit raffish too. My last week was spent in Recoleta, which was a huge relief. The contrast was like going from the ridiculous to the sublime.

A great place to spend a Sunday afternoon visiting the hippy art fair. Great collectables and are work are to be found at the San Telmo hippy art fair on Sundays. Many things are exceptionally well made. Also, collectors of old things will find many things here. I have previously purchased Harley Davidson cigarette lighters here, an old telephone that you would never find in the USA, handmade jewelry.Many restaurants and antique dealers are to be found around the San Telmo hippy art fair also.Allow yourself a Sunday afternoon here.You could also combine this with a trip to Boca first, and then visit San Telmo afterwards as Boca is an interesting place to visit, but it just does not take that long. Also, DO NOT try walking from BOCA to San Telmo. While it is doable, if you still want your money, I would not advise walking from BOCA to San Telmo.Enjoy your Sunday afternoon here, as you will always remember it. Also, the hippy art fair only occurs on Sundays.

Nice Area, Great History. The colonial architecture and the story behind this area was a nice piece of history and gave us an insight to Buenos Aires. We enjoyed the art galleries, the leather goods, the antique shops and outdoor crafts. We saw many restaurants and pubs but did not stay for lunch or dinner, was a nice outing.

History and charm. I went on a Sunday, which the locals believe is the worst time to go! Indeed it is seriously bustling with tourists, given the artisan and antiques market, the free tango and music performances etc but it's good fun.For a more accurate reflection of San Telmo, make sure you also go there on a week day.

Fun market. The sunday market is a great place to get souvenirs. Lots of places to eat. Street performers. The road is almost all stone and some parts are very difficult to get through with a stroller and also very crowded. Lots of tourists.

Market was a great introduction to BA!. We were only there for the Sunday market, but it was well worth the visit! Lots of people, crafts, entertainers, and some tango on teh corners. Find a coffee dshop fo lunch and spend a few hours getting to know BA people...
Lovely. This area offers beauty, safety, history, upscale shops, and dining. On weekends the streets become an open market. What's not to like!

Don't miss the Sunday market. We started at the Plaza de Mayo end of this 8-10 block Sunday market in San Telmo and while it was crowded we found it fascinating. The quality of the offerings for sale at the stalls were mixed but often unique and showed real skill. Along the way you can pop into galleries, small museums, historic churches and listen to talented street musicians. There are many cafes for snacks and it is easy to spend a good part of the day here. As with any market in any part of the world you need to be vigilant about your valuables but it is a fun, relaxed way to spend a Sunday in BA.

Interesting but nothing special. Stopped here as part personalized city tour and found this place sort of interesting. We visited an old city mansion near Plaze Dorrego which has been turned in shops and also visited one of the local bars, these are the places that gives one a senses of the neighborhood. This area is worth seeing because it's part of what makes up a city like Buenos Aires, I wouldn't visit this area without a guide however.

San Telmo has seen better days. Went to the Sunday open air market and was not impressed. San Telmo is being neglected as sidewalks are crumbling and streets are dirty. The market will appeal to folks who like antiques but little else is showcased. I personally think this area is overrated.

Bohemian Chic, Art and Antiques Paradise. San Telmo is an easy neighborhood to love, with its quaint houses, cobblestone streets, quirky shops and great restaurants. Stroll around the neighborhood for great photo opportunities. Even better, go on a Sunday for a the best vibes. The weekly antique market runs along Av. Defensa and is a mind-boggling mix of tango dancers, street artists and handicraft shops.The Sunday market takes place every Sunday, rain or shine. Arrive early (before lunch) to avoid the maddening crowds that start to trickle in at noon. Many stores offer similar handicrafts so shop around before settling on a price.

Robbed. Second day in BsAs, first day spent in Ricoleta .Second - went on city tour with very reputable company, at the end brought to San Telmo for Sunday antique market and were advised to stay . It is old and very run down area, vendors selling tons of cheesy useless, poor quality stuff. At the end our camera was stolen- couple of young women set next to us at the caffe and ran away taking our camera bag . Just disappeared in the crowd... Advice: if absolutely need to see whole city - go with a group for 15 minutes and do NOT stay In San Telmo or La Boca!!!

this area deserves better treatment. we were told that gentrification is underway here, but it isn't making much progress. this historic area should at least have some civic assistance in fixing the sidewalks, which are dangerous! we like it, but feel bad that it is continuing to degrade.

Save for the Sunday street market. San Telmo, particularly Plaza Dorrego, is best on Sunday afternoon, when there are hundreds of outdoor vendors, tango dancers, and thousands of people milling about looking at crafts from all over South American and antiques--some real some not so old. This is all in addition to the store fronts with interesting antiques and stuff. When you get tired of walking the cobbled streets, you can get a window seat at the Dorrego Cafe and Bar and watch the world go by.
Lots of independent shops to explore. If you're fed up with the same shops where ever you go, then the shops in this area is a nice change.

not to be missed. we went to the flea market in San Telmo and you can't help but be impressed at the sheer volume and variety of merchandise that is for sale, from old family heirlooms, to contemporary jewelry, to kitschy souvenir stuff. It is just fun to walk around and people watch. This old cobblestoned area is fun and interesting and loaded with places to grab a snack of empanadas.

Historic barrio with great vibe. I live in Buenos Aires now and this is one of my favorite neighborhoods to wander (though be careful at night as some parts can get a bit sketchy). This is one of the best preserved old neighborhoods that Buenos Aires has to offer, beautiful old mansions everywhere. Its a bit run down in parts now, but that has given it a great artistic edge with lots of funky shops and great bars for nightime.
Interesting open market fair. We visited San Telmo on Monday. there are a lot of shops along the ave de defensia. It is kind like florida street. There are music performers with beautiful music.

Buenos Aires' version of Covent Garden or Greenwich Village. This is quite a run down area (as much of Buenos Aires is) but it has a great atmosphere. I liked the colourful, artistic graffiti/murals and in the main square (where the market stalls are) we came across a young couple dancing the tango - wonderful! Then an excellent lunch at Amici Miei.

Great people watching and trinket shopping. We visited San Telmo twice, once to explore the antique shops and once to see the market. Calle Defensa is a narrow cobbled street which leads you into the heart of the area. It has some lovely old architecture and lots of interesting stores and arcades.

Fantastic. We went here a number of times. The Sunday market is very interesting, a mile of booths, all very differnt. We went to the antique mall one day and back one evening for a great dinner at DesNivel.

Interesting area of Buenos Aires. Old fashioned area, cobbled streets, lots of atmosphere. Grafitti on the walls is impressive. Need to be a bit careful of the holes in pavements/roads when walking! Probably need to be a bit cautious at night as to where you walk but the more populated areas are fine. Loved it!

Beautiful Old Neighbourhood. San Telmo is always fun to visit on Sundays - flea market, tango dancers, entertainers, etc. However, it's also lovely to stroll through the streets during the week when it's quiet. Beautiful architecture.

FOOD & FUN!. Great area for a quick bite and a drink. We went to Medio y Medio, at night they have a live singer with great singing, order one plate for two and enjoy! ...after stop by the ice cream parlor at the corner for dessert and take a picture with little Mafalda, too cute!
Lovely area in Argentina. A place to walk and shopping...very nice places to have a lunch with friends. Like the food and the easy way to take a cab.

Sunday street market along Defensa worth the trip. The Sunday street market along the entire length of Defensa was an interesting way to see the art/crafts/tourist junk that is offered for sale in Buenos Aires. Add in the 'local color' (street vendors selling barbeque & grilled meats for lunch, etc.), and it's a great way to spend several hours. Total distance is about 2 miles, ends in Plaza Dorrego, where several 'street tango' performers entertained the crowds.

Sunday market!. Be sure to visit the market that happens there every Sunday. All sorts of wonderful things to buy and see! It goes on and on for many blocks. La Brigida is the renowned steakhouse right in the area as well.

The best part of BA. Visit on a Sunday - get lost in the magic atmosphere of the antique market and street entertainers! Take time to browse - we ended up buying a 1950's HORNBY train set and bringing it home to England!

Sunday amusement. Gotta go on the weekend (Sunday), to catch the feel of the place. Bit more boring on the weekdays, as it's no where near as crowded and fun. Lot of "junk", lot of "stuff", but if you are into that sort of thing, well worth the time to do it!

Colorful, fun-filled and amazing food!. First, the Sunday San Telmo fair (feria) is an absolute must. What makes it so special is all the music and entertainment...breath-taking. You can definately find some deals..but it is far less about the stuff. Food...best empanadas ever are at Pedro Telmo. It has been around for ever. The elderly woman who runs the restaurant is a doll...you walk in to kisses. Just a lovely experience. Also, recommend Parrilla's Tour San Telmo food tour for a great introduction to the neighborhood.

a must seen on Sundays. I've been there on a Sunday at the market during the day. In the evenening they change to a really chilled nice place for drink and looking for Tango dancers.you will find very interesting things at the market and antiques things.

Pass if not a Sunday. We visited mid week and found the district quite run down and a bit dirty ( even for BA standards). It was fairly quiet and we cut back the time we had originally planned to spend there. Some of the antique shops are worth a browse but apart from that it was an unremarkable part of the city-perhaps if we had been there on the Sunday market we may have had a different view

A Fun Afternoon. Definitely should visit on Sunday afternoons when they hold the weekly market. Singing and dancing in the streets, vendors selling an assortment of goods, and really tasty local foods for sale. The market itself fills several streets, surrounded by small cafes and bars on every corner. Of course the typical touristy crap is for sale, but you can find some pretty awesome homemade goods here too. It’s a fun place to grab a drink and buy some locally crafted stuff. Oh, and just a tip! If you use your American dollars or pounds here, they will actually give you a better rate than using Argentine pesos. :)
Nice, safe place to stay and visit. Nice, safe place to stay and visit. A lot of bars, pubs and restaurants, and good Hostel America del Sur.

Worth checking out. Best on Sundays during their street fair - lots of local artists selling their art and others selling faux antiques. Watch your wallets/purses/cameras as it would be easy to be pickpocketed or robbed here, use common sense and you'll be fine. I picked up some real art treasures here for almost nothing.

Sunday fun. Though worthy of a visit at any time, this quaint old area is exciting on a Sunday with is antique market and flea market too.wander the stalls and enjoy the myriad of fine things amid some junk! Lots of tango dancers on small square platforms too. Lots of fun for an hour or so.

Not what I was expecting. San Telmo is an area of Buenos Aires that everyone says to see. To me it was just an average neighborhood. It has old street feel and some older buildings. The big drawback is it that is destroyed by all the graffiti around. The area DOES have a great sense of feel and has a few good places to eat around the area, but also expect the prices to be a bit higher as well since it is a tourist spot.Over all, the places is perfect if you want to get some good photographic experiences, as the old cobbled streets and buildings allow for that. If you like to explore some of the tourist spots in Buenos Aires you would also like this area of town. Not so great for those who like a clean city, nature or budgetting.

Over-rated & hyped up. Run-down streets, not very authentic, uninteresting. Not a must-see at all. Aggressive waiters on Plaza Dorrego, they grab you by the arm like you're in Turkey. Uncharming. Go on a sunday if you absolutely have to. More lively when the flea market is on. Any other day is a waste of time.

San Telmo Sunday Market. Go to the Sunday market it starts in Defensa street very close to Casa Rosada, Plaza de Mayo. Its great for all kinds of things from bags clothes shoes etc to trinkets, antiques and so much more. There are entertainers along the way and perhaps you'll see tango dancers in the Plaza Dorrego.

If you like antiques. This is the place for you to walk around and look. My wife and I walked around San Telmo after being dropped off from la Boca and it is quite nice. Seemed like it was the older part of the city, with the cobble stone streets and the old rails from the street car (I think). We did the walking tour that is advised in the back of the maps from the city, and found the place very charming.

Sunday Antiques Market is Boistrous!. I read many negative reviews of this market but I found it to be quite wonderful and visited twice. Yes, there are vendors selling plastic junk from China, bad souvenirs, and the ubiquitous pan flute people - however, there are many, many lovely art galleries, artists, jewelers and shops. I found a lot of unique gifts. The antiques market has a lot of great finds; I bought two old books in Spanish and some antique photographs. Stay into the evening and you can have a beer in the central plaza - touristy but still worth it.

Lots of culture. San Telmo is one of the must see neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires. It is full of culture and interesting shops. You could spend quite a few hours wandering around this area. Must see area.

The best neighbourhood in BA!. San Telmo is in my opinion the most multi-faceted neighbourhood in BA. I visited San Telmo on a Sunday with the huge market of arts & crafts, and then enjoyed the best open-air tango in plaza Derracao (I think) as well as some drums and the best carrito! A wonderful experience!

For antique interested ones. On Sundays there's the famous street fair where hundreds of Argentines sell their antique silvery, china , cristals, chandelliers,rugs. Very crowded, watch your bags. On the strres around, many antique shops open on Sundays too
Great opportunities. It's a traditional fair in downtown area. There are some painters really nice and I bought a really nice Beatles paint

Our hotel was here nice and central. Hotel was nice but area was not the best although we suffered no issues. It could be intimidating for those with very young family, elderly or travelling alone. OK during the day but evening time feel in the back streets can make you feel uneasy.Lots of bars/restaurant and things to do around here. A great area for a base and many things well within walking distance.Also lots of small shops/supermarkets dotted around which you can easily get supplies from if you find you need something while travelling.

A great place to wand around.. We spent a few hours browsing. There are lots of antique shops in the streets leading up to the square. The antique market is not so good on weekdays, but better at weekends. There are lots of craft stalls around the square. The square is a great place to have a beer and watch tango dancers.
Sunday Flea Market. This market is good for tourists interested in buying crap which I of course was. I enjoyed it and got a good deal on a mata cup and hats and aprons

Cool place to hang out. Good food, good bars, a very impressive Sunday market which will keep you busu for a full day.
Shop and then eat at El Desnivel for a great steak

Market is small, a bit disappointing, but interesting. We're glad we went, for a slice of Sunday afternoon in Buenos Aires, but we didn't stay long. (We're not much into shopping.) There are a few street musicians and buskers, but if you've been in similar markets elsewhere you'll be disappointed.

Nice "up and coming" neighborhood. This area of Buenos Aires is just coming back into favor. It was where the elite of the city lived in the early 20th century but then when the city was hit by several plagues the wealthy moved to their summer residences in Palermo and Belgrano leaving the area to fall into a state of disrepair. A mixture of late 19th century and early 20th century architecture give this area an eclectic mix. There are now major renovations being done and the area is improving dramatically.There are many nice restaurants in the area with outside terraces to enjoy a meal with a cold beer or a wonderful bottle of wine.Come to the area on Sunday's when there is a market on Defensa and an antique fair on the square where there is also ample opportunity to watch tango being danced if you're not into going to a tango dinner show.Visit the Mercado de San Telmo with a mix of produce and meat and antiques being sold.

Flavor of Argentina. It's touristy but well worth it, this is the flavor of Buenos Aires, Argentina. Tango dancers, shopping for souvenirs, many antiques (some may be hard to travel with because they are breakable). Anyone going to B.A. should make sure to be there on a Sunday to visit San Telmo. Other days of the week there are shops to visit, but Sunday is the best day.

Prefereable to Palmero, non touristy. We stayed both in San Telmo and Palmero Hollywood, visited Palmero/Palmero Soho.San Telmo has more character and everyday BA to the area, we actually enjoyed it very much. We were there during the week. Next time I know we will stay in this area again. The streets seem narrower, and cobblestone more. Shops are not tourist oriented, so get to see the real place. Yes, lot of antique shops. Also great Argentinian steak houses, empanada shops, etc. Someone had placed art on their balcony, created a streetscape - very cool.

Lovely little neighborhood. I love San Telmo. Not only because it's so cute with the cobblestones and cozy little cafes but also because of the people. They are so photogenic. I have taken awesome photos of just people working or wandering around. If you're looking for taking portraits of artisans, tourists, hipsters, old people, tango dancers, anything really, San Telmo is the place to go to!

Unique Market!. Make sure to visit the San Telmo market on Sundays. The area around the plaza becomes an antiques market. There are several bands playing on street corners and tango dancers. Get lost in the streets near the main plaza and you will discover old houses with art galleries and more antique shops. I will also recommend getting a beer in one of the bars in the main plaza and do people-watching. Unique and lovely place! One of my favorites in BA.
Great antique fair. The San Telmo fair is a must go in Buenos Aires. If not visiting on a weekend, still worth visiting the antique shops and the San Telmo Church.
antique heaven!. great area - slightly edgy and trendy. some great bars and restaurants. countless antique shops and arcades - art nouveau/deco heaven.

Great place to roam but not clean. San Telmo is a great place to roam around and to visit the antique shops. These shops are great and its a fantastic place to spend some time a see some BA history.The place, however is not the cleanest, but never mind and shop

Great Marketplace. Make sure to visit the San Telmo market on Sundays. Defensa Street is closed for this event every week. You can buy anything imaginable and it is so much fun to see, smell, listen, and taste all that is Buenos Aires in this great environment.

Well worth a wander.. I went on a Sunday afternoon and enjoyed a couple of hours wandering up and down the streets looking at the market stalls. There were several bands playing on street corners but sadly no tango dancers on that day. The antique shops were more curio shops than antiques in my opinion but interesting all the same and got me out of the sun for a few minutes. I held on to my bag tightly and didn't feel uncomfortable at all.

Everything is walkable... San Telmo on the weekends hosts a outdoor market...It is busy so hold onto your wallet.Some antiques but mostly touristy things to bring back for family and friends...Great restaurants and cafes and the Starbucks is cool with free wifi.

A little bit of tango on a Sunday afternoon.. San Telmo has a historic feel to it. It has narrow streets with a lively street market on the weekends with vendors, musicians, tango dancers and lots of tourists. I really enjoyed my visit there. There are also a lot of antique shops in the area.

San Telmo was a disappopintment. The market did not have much that interested us. The wares could have been purchased anywhere in the world...nothing very unique. The crowds were too large for my tastes.

Mob scene. We went to Plaza Dorrego on Sunday, the day of maximum activity. We hoped to see couples tangoing and partying. What we got instead was a jam-packed street market. The area around the plaza is an antiques market, and there were many established stores to visit; but the street stands had as much variety and maybe even as much quality, which isn't saying much. The best part of the visit was lunch at the bar El Federal, with good steak sandwiches and local beer.
A place to visit on a Sunday morning. lots of antic stores, lots of music and of course tango, I vist San Telmo market every time I'm in BA,

Lived here and loved it.. If you prefer NYC to LA, you'll love it here. Great architecture, history and culture. Otherwise, Palermo SoHo may be right place for you. (Lived in both, and while there's more to do in Palermo, San Telmo is the real BA).

Historic Area Worth Seeing Once. Area is historic with interesting bars and restaurants and buildings. Is dirtier than it should be and caution is noted in traveling alone but one of the "must see at least once" places in BA.

Getting too full of tat now!. 17 years ago the antiques fair occupied the square only but has now become a victim of its own fame and spreads for blocks in all areas selling the usual tourist tat that can be bought in other areas of the city. There are some gems selling retro clothes or hand painted tee shirts but for a less crowded experience try Barrio Norte
What's all the fuss about?. Had lots of people tell me to come here. Can't quite figure out why. I thought it was a bit dull, not much to do.
Weekend wonders..... Weekend markets have lots of handcrafts and pre loved goods. Lots of bars and cafes in side streets, better priced. Tango, drums, guitars create a great atmosphere
so much history. What an unique part of Buenos Aires, with so much history, and so much to see and take pictures of. Oldest barrio in BA, cobblestone streets, tango dancers, etc.

save your money. I found this to be a flea market with questionable quality. The prices were high and probably a lot of fakes are on display. The real antiques are located in the shops and the prices prohibitive.

Great fun on a Sunday. Thought sophisticated visitors like to criticize the street market - and it's true that there are virtually no genuine "antiques" to be found there (tho there are in the nearby antique shops) - there's a good ambiance during the Sunday market, and the buildings lining the street are attractive, if starting to run down. Be sure to head to Plaza Dorrego, which seems to be the "heart" of the market, and it's nicest area. You can sit outside at one of the funky restos lining the square. And in the square there is usually tango dancing.

Pub Gibraltar haven for English speaking - especially beer drinkers. Gibraltar - Perú 895 San Telmo (4362-5310)We were walking through San Telmo, on our way for dinner - Buenos Aires time (9:30 pm), and we had time to kill. Our son was here a few years before, and said we should go here– they have a good selection of beer on tap – and they did.In the heart of San Telmo – the bar is a throw-back to London – and haven for English-speaking students on semester programs or now living in Buenos Aires. If you want a place to enjoy good beer, find English language publications (got a copy of the Buenos Aires Indypendent here), and be certain that you are understood if you don’t speak any Spanish – then stop in at Gibraltar.

A very atmospheric part of Buenos Aires.. A very atmospheric part of Buenos Aires, although we had an unpleasant experience with a changing bureau in Defensa. When we came to the last two 100 pesos notes (of some 20 notes) we had received at the bureau, nobody wanted them as payment. They were simply fake, being ordinary photocopies, apparently cut apart with a scissor! Not what you would expect from a good-looking bureau.
Sunday. Walk on the streets on Sunday market. Loved it. Be careful of your purses or bags. It's a long street of people selling really cute things.
Hated it. Went on Saturday to see the dancers Very crowded and hot. bit like Petticoat Lane with music. Poor quality goods.

A classic, old porteño neighborhood, updated.. The cobblestone streets are lined with an eclectic mix of restaurants and many shops and antique dealers. Great for browsing and, of course, a visit to the Sunday San Telmo feria, which seems to grow every year.

San Telmo. Sano Telmo is very dangerous and the streets were not very clean. Don't walk arround at night! Take a taxi even if it's expensive. At day you have to be careful with your stuff. We heart from a couple that the were stolen during the day!
Shopping. On Sunday they fill the streets up with the tables full of the local trinkets. The coolest part was the antiques that you could buy.

The fair grew too much, witnessed a theft. Over the years, it went too big and is lacking of security and cleanning. We withnessed a bag stolen from a lady and the group just evaded in a motorcycle, in the middle of all the crowd. Watch out!

Wonderful to see it on Sundays. I know San Telmo well as I bought and apartment there that I recently sold. I used to let it to tourists and it was obvious that they liked the area. Porteños are divided about San Telmo; it is a bit drab if you fancy ultra modern skyscrapers rather than beautiful colonial houses and cobbled streets. San Telmo has a community of artist and bohemian people that appeals to yonger and more adventurous types. On Sundays there is a flea market in Dorrego Sq. that now extends throughout neighbouring streets. It is chock o'block with tourists and it's definitely the best time to go as through traffic stops until 8pm so you can wander the different stalls to your heart's content. Some local eccentric characters are always there, living statues, musicians etc. The atmosphere is informal to say the least. There are also many antique shops that are seriously eager to accept your credit cards, cash or whatever you want. If you have time wander inside the market, it was built in 1907 and the shops there ell knick- knacks, good meat and fruit and veg that are fresh and taste real, unlike the veg you buy from a supermarket. Have a coffee in a small stall in the centre, it would blend coffees from various countries if you ask them nicely. Not many tourists go in as it's perhaps not well advertised but it nearly occupies a block so there are various entrances. That's my top tip for tis, if you fancy a tango there are people dancing in the square in the afternoon, don't be shy as nobody would bat an eyelid if you can't dance.

Shabby and dodgy. Run-down neighborhood that lives off its former fame. Most old are in desperate need of renovation. Instead of renovating owners seem to prefer to flatten the charming colonial style buildings and rise ugly 20 story blocks instead. Kills the esthetics.

Don't miss the Hippie Fair. Common in many South American cities, the Sunday Hippie fair is a great place to buy local souvenirs. Some vendors will bargain and some wont. if you don't like the prices just walk away.

Do Not Miss!!. San Telmo is such a cool part of town. Walking around and seeing the artisans crafts and booths is a must. We went back to San Telmo a few times as it is just a fun place to stroll and buy artisans' works of art and souveniers.

Eclectic Bohemia. Visit San Telmo on Sunday afternoon, but be prepared for the crowds. Thousands crowd some ten blocks. There is lots to see, do, and buy. Vendors line the streets with jewelry, art, and crafts. Good place to get gifts. You see street actors and lots of tango. Fun to sit in a sidewalk cafe and people watch. Also, check out the bookstores.

A crowded Sunday shopping market.. I felt a little paranoid while our group of 5 was walking mor because of how crowded it was than anything else. Many antique shops but since we are flying home we could not buy anything large.
San Telmo Flea Markets. If you like antique shopping San Telmo is the place, allow at least half a day. We stayed at a great B&B and only 59 pesos by taxi

Love this place on Sundays. Every time I have family or friends visiting, I make it a point to hit San Telmo on Sunday when the market is on. It's always a crowd pleaser and offers new discoveries every visit so it doesn't get boring for me, either. I recommend starting your Sunday by touring Casa Rosada first and then from Plaza de Mayo head up Defensa all the way to Plaza Dorrego. The Sunday market stalls start on Defensa right off the plaza and it's nice to start this far north because it's not nearly as crowded as it gets southbound closer to the square. Duck in to the little museums and churches and stores along the way-fun!

Fun place to visit.. Too bad we were in San Telmo for just a short visit (& on a weekday!) but enjoyed looking around, just the same. It has preserved its colonial architecture, colorful exterior, & some funky arts outside some buildings. Lots of souvenir shops, too, along with art galleries, restaurants. The mercado was a typical one; nothing unique. There was a pair of tango dancers who you can have a picture taken with for a small donation. That was cool.

Great bars and plazas. I lived in this area for a few days and loved the constant buzz with the old antique shops, bars and restaurants and plazas where you could watch tango dancing and enjoy the beauties of BA until early hours of the morning. The food market is also great!

Don't miss the mercado. Love this area of town. Great old buildings, great stores and a fun place to spend an afternoon. Take the bicycle tour that leaves from this area. Also, visit the market, great old finds!

Sunday market, a must try. The sunday market in San Telmo is a special kind of sight seeing, but worth the time absolutely. You will find a lot of useless pieces, gadgets etc, but you also might find that special little thing that will suit into your house, like an old argentina sign, a fancy poster, handmade painting etc.
stay here. quite grungy and very rough around the edges, but spend the time to look beyond and you will be amazed.
colorful. kind of funky, reminiscent of greenwich village in the old days. a great place to take a lot of pictures and maybe do a little shopping.

Target for a Sunday. We visited the place on a Sunday. Then it is in the day an active vivid antique and vintage market. Colorful, facinating which add to the entire atmosphere of San Talmo. Then we return at afternoon (~ 1800) when it transforms from a market to an open cafe house with street dancing tango. See people from all ages, rich or poor (as per dressing) young and old sharing the love to tango. In addition the nice old house the faceds, the porches, the outside decorrationof the church. A unique 5 star place.

Charming, old world colorful neighbourhood. Cobblestone with painted colorful buildings. Street art, artsy restaurants brimming with antiques and local culture. Lots of restaurants and shops, great for a stroll or a meal. Tango dancing on the street and music everywhere you go. Go on Sunday when the market is open for maximum effect.

San Telmo. A must in Buenos Aires, just the Plaza of the Obelisk is a must stop for tourists. There you can see the presidential Pink House where Evita and Juan peron gave speeches to the people and there are many political signs and memoriams for the Flakland Islands war with britain and the 30,000 missing due to the military overthow of Juan Peron back in 1973. very scenic and historic.

go only sundays. Its a lovely old area of Buens aires. I recommend going on sundays for the street narket, very busy and hip.... lots of lovely restaurants, some street food.. you will feel the essesnce of BA on sunday
Great 'hood. I loved wandering the streets of San Telmo, both on Sunday for the market as well as other times. Decaying architecture, funky antiques, street performers, nice places to eat.
A step back in time. If you read the documentation on the walls it was amazing how many people lived here. A beautiful historic site.

Great neighbourhood. Interesting quarter of Buenos Aires with some great local restaurants. We went to a full restaurant then asked some locals there where they would go if they couldn't get a seat. Their recommendation was spot on.
Give it a Miss unless it's Saturday/Sunday. This area is a bid creepy during the week. I hear it is great on the weekends when the street vendors are there, otherwise I didn't feel comfortable there.
Neighbourhood with zip. We kept coming back to San Telmo: for the market; for Tango; for community events; for great food. Its one of the my favourite places in BA.
to visit. Great on Sunday with the market, so much to see. There are several beautiful bars, restaurants with antique furniture, bottles etc. Worth visiting.

OLD INTERESTING AREA. This place has an oldie worldie feel. A large indoor market selling antiques. In the square It has many restaurants with tango dancing while you eat. Around the square it has stalls selling souvenirs.

filled with style. San Telmo is charming with its cobble stoned streets, low houses and glimpses of wonderful tango here and there. Just wandering the streets is pleasant enough, but there are also tons of great cafes like El Federal or El Dorrego. Well worth an afternoon!
Buzzing. Just m kind of neighbourhood. Really atmospheric, particularly a the weekends. There was a march on the Sunday, celebrating democracy; the place went berserk, all in a good way!

Antiques - Artisans - & Cultural Centerpiece. This wonderful barrio is a must see. Full of artisan and antique shops, San Telmo is full of new world historic charm. It is a gem for local arts and crafts centered around a beautiful park square and convenient to newer and historic coffee bars. I am told that it is also home to an extrodinarily large Sunday craft and artisan fair, which I will simply have to return to see another day.

Lots of places to dine, but few found exceptional. San Telmo is a crowded, busy neighborhood area filled with hotels, hostels, restaurants, shopping. We found a hotel in the area to stay at, restaurants to dine, museums to visit. Sometimes staying in this area isn't always the best, being in a crowded area, at least by daytime. In the evening, the crowds shift to where the shopping, eating areas are, and as the hours get later, the streets empty of people except for the litter left behind.The Sunday flea market is a big weekly event if you're in the area. I found it tiresome after walking for a while, it seems to go on and on and it's very crowded, slow moving and not so easy walking on their uneven streets. There are some interesting things to browse at, the food the vendors at the flea market provide simple, tasty, inexpensive foods.Watch your valuables, as in crowded areas and distractions like watching entertainers could be the distraction pickpockets need. See those who carry their backpacks on the front, they're probably victims of pickpockets.A few places will entice customers with a Tango dance, but will tease you to stay till they think they have a large crowd before the performers will dance, and afterwards go around asking for tips. One restaurant in the area near the museums have dummies outside have a good Tango show but their food isn't all that good and is on the pricey side.I didn't think of it at the time, we were leaving for the airport that day, should have stocked up with food snacks from that vendor, as the food prices at the airport are way more expensive.It's worthy of a visit. Lots to see, lots to do, can be expensive, the money meter can run fast here. Restaurants are plentiful, but few are exceptional to the palate at any price.

nothing special. I thought we would see antique stands on the street, or local artisans selling their goods. Instead we just found the same cheap stuff over and over. A few places selling leather bags and such, that was the only thing worth it.

delapidated. How clean recoleta is, San Telmo is not more than a dilapidated neighborhood. Rubbish, run down old houses in horrible narrow streets with sidewalks in dire need of a makeover. No authentic vibe, just a cheap tourist neighborhood.

San Telmo needs some love. Described as "charming" apparently means loads of broken pavements, unlit streets at night and tons of garbage all over the place. Interesting architecture but only look at it while standing still, it'll be safer that way. This part of the city needs some investment in it's infrastructure. Recoleta isn't like this, nor is Montserrat. City governers need to take note.

One day is all you need. If you like any of the following you may consider staying in this neighborhood as a non-spanish speaking tourist: dodging dog poop on the sidewalks, rudeness, antique shopping for hours on-end. If you're like me, and you like not having to worry about stepping in dog poop every 20 seconds, only spending an hour max looking at antiques, appreciate manners and courtesy, I would not recommend visiting San Telmo on your trip to Buenos Aires. The only good part about San Telmo is the tango in the square. Other than that I wouldn't bother.
LOCATION LOCATION LOCATION. Close to about everything that tourists need. A local neighbourhood rather that a tourist strip. Not posh but friendly.
Must see. Easy to get to by public transpor... why not walk the streets, nothing is too far away and a lot to see on the way....

SUNDAY Antique Fair - a must. I made sure that I would be in Buenos Aires on Sunday because I had read about the San Telmo Fair and Antique Exhibition.To my delight, the day was beautifully sunny. Waking on the quaint cobblestones of Defensa Street for many blocks, the sidewalks are filled with people displaying their local wares. Plenty of food was also available. At Plaza Dorrego, the plaza was full of vendors displaying Argentinian pictures, jewelry, Indian artifacts, delicate quilts and the like. At one corner off Plaza Dorrego on Defensa Street was a nice exhibition of the Argentina tango being performed with local live music to go with it. At times, the guitarist would play a medley of Spanish music flamengo style to the audience delight.At other locations, one can also see classical music being played, complete with violins and cello and a Spanish crooner on the mike.A good two to three hours in the afternoon is enough time. Take a break to eat the great meat dishes available all over and the local beer.
Lovely place. Wonderful quarter of Buenos Aires, great for shopping and hanging around. This is the Notting Hill of Buenos Aires...

Antique area. From reading the other reviews it sounds like a Sunday is the time to visit San Telmo when the merchants are out. We went on a Thursday, interesting. Many antiques if that is your gig. The central park was nice but not overly exciting

Go to the main square on Sunday--don't miss it.. The flea market in San Telmo on Sundays is really great. There is no sense of high pressure selling. Argentines are very laid back in this regard and it is such a breath of fresh air. There is great Tango in the square and you'll find items from all over the world and it good shape. Also go to the mercado, which is downhill a bit, and is the permanent inside market in San Telmo--cool building too.

Fun on Sunday. Go on a Sunday, I believe it starts around 10am. We started in Plaza Dorrego and walked up along Defensa. Place full of fun little gifts and pretty crowded. There is also an outdoor spot along Defensa that serves some asado that was pretty good.
great market and live music. San Telmo on Sunday is a paradise. buy everything you can think of at excellent prices. free roving musicians and dancers, parillas and cafes. don't miss this.

Go and see it on Saturday afternoon. Antique markets, Tango in the Street, open air Cafe's but all a little bit rough and ready - no polished metal and glass here, more like the real Buenos Aires - some great places to eat and the locals pretty friendly, but keep your valuables safe, and dont flash too much bling, some poor areas here, so be smart and you will love it

Something special. This Sunday only market fills several streets and can barely be negotiated with the crowds, which. I hasten to add, are generally very polite - certainly better behaved than that many of my fellow Americans. Prices are very good, some of the stuff we bought was also at the airport (I know, the airport!) for 50% or more higher.

Sunday Market in San Telmo is the place to be. We spent the day exploring market day in San Telmo. The main square was not much interest to us as it held the antique wares. However stretching out from the main square is Defensa street and the artisan goods along this street were varied and interesting. There are great boutiques along the street as well. If you are peckish, don't hesitate to buy an empanada from the vendors selling near the intersections - quite tasty. Or, enjoy a refreshment at the pub that is located kitty-corner from the main square. We purchased a Yerba Mate cup that was hand decorated and some funky jewelry - or which both, there were many to choose from. Wear comfortable shoes because if you meander along, it takes a long time to travel along the few blocks. Also, be mindful of pickpockets - they are always around.
