If you have time for only one market, we enjoyed the Recoleta market better, but the outlying businesses and restaurants are extremely overpriced.

Why not? What else are you going to do on Sunday?. Sunday morning at San Telmo. GREAT people watching, some tango going on in the square. Your chance to buy that soda seltzer bottle and get some great pictures.

Funky place to explore. Artistic, funky, touristy, antiques are just a few words to describe San Telmo. I stayed there for a month and enjoyed walking around the town. A mix of touristy spots with some good finds. Liked the Ricoleto Sunday market better, but liked the cobblestone funky of ST. Loved La Herbabuena.

Nice area, great sunday market. Watch out for pickpockets.. If you are here on a Sunday you must go to the Sunday Market. Watch out for the pickpockets. There are some lovely Cafes around. Try La Poesia at #502 Chile.

Great neighborhood with lots of potential. My hotel was in this part of the city. While it can seem a little sketchy at night there is a lot of history, fabulous architecture, and a Sunday market not to be missed. It was fun just wondering around the streets seeing what was around. There are shops in interesting places, food all over the places, and lots to look at. Beware of the uneven sidewalks!!

WOW. Great markets! Spent five hours wandering through until it started to drizzle. Wares are not as cheap as you would expect in markets. Best purchases were bags from the man who makes them all with continuos zips.
Don't miss it. This is a must in Bs. As / great people / food & original shooping squareThis is the best place to buy antiquetes in town

Funky and fun. There are interesting shops open most days and the Sunday fair is a must when visiting the area. Lots of small and inexpensive places to eat lunch or dinner or just have a drink. Some very good gelato can be found near the Plaza Dorrego where the Sunday fair is held.

go on sunday. This was a blast, but go Sunday afternoon. You've got the antique fair, and lots of street Tango --dance, orchestras--amazing. The flea market has some good buy, too. the taxi cab driver warned me to be careful of my perse and pickpockets, but we had no problems

The main historic and and cultural area. San Telmo seems to be the main neighbourhood to go to for tourists as it's where a lot of the history and culture is. On Sundays the hold a large market all over the streets and there's plenty of places to visit. Tango shows are meant to be a regular occurrence on the square but I ended up being lucky to catch just one basic one.

One of my favorite parts of the city!. I loved wandering around San Telmo. I was there on two different occasions, walking through the market. I would consider it a must-do if you're there on a weekend.

Good Timing. took a taxi from Arenales and Cerrito to Plaza Dorrego 14 pesos Liked that it was not busy like on Sunday check out the indoor flea market. you can haggle got a few good pieces...although not all the stores were open

The heart of tango. A great neighbourhood with nice little restaurants like Lo de Luis in Tacuari and La Casa at Independencia( great bife de chorizo for a low price and nice owners), great empanadas at La Reliquia at Mexico. The Sunday street market at Defensa is great with a nice atmosphere. Also on Sunday the market and in the evening tango with El Indio at plaza Dorrego is worth visiting.

Fabulous time. We walked through San Telmo during the week but returned on Sunday morning to go to the antiques fair. Wow, what a fantastic atmosphere! We also bought some souvenirs there at a decent price including beautiful rodocrosita, the pink national stone and a CD of some of the lovely music.

Lively and interesting area of old Buenos Aires. Come for the Sunday street market - very extensive. All the streets through San Telmo from the square with the Casa Rosada close down on Sundays and are filled with stalls, vendors of all things imaginable and performers. Check out the tango dancers in the neighbourhood where the dance began

Be there on Sunday. The Plaza Dorrego in San Telmo becomes an amazing place on Sunday. That's when it is turned into a market place. Actually it is more than that because there are tango dancers and other performers in various locations along with all those street vendors.The variety is extensive, from antiques to some tacky souvineers With a bit of patience and scouting you can score some nice things.Check out Humberto street adjacent to the square where we found a variety of local hand made items.
Boho area. Walking San Telmo is fabulous. Wonderful colors and architecture. Cool antique stores and other shops and cafes. Plenty of Tango in this place.
Character-filled neighborhood. A must-see part of BA. Cobblestone streets, nice shops and plenty of good eats. Easy to get to the subway as well.

Great vibe. I loved san staying in san telmo. It was a pretty chilled out part of Buenos aires. There are many unique shops, some with unusual fashions and a lot of antiques. On Sundays the streets become a maze of people and market stalls. There are plenty of souvenirs and bargains to be found, as well as interesting people to meet. If you don't like huge crowds then it is still worth a visit any other day. There are many amazing food places to be found.

Try the market on Sunday. Great historical area, it is very crowded on sunday but worth it to go hang out, drink a beer, brows through shops. If you hate crowds, I'd recommend another day. Great place to see tango in the streets.

Great for the history, but the Sunday Market was so-so. It made me a little sad to see the disrepair of some really beautiful buildings in the area but that's the history of San Telmo. It's still great, architecturally but the big attraction for many is the Sunday Market street fair. I didn't love it, despite the fact everyone tells you it is a must-do. It is very crowded. The vendors wares generally look cheap and kitschy - after a couple blocks you've seen what you need to see. The exception is antiques. I'm not an antiques person but if you are, San Telmo is a slice of Argnetinian heaven. They definitely have some cool stuff in the stores lining the outdoor market. It's a fun afternoon but if you aren't a big shopper and don't love crowds.... A quick visit will be all you'll need

So much to see!. Sunday is the main day where you will find all the artesan street sellers displaying their wares on the pavements and in the little squares. Best to take cash if you want to buy a bargain as few take credit cards. There is so much to see and choose from!
Great afternoon out. walking around San Telmo on a Sunday is one of those must-do things in Buenos Aires, the market, the people, the food..

Try going midweek for a pleasant stroll!. I went on a Wednesday and was afraid of missing the Sunday market. But I found it very enjoyable to have a leisurely stroll without a lot of people. The artisans and shop owners actually conversed with us in a friendly way. Probably my favorites were la defense, the San telco mercado, plaza santo Domingo and an awesome vintage shop off of plaza San Domingo. Enjoy!
True Bohemian ambience. A different part of buenos aires with boutique shops and lots of antiques available. Great place to hang around at night on weekends. Lovely fair in sunday mornings.

If you like antique fairs, you'll like this. I'm a little.... so-so when it comes to antique fairs. But I decided to go to San Telmo regardless, and it was definitely enjoyable. There are a lot of historic houses in the area (albeit a bit run down), and miles and miles of stalls on Defensa. The plaza itself is also crammed packed. It's the fairly standard antiques fair stuff - I'm not entirely sure if there was anything particularly unique or different.

Fantastic antiques market but much more too. I went to this district twice, once on a Sunday to see the amazing antiques market, it was amazing and there were so many beautiful shops as well as stalls. Never seen so much gorgeous stuff in one place - wish I wasn't travelling! I went back a few days later to El Zanjon which was an extraordinary experience - a restored building where once the rivers ran through, tunnels, beautifully restored, fantastic guides, outstanding resotration. Add it to your MUST DO list in BA for a unqiue experience.
perfect for a sunday morning stroll. A lot of colour, fun stalls and a lot of creativity. Gets crowded around lunchtime. Reasonable prices and friendly people. Good deals for the conaisseur.

Nice older area. I love the side streets with the old colonial style homes. It is an area that is chugging for the better. Fun to see especially on Sunday. There is a huge flea market type event in a closed street that seems to go for miles, must see the plaza dorrego at this time too. Some interesting people watching there. Some tango too. Go to amici miei restaurant on the plaza for the finest Italian food in the city

Mafalda's Bario. Begin or end your stroll on Defensa at the intersection of Chile with a visit and photo of yourself with Mafalda, an Argentine icon the equal of Eva Peron. Make this walk during the Sunday street fair and enjoy the color of the open air fea market and the more established fair with art and antique artifacts at Plaza Dorrego. With the expansion in recent years of the number of street vendors, the Sunday fair now stretches more Plaza de Mayo until Avenida San Juan. But if you wish a more calm venue, take this jaunt on a mid-week day and step into the many antique emporiums lining Defensa for a glimpse of past Buenos Aires, a mid-morning coffee or afternoon vino at Plaza Dorrego, and stay on for the evening entertainment provided by Tango dancers and musicians. At mid-week, you probably won't have to wait in line so as to have a seating and photo-op with Mafalda on her bench.

Beating all expectations!. Vising San Telmo is a guaranteed ride to the past! My favourite bits: the collection of old toys piling up everywhere, the forgotten kettles and oldfashioned appliances waiting for new owners, and the everyday treasures once forgotten and now brought once more into life. Comparisons are dreadful and I apologize for yielding to the temptation but I think my previous visits to San Telmo account for the lack of enthusiasm I experienced in El Rastro (Spain). So if unsure, just let San Telmo beat all your expectations!

San Telmo Street Fair. After being slightly disappointed by the Hippie Fair in Rio de Janeiro we were skeptical of the San Telmo Fair in Buenos Aires. It did, however, exceed our expectations. First-it's huge. There are blocks and blocks of unusual antiques plus the standard street fair tee shirts and the like. Then there are the vendors themselves. We weren't sure if it was a special occasion, but some of them looked like they walked off the set of Rocky Horror Picture Show. It was funny and creepy. We would certainly go back.

Great marketplace, very lively. The San Telmo market is a nice place to visit, especially for the weekly fair on Sundays. You will find a bit of everything on the streets, from fresh fruits to old antiques, and even odd objects such as medical protesis. I really liked the atmosphere, with street artists, musicians, and a mix of alternative tourists and locals.

Best market in Buenos Aires!. I've been here for a month now and visited the Sunday San Telmo market 3 times! There are endless number of kiosks with INTERESTING items - not just things made in China. Everything from wall art to jewelry, leather goods, mate galore, shoes, antiques. Prices are good (I inquired about similar items at different stalls and got the same quotes). Pablo Salvado is a painter there whose work is unbelievable - Highly recommend him. There are also plenty of restaurants intermixed. Great way to spend the day!

Good to feel the nostalgic atmosphere of Buenos Aires’ bygone days. San Telmo is the smallest neighbourhood in Buenos Aires.Originally it was inhabited by people working at the port. Later on, the Jesuits founded the Our Lady of the Rosario Church. After that, rich families occupied the place, but the 1871 yellow fever epidemic made them leave the neighbourhood. It was then when the old beautiful houses began to be rented to the arriving European immigrants. These people used to live in what is known as conventillos (big houses whose bedrooms where hired separately to different families who shared some common areas, such as the kitchen, the bathroom, the yard, etc) (Similar to the idea of a Hutong in China).A long time passed and by 1970 Plaza Dorrego was created with its characteristic Antique Fair (Sunday from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.). There are many places to visit when in San Telmo: Buildings from the XIX and XX century around the main square, Casa Mínima, built by freedmen following the 1813 abolition of slavery in Argentina, Defensa Street, Humberto I Street – The Jesuit Church of Betlem., Mafalda Statue (on the corner of Chile and Defensa), Nuestra Señora de Belén Church, The Russian Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, San Pedro Church, The Prison Museum (Museo Penitenciario), San Telmo Market, Pasaje La Defensa (ex Casa de los Ezeizas on 1179 Defensa Street), a typical criolla house built in 1880, and one of the best kept examples of a house of those times with two floors and bedrooms around a lovely garden). Make sure you visit one of the old houses (of which Pasaje La Defensa is an example), now turned in Art Galleries, antique shops or commercial galleries. Luckily, you will be able to see street performers and Tango dancers on the cobblestone streets of this lovely neighbourhood.Restaurants and bars in San Telmo are not that expensive so it would be a good opportunity to have something there and relax, while you feel the nostalgic atmosphere of Buenos Aires’ bygone days!A good website to take into account: http://www.feriadesantelmo.com/menu.htm

I love San Telmo!. San Telmo is a great place. It is the oldest and one of the smallest barrios (neighbourhood) in Buenos Aires. If you come here just as a tourist passing through, San Telmo can seem like nothing more than a typical tourist spot with old churches, old buildings and tons of antique stores. Now I've lived in San Telmo with my girlfriend for two months, and we both really love it here. There are so many great bars, restaurants and cafés surrounding the place, and really get that "Buenos Aires feeling" when you spend your day walking though the old streets, enjoying some of that terrible beverage that passes for coffee here at a nice café, or having some drinks or a couple of beers in one of the many unique and original bars found around here.There are also a lot of cool clothing shops around here, with unique clothing.What I love about San Telmo is that you are not too shielded from what is the reality for many people in this country. You see young students, old people, poor people, wealthier people and tourists together. The sunday fair in Defensa is really nice, but very crowded. Here you can buy everything from chili paste, clothes, shoes, leather belts and art to tacky articles and gifts. What is a real treat though is the indoor Mercado (market). Here you find a lot of the things you find in the sunday feria, slightly cheaper and without the extreme crowd. And most of the antique shops with tons of different things are mostly open every day. If you hit the indoor mercado, be sure to have a cup of coffee at Coffee Town, the small "pavilion" in the center. They are one of the few places in Buenos Aires with good coffee.San Telmo is also a place where you can cacth some decent tango shows while having a glass of wine or a meal.The atmosphere in this barrio is something you really should experience while in Buenos Aires, and try to give it a couple of days to walk around here and try some different cafés, restaurants and bars. It's as great as Palermo, slightly cheaper and with a more neo-bohemian crowd than the rich kid hipster crowd.

oola la!!!!!. Everything - St Telmo's ambience, the square, the little cafe's, AND the Tango dancers are without question the best entertainment out. One can easily sit in the Square cafe's all day and watch life go by XXXXXXXXX

Fun outdoor market. We went to San Telmo three times in our month-long visit to BA. Go on Sunday when the antique market is happening. We also went once to more of a craft market, but couldn't find it again when we went back. Do be aware of pickpockets especially when talking with merchants. We were lucky enough to see some tango while walking around, even saw the older couple who are featured on the cover of Lonely Planet Buenos Aires there dancing cheek to cheek. The buildings are lovely there too. It was a bit painful to see Starbucks in an old building on a prime corner when all the other businesses around seem classic and far more traditional. Oh well...I guess if you're looking for a familiar latte in an unfamiliar place Starbucks is there for you!

Spend a great afternoon wandering the streets of San Telmo.. The Sunday market is great fun, but go on another day to avoid the crowds. We walked all over town, explored a fantastic antique store that had all art deco and art nouveau items, walked in and out of paseos filled with interesting antique stores, walked by El Parque pizzeria that smelled so wonderful, we stopped in to pick up a few slices and realized that it was the best pizza we have ever tasted, discovered the fascinating penitentiary museum, photographed beautiful architecture, walked through a huge market filled with fresh fruit and vegetable stands, used clothing and antique stores, stopped and had drinks at la poesia, a tiny old bar, and had a wonderful day exploring San Telmo. One thing I noticed is that the stores close to the main square have a lot of beautiful leather goods, but the prices are 1/3 higher than the exact same items I saw in shops on Callao in Recoleta.

Markets that go on forever!. The San Telmo markets are a must if you visit Buenos Aires. There is a wide collection of interesting artefacts to admire and purchase. Many photographic opportunities also abound.
Fabulous neighbourhood. I have just moved to Buenos Aires and am living in San Telmos. I love the feel of this bohemian neighbourhood. Nice cafes, good market and lovely people.

Wonderful spot in Buenos Aires!!!!!!. Amazing neighborhood in the heart of Buenos Aires. The stone streets bring you back to colonial times. There are small stores that offer wine and delicious delicacies, such as alfajores and chocolate bars .Also, beutiful decorated stores are located along these streets, On the other hand, an open market is visited by many tourist every Sunday afternoon. I loved it!!!!!!
DeBar. if you are a rocker, DeBar in San Telmo is a perfect place to go! good beer, nice people and the best rock videos.

Fun Sunday afternoon out. Given the centre of BA can be quiet on a Sunday we caught the subte blue line to Independencia and then made the 10 minute walk down to San Telmo. It is very busy street market that sells everything from tacky imports through to fine antiques oh and fruit & veg if you need something to go with your dinner. In amongst all of this are magicians, tango dancers, music bands, mime artists and just about every conceivable type of life imaginable. A very long street which got very crowded but at all times it felt safe & fun. Lots of street food or restaurants to eat in - or just sit & watch the world go past. Look out for the antique jewelry shops - sheer amount of stock is glitteringly impressive. By chance we happened on Museo Penitenciario - 378 Humberto Primero - museopenitenciario.spf.gov.ar which couldn't find in Tripadvisor listings. Free and worth a look to see what was a working prison dating back to the 18th century looks like.

Enjoyed the market!. San Telmo is a very nice neighborhood in BA. The popular thing here is the street market on Sundays. You can walk for quite a ways enjoying the weather and architecure of the city as well as the culture and vendors. At the end of many blocks is a square where there is a little Tango going on in the street as well as more vendors. We sat and had a beer and burger at El Dorrego on the square and really enjoyed the atmosphere. Its definitely a place to check out in BA.

Nice street market. San Telmo is a huge street market that works on sundays. It's nice to walk around and check out all the hand made staff and gastronomy around.It's nice but the first 2 blocs looks really turistic (not hand made staff, but chinese staff... :/)Walk a little bit more and you gonna find parrillas, choripans, cafes... tango on the street... and second hand market!

Sunday Market. My husband and I just returned from BsAs and of course spent Sunday afternoon at the San Telmo Market. We love to see all the variety of items for sale. Be prepared for crowds, it can get a bit congested in certain areas. I have to put in a BIG recommendation for the most incredible empanadas being sold there by a darling couple, Anna Marie and Martin! They are in the same location every Sunday selling their empanadas. The empanadas are large, stuffed end to end with a wonderful ground beef filling. Their empanadas are fried (but not greasy) rather than baked as you will find everywhere else. I think this is Tucuman style. Don't miss out on these!

Very unique market. The Market itself (that is in the building) is a flea market of antiques that gets old within the first 10 minutes. If you're into antiques, it's great -- otherwise, kind of boring after a few minutes. However, if you go on Sunday, and get out of the flea market, there are stalls as far as the eye can see. We ended up buying some decorative pieces from here at reasonable prices. Definitely something to see on Sunday, outside in the streets. We actually walked all the way to Casa Rosada without realizing it. Watch your stuff as it's a narrow street, and probably an ideal place for pick pocketers. There is so much going on that you almost miss the building facades and can be sensory overload. Overall, worth the visit, but you don't have to walk the whole thing to get the gist of it. Interesting but very touristy.

Funky Little Neighborhood. This is sort of the hip artsy and trendy part of BA. There is a weekend arts and crafts market that gets the area very crowded. There are plenty of nice restaurants and shop on normal days. The architecture is worht the walk as well.
WOW!!!!. The most beautiful area of B.A.! The architecture and of course the market! Seriously: Don't miss it!!!

The Sunday place to be. I'm not much for Sundays but San Telmo makes me feel differently. I love browsing the market in Defensa Street and I recommend having lunch in a restaurant two blocks away (corner of Peru and Humberto 1o) called Origen - mostly vegetarian and delicious! Or stop in for a slice at Pirilo pizza on calle Defensa between Independencia and Estados Unidos. If you're looking for a mate gourd, shop around - prices and quality vary.

Gorgeous area, steeped in history.. Great for a walk around, lots of old antique shops, arty kinda place. Nice relaxed vibe, lovely tango music bars around the old square. Nice way to spend a few hours walking around BA.

Sunday fair. If you have plans to see San Telmo, go on Sunday. Defensia street is lined for miles with magicians, puppet shows and other attractions among the hundreds of street vendors. There is an elderly couple that dances tango at the end of the way, but better yet is a full tango orchestra off on a little side street. If you have good weather and several hours, this is a must for visitors to buenos aires.

Little bohemia... Good things : architecture, history, feeling Paris or europ, the building, the little parks, dorrego place, the restaurants, cafes, bares, food market, and antics...lovely and romantic...Bad things : graffitis, trach, walking side in very bad shape, noise and poor peoples living in the street... i think people do not understand what they have in fact in this wonderfull city...I thing unsecurity start with the graffitis....and trach open in the street...
Bohemio. You can breath tango when you walk around this little neighborhood. Old streets, colourful houses and art everywhere

The Heart of Buenos Aires. I stayed in a lovely hotel in San Telmo, ate in great restaurants, shopped in the market, walked to La Casa Rosada and Place de Mayo during my visit. I highly recommend this area of Buenos Aires

Highlight of my trip. I was told to visit San Telmo on a Sunday in order to enjoy the antiques market, and I was not led astray. I started my day at Plaza de Mayo and walked along Defensa St. all the way to San Telmo. The street was lined with vendors selling everything from jewelry to matte, to scarves, paintings, food and kitchy souveniers. At the end of the market was Plaza Dorrego which had a large antiques market, live music, people dancing tango, cafes, and beautiful buildings. I could have sat and people watched all day. Definitely worth a visit!
San Telmo, the true Portenho place. San Telmo is very cool, a traditional place where you can appreciate the true Portenho life style. The antiques faire is awesome.

Feria de San Telmo. If you are on sunday in Buenos Aires, go to Feria de San Telmo. You will see a lot of old things, anything and you will be able to eat at the street or in a restaurant, but always full of tourists. many blocks of small tents, selling things that many, never saw. You can stay the whole day watching, buying or just walking. totally different mood.

Very cultural - tango and arts. One of the tips our guide had suggested, was that if we had time to come back to San Telmo on Sunday afternoon there is an antique fair and we might see some tango dancers. After walking all morning through Recoleta Cemetary and the parks, we were tired so took a taxi to the San Telmo area and walked toward the plaza. Saw lots of vendors selling antiques and souvenirs. When we got to the plaza there was a group in one corner and sure enough a couple was dancing tango. They looked great and we watched for awhile. Glad to throw some coins into the hat they passed at the end. Far cheaper than the tango clubs! And still gave us a flavor of the dance.

love love love!. Although we stayed in Palermo Soho, we thought that San Telmo had a lot more character (but soho was more accessible). The fair was awesome, the people were nice, and there are a lot of neat museums to go into.
Funky & Cool, Low Key. The film school is here, nightclubs are here, funky restaurants are here, you should be here.

Historic part of Buenos Aires. I really loved San Telmo! The people who lived there seemed to be much warmer than the people who live in Palermo or Recoleta, and it still has some of that old-timey feel that makes Buenos Aires awesome! The feria on Sundays is the biggest in Buenos Aires, and a good place to people watch and buy gifts for your family. The only reason why I can't give it 5 stars, is that it seems a bit dangerous at night, as there are a lot of drunks, homeless people, and somewhat scary looking people walking around. There are also places where it is quite dirty, with trashed piled up on the street corners.

Fabulous coffee in San Telmo Mercado. San Talmo Mercado is definately worth a visit in it's own right the added bonus is it's home to the best coffee in town - Coffee Town is a small stall right in the market centre producing the best brew I've had in Argentina. Delicious!

Nice area to check out in BA. We stayed in San Telmo for 5 nights.It's a really trendy area with some very nice restaurants, pubs and local attractions.On Sunday they have the San Telmo antique markets... The whole main street closes down and the markets are almost 1km long - people everywhere... A must do if you are in BA on a Sunday.Overall it's a really historical, arty area, cool old buildings and nice atmosphere.

Go to the Sunday market!. San Telmo appears to be a slightly sleepy historic area, with narrow streets and tight sidewalks, but it comes definitely comes to on the Sunday Market. Defensia Street is jam packed with vendors, locals and tourists. All kinds of crafts, antiques, art, foods, musicians & tango dancers, for over several kilometers. Not to be missed! Also there are other great places to go throughout the week. Ask locals for the best tips.

Lots to see and do. This neighbourhood is home to Plaza Dorrego with it's open-air cafe seating and tango dancers, El Zanjon (well worth the price of admission), a 15-block long Sunday market, the Buenos Aires Modern Fine Arts Museum, and the interesting but unpromoted Penitentiary Museum. Also, lots of cafes and restaurants (my favourite: The Gibraltor, a small English pub with British and Thai food on the menu).

Antiques heaven. This area of the city is a little walk from the centre but worth seeing as it has a very different vibe. Lots of antique shops, stalls and markets, and lots of locals, so I think it gives you a very different sense of the place. Also, we went to La Poeta, a cafe / bar there one night and it was excellent and VERY cheap, so perhaps a bit less touristy.
Great place to spend an afternoon. An afternoon visiting the antique shops and shopping for something unique, is a must when in BA. Go during week days and avoid the Sunday crowds. Great finds.

A regular neighborhood, very relaxed.. There are not very many tourists except on Sundays because of the flea market. There is nothing fancy here but this is an average neighborhood where you get to meet regular people. We loved it, we drank coffee at a family owned coffee and bakery shop, we got our water at a family owned market, we at at a family owned grill that you had to sit on the curb to eat. Do watch for cars though, pedestrians are nothing more than speed bumps.
Go and visit Mafalda. This is an area of Buenos Aires full of tradition, shopping, bars, restaurants and everything you need. Don't forget to visit Mafalda in the corner of Defensa and Chile.

Tradition and shopping. Maybe the most traditional neighborhood of Buenos Aires, San Telmo still has a great number of colonial buildings, and marks of the rich past of the city. Here you are gonna see street arts, many tango stores, good restaurants, old churches, and maybe the best of this part of the city: the market! During the week, the San Telmo Market is full of antiques and gifts with a very low price, maybe the best prices in the city. At sundays, the stop SHOULD be at the Street market of San Telmo, to see tango shows, handcrafts of all kinds, typical food and all the diversity of the capital.

An expedition to be had!. Even if it wasn't market Sunday, there are lots of things to do in San Telmo: browsing through local designer stores, get lost in the endless antique stores, people-watching in a cafe, gorging on meat and wine in a parrilla. Something new & interesting can be found every day!
Historic neighborhood. Historic neighborhood, you can see Tango dances in many corners and listen tango everywhere
Sunday in San Telmo. A wonderful day, lots of crafts and vendors selling.

A must see but be very careful who you help in coffee shops - I almost had my camera stolen -. San Telmo is a must see on a Sunday afternoon but be very careful... I was sitting in a "well known" coffee shop in San Telmo yesterday with my camera bag right in front of me. A woman pretending not to know the language asked me to help her get the attention of the person behind the counter. When I got up to try to help I saw the man, who was sitting in the area behind me try to pull my camera bag towards him. Fortunately I saw what he was doing and stopped him before he could get his hands on it, but he and the woman were obviously in cahoots. When I asked him what he was doing he and the woman ran off. It just proves once again than no good deed goes unpunished.

boho buenos aires. During the week, streets seem dirty and the general neglect of this city is apperent.On Sunday it`s very lively, an antique market (more bric a brac kitch than antique) make it more attractive.
Nice place to visit. Great atmosphere and places to visit. La Brigada and Café Dorrego are a must.
Sunday Fair!. You cannot miss the sunday fair, with all the antiques and street performers. Nice day program, just a bit too hot in the summer...

Great people watching. We walked around the Sunday fair but didn't purchase anything. There were tons of antiques and it was interesting to look around at those. We sat and had coffee next to the plaza and enjoyed the view. Lots of interesting characters hanging around. Would recommend for those who like to observe.
Sunday Strollers. Nice place for a stroll on a Sunday, would recommend trying a choripan (sausage sandwich) from one of the bbqs on the street.

Very quaint and fun. Lots of people, locals and visitors walk to market on Sundays in the heart of San Thelmo neighbourhood. Street dancing and singing, performances, human statues and invisible men and the like. Colourful and lively. You can buy antiques and curiosities.

Chiquilin really hit the spot.. We had the best, most enjoyable meal of our two week trip. Thanks to our server, Bono Daniel, we experienced a meal fit for a king. He suggested the wine, which was superb. He understood our requirements for a beef rib eye cooked to perfection. And his pleasant attitude and attention was very appreciated by us. Each of us had a different request regarding how we wanted our beef cooked. Bono understood and delivered meet beyond expectation.

What to do on Sunday.... We spent a glorious Sunday in San Telmo. What a delightful, exhilarating part of Buenos Aires. The market stretches down one road as far as the eye can see, for approximately ten blocks in this historic part of the city. Stall after stall adorned with original artworks, handcrafts, jewelry, clothing, leather ware, curios, books, antiques and collectibles have something for everyone. Then you have the vendors selling freshly barbecued Choripans, spicy Chorizo sausages on fresh pan(bread), or tender pieces of Argentina's finest steak on a roll, the inviting aromas tempting you to overindulge! The tree lined cobbled street is also home to a myriad of antique dealers whose premises are within the beautiful old, restored buildings on both sides of the street market. Finally at the top end of the road the smell of freshly ground coffee lures you into one of the coffee shops where strains of live tango music waft through the air and couples impromptu-ally dance in the square outside. What a joy to behold.

Make sure to see the market. The best thing about San Telmo is the sunday market. An absolute must see, with plenty of street vendors and music and tango being performed. A few nice bars around to have a breather and grab some food as well.

A bit touristy but worth it!. First advice: as all tourist places, beware of your belongings if you want to spend a pleasant time in San Telmo. Walk around the plaza, the bars, the Iglesia de San Pedro Telmo and adventure until the small hills of Parque Lezama. Enjoy a cold beer with peanuts and watch people walk by. Sunday's markets are also very interesting.

A decadent and charming part of the city. In San Telmo, where we were stayed, you can walk anddiscover many interesting houses and shops, like L'Ago (Str. La Defense, near de Market of San Telmo), go to Dorrego Place, were a fair in Sundays sells many interesting new and old things, and where you can see tango dancers free. So you can take R. La Defense and go until Rua Chile, and take a photo with Mafalda (cartoon very popular in 60's).

Highly recommended. This is the place to visit on a Sunday. There is an Antiques Fair here, but for us the highlight was just walking through the streets and visiting the market stalls in the street or in the square. There is a huge variety of quite unique shops (there's a great chocolate shop with innovative and really novel packaging) and the best selection of leather goods - apart from Calle Gurruchaga, 861 Palermo, an area of outlet shops with quality goods at reasonable prices.San Telmo is a great place to go on a Sunday to soak up the atmosphere and visit really different types of shops - a really worthwhile experience.

A must go on Sunday!. The sunday markets in San Telmo along the cobble stone street 'Defensa' is a must must do! Hopefully you have a Saturday and Sunday in Buenos Aires to explore all the awesome artesenal markets in the city- they are excellent!This is a huge long street of markets for about 30 blocks! awesome!San Telmo in itself is such an antique place with a good lot of history. The buildings are fantastic and has some good little hidden restaurants and bars. I have heard there are some good backpackers places to stay in San Telmo also. A great place for people who want to use public transport like the subway and buses!have you camera ready- San Telmo is vibey and fun!

A MUST!. Amazing place to buy anything you imagine, especially antiques, great restaurants and places to buy souvenirs or decorations. This place is a must for every tourist who visits buenos aires, here you can find the "old" buenos aires.

Birthplace of Tango. San Telmo is the heart of Buenos Aires. The streets are littered wit local art, dance, and music. Explored the market for an entire day looking at the crafts; saw tango on the street, bought art, and marvelled at the beautiful architechture... it had so much character.Tourists beware. Neighborhood exploration here puts you at risk for theft. Gaurd your posessions. Although my wife and I were spared, I'm sure there are many pickpocketers.We decided it was best to stay in Palermo, even though San Telmo was our favorite spot in BA to visit.

The perfect location to stay in Buenos Aires. Full of its decadent glamour San Telmo is the oldest area in town, several hotels and parkings availble with affordable prices and various bars to sit and have a drink of Quilmes while the capital runs like crazy. Safe place if compared to other areas and has a street fair that sells every sort of things.

Great part of the city. This area of the city is older. It was fantastic to see the change in the city and all the old culture. The antique shops are interesting and offer lots of stuff if you like old stuff.

Don't miss Sunday in San Telmo!. If you find yourself in Buenos Aires on ANY Sunday, it would be tragic to miss this scene. Start in the thick of things at Plaza Dorrego and then go off in any direction. Go hungry as there are nearly 50 eateries within a 5 block radius. World-class antiques are everywhere with street entertainers putting a smile on faces from young to old. Truly not to be missed!

Wonderful way to spend Sunday morning in Buenos Aires.. Grill Room at The Squareisited on a Sunday morning, quite early, so at first it was quite quiet. Busied up as it got later. The antiques are amazing (wish we had similar in Scotland) and lentiful. The atmosphere was very Buenos Airian, with live tango, loud tango music and street performers.Veering off from the main square are the antique shops with some of the most extravagant wares I have ever seen, ranging from toys and jewellery to furniture and lighting. Old churches, side streets, bars and eateries all contribute to the experience.Be wary of bar prices though, I noticed a 400% mark up on the price of a Quilmes in a bar on the square. Still though, it's probably what I expected.Go and see for yourself, there's no words can really explain the great atmosphere.

It is the place to be on Sunday morning. Have that in your schedule : San Telmo on Sunday morning - antiques fair, Mercado de San Telmo, street musicians, artists, tango, crafts, restaurants, cafés notables , and much more. With so much going on, look up too and do not miss the opportunity to enjoy the beautiful balconies of the houses in this picturesque neighborhood of Buenos Aires. To get there, a short walk down the subway station Independence.

Never on a Thursday. This may well be the best place on earth on Sunday as others have claimed---I don't know. But on Thursday night, it is dead dead dead, and not all that exciting. If I had it to do over, i wouldn't bother unless I was able to take people's Sunday-is-the-right-time advice.

Visit San Telmo on a SUNDAY!. Check out San Telmo on a Sunday to see one of the best street fairs around. They have great crafts, art, music and food available at great prices. If you don't want to purchase anything then you can enjoy it without spending a dime! Great things to eat are Pan Rellenos (similar to Calzones). Look for a group called Aqualactica who are one of my favorite musicians in Buenos Aires.

Nifty neighborhood with many layers of fun.. I spent quite a few days in San Telmo during my nine days in Buenos Aires, both visiting local attractions and passing through. I really think there is something here for everyone.Flea markets/antique stores: Just a walk down Defensa Street to Mercado de San Telmo sets the vibe for these. If you can't find something the suits your fancy then the Sunday antique/artisan fair at Plaza Dorrego will fill the void.Restaurants: Too numerous to mention. I visited Bar el Federal (see separate review) but there is a cuisine to fit anyone's taste.Mafalda: The famous Argentine cartoon character is found on the corner of Chile and Defensa. She's cute!Museums: El Zanyon (see separate review) sets the standard here. Other options include the Modern Art museum and Museo del Cine. There is plenty of history here, you just have to peel back the layers a bit.Atmosphere: Well, this is what brings it down from five to four stars, largely because I visited during the winter (end of July). Needless to say there was a shortage of street performers and entertainers here at the time so I didn't really appreciate the atmosphere that much; I will defer on that to other reviewers.

San Telmo flea market - great, charming and full of action. San Telmo flea market is amazing. It is charming, full of all sorts of stuff you might find - street performers (original), tango pozers (haven't seen dancers the day I visited), antiques, pre-loved clothing and crowds of people. A super cool place to go. A must if you are in Buenos Aires!

Worth a visit on a Sunday. Whilst we didn’t have long in San Telmo, during our Sunday afternoon visit, it was clear the area had a good vibe. Arriving at San Juan station on the C Line, we were warned by a local to take care whilst in the area. However, we saw little sign of any trouble en route to Plaza Dorrego or in the square itself. As you walk further south down Calle Defensa, the area becomes decidedly edgier. But we still felt fairly safe. Be aware of your possessions and the people around you, and you will have a good and safe time.The antiques market itself was quite interesting. I particularly enjoyed the soda siphon stores.I’d definitely recommend paying the area a visit on a Sunday and would have liked to have stayed for longer.

hip pubs in antique locations - check Krakow. Historic San Telmo is packed with very bohemian pubs and bars frequented by young international crowd. These places have very special unpretentious vibe created by timeless surroundings. Besides others already mentioned in previous reviews Krakow Cafe Bar on Venezuela 474 right of Defensa comes to mind. You think of an old tavern or pub when you enter the place filled with friendly crowd and then you spot the Nintendo Wii and hear the latest music.Trust me, the experience is unforgettable, so plan to spend an evening in San Telmo.
San Telmo fascinante. I went to San Telmo on may 2008, and it was wonderful, the people, the street shows... I couldn't speend all the day there, but I promise myself to return back...

Interesting place...BUT watch out!. I am an American woman traveling alone in BA (very saavy world traveler), and yesterday afternoon/evening in Plaza Dorrego I was robbed not once, but TWICE --different occasions. The first time I bought something from a seemingly nice young street vendor who subsequently sat down with me to talk afterwards at the outside table of the Cafe Dorrego. Well, long story short, he tried to run off with my very expensive, professional Nikon that was sitting on the table directly in front of me. I had some other people around me and we stopped him. Very upsetting. Again, I did not walk away from my camera, it was just sitting directly in front of me, and the man seemed so nice.The second time a waiter from a restaurant I had never been to called me over to tell me he had my passport. I said no you dont! He said YES I DO! ??????? My passport was zipped into the inside of my purse in a very secure pocket. Not anymore! Apparantly he retrieved it for me when he saw some men with it. Very bizarre. Again, I am not a careless woman, and it wasn´t that late in the evening.Also, beware of the cute little kids everywhere in BA. They also tried to run off with my stuff while their mother watched.

A favorite part of BA. Definitely worth your time. Make sure to walk down "Defensa" street to check out all the street musicians and performers. The Sunday market itself didn't appeal to me, because it is not artisans, just antiques. Being out among the people and enjoying the colonial atmosphere was the best.
Sunday Market Worth a Visit. There is just so much going on at the Sunday makret. What a great way t wander, and people watch.

Great Tango. Lovely little atmosphereic cafes, the flea market, diverse(!) entertainers and some of the best tango in town - head to San Telmo on a Sunday for a taste of how BA might have been before Dior, Harrods, Ralf Lauren etc all hit town.
Dirty, crumbling and dusty but brilliant - a must see!

Go to the Sunday Antique Fair!. Every Sunday, San Telmo is transformed into a great outdoor antique fair...It is wonderful...live music, tons of things to buy, lots of poeple...Great place to spend the morning on Sundays...Very lively...I truly enjoyed it...

Loved Every Second. I was in Buenos Aires in February of 2006 for a family wedding. LODGING:We stayed at the Hotel Internacional on the main drag, may be a 1/4 mile from the obelisk (sp?). Good hotel, rooms were clean, staff was accommodating. They were redoing some of the marble in the lobby. From what we saw during our stay, it's gonna look great when it's done. There's a place right next door that makes a mean empenada de pollo. A few of those and a great big Quilmes, and I was loving life! Head out the front door and hang a left, they're right there. FOOD/DRINKS/NIGHTLIFEIf you like wine and beef, you will think you've died and gone to heaven. There was the greatest little resto bar in the San Telmo section of the city called Todo Mundo! Address is Anselmo Aieta 1095 tel is 4362-2354. I wish I could boast that my memory is just THAT good, but I snagged a napkin with their info on it before we left. I keep it in my wallet as a reminder of our trip. Their house red is some sort of malbec and it was so good, we brought a few bottles home with us. Live music every night we were there, and a tango show upstairs in the the balcony. There was a little old lady selling roses, which was cute the 1st night. not so much the 2nd, 3rd or 4th night.This is a prime wine growing region, so treat this like a trip to napa valley. Try as many wines as you can. Don't stick with the "safe" choices. With a 3:1 exchange rate in favor of the American dollar, you really can't go wrong. If you like Beef, this is gonna be your town. There are awesome restaurantes everywhere, but there's a place called La Estancia. It's on one of the foot-traffic malls. Can't remember the name of the mall now, but some of the taxi drivers know the restaurante by name. I had one of the best meals of my life there. Don't let the cafeteria look of the place run you off. They bring out your food on a huge platter with hot coals in another pan underneath it to keep it piping hot. Just remembering the smell is enough to get my mouth watering again. SHOPPINGSince this city serves up so much beef, they have to do something wih all of that leather. Oddly enough, the leather prices rivaled those in America, but after you take the exchange rate into account, you make out on the deal. There are leather shops literally everywhere.SAFETYJust remember where you're from. If you're an American, bear in mind you might not be very popular with some people there. Fortunately, the police presence in this city was pretty strong. Could have had something to do with the protests that were going on that week. If you stick to the touristy areas you should be fine.

best place in the world!. San Telmo - is there any place like it? I have never been to a place so atmospheric or so redolent of other places. Paris (Le Marais). parts of Naples even Cape Town in places, it is steeped in history but it never stops moving.Some places to try: La Brigada a huge parilla (beef restaurant) though obviously not if you are vegetarian, Plaza Dorrego on Sunday afternoon for the vibe, Abril for amazing food with incredibly reasonable prices (and waitresses who all look like Penelope Cruz) the list is endless. Just when I think I know San Telmo I turn a corner and something else (new or old) is there. The nature of the architecture (courtyards and conventillos) means there is always something hidden, something to discover.

The heart of Buenos Aires. If you are in Buenos Aires over a weekend, San Telmo is not to be missed on a Sunday. After living in Buenos Aires for 3 months, this was my favourite place. The Antiques Market definitely lives up to its reputation. Busy, exciting, entertaining, different - this place is unmissable. Aside from the antiques shops and market, there are various crafts fairs along the side streets, tango dancers and musicians giving free (fantastic) performances, great eateries and other street performers like puppeteers and statue men. Great for kids aswell as adults. You feel like you've been transported back in time with the cobbled streets and the ancient looking shop façades. However, don't go on any other day than Sunday - its really quiet and you'll be sorely disappointed.
